PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate and the senators in Parliament assembled:
The Humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That every abortion kills an unborn human baby.
That the right to life of all humans is the most fundamental and essential of all human rights.
That the Government's first duty is to protect this right to life.
That the most defenceless and threatened lives are those of unborn babies for whom the Government is duty bound to take extra steps to protect.
That in 1987/88 taxpayers funds through Medicare provided Medical Benefits for 61,879 abortions totalling $6.4 million.

And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Aboriginal Deaths in Custody
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
We, the undersigned Australian petitioners call on the Australian Government to take real steps to prevent the abuse of human rights of Aboriginals in prison and police custody.

A Royal Commission was set up to find out in general terms why so many Aborigines die in custody and the circumstances surrounding each death before the Commission. We, the petitioners, would like to express the following concerns:

1. Aboriginal families and organisations have not received adequate funding from the Federal Government to ensure adequate representation. Yet the Commission faces constant challenge from the powerful police and prison officers' unions in their efforts to shut down the inquiry.

2. The Royal Commission's report includes recommendations for changes in custodial practices. Yet only some of the recommendations have been implemented, and only in some places, no government body is monitoring the implementation and the deaths continue.

That whereas on 11th March 1990, the democratically elected and legal Government of Lithuania re-declared its independence from the Soviet Union into which it had been forcibly incorporated in 1940.

DEBATE.TITLE: ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION OF COASTAL WATERS (STATE AND NORTHERN TERRITORY POWERS) AMENDMENT BILL 1990

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Dunn) agreed to:

That the following Bill be introduced: A Bill for an Act to amend the Coastal Waters (State Powers) Act 1980 and the Coastal Waters (Northern Territory Powers) Act 1980 to protect the environment of coastal waters.
Motion (by Senator Dunn) agreed to:
That this Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dunn Sen I.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

Mr President, I introduce this Bill for the better protection of coastal waters in order to draw attention to a need for the Commonwealth to give national leadership in the protection of the environment.
Much has been said recently about the desirability of the Commonwealth to accept its role as a national government and to assume responsibliity for many aspects of the Australian environment.

The Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, indicated prior to the recent Federal elections the Government's intention to establish a National Environmental Protection Authority. The Environment Minister, Ms Ros Kelly, has since confirmed this intention. The Minister for Primary Industries, Mr John Kerin, has spoken in favour of a referendum to transfer powers over the environment from the States to the Commonwealth to enable the Government to legislate for environmental protection free of the limitations and impediments that are said to currently exist under our Federal system of Government.

Support for such a move has come from an unexpected quarter: the Premier of New South Wales, Mr Nick Greiner, in a statement issued on Earth Day, urged his conservative political colleagues to abandon their ``narrow obsession with States rights'' and to recognise that for some purposes at least, there should be an acceptance of the Commonwealth's role in promulgating national environmental standards.

While I am encouraged to see the emergence of some sort of consensus on this important question, I don't believe we need to wait for a referendum on environmental powers before translating some of these words into action.
Since Federation the Commonwealth has possessed a range of constitutional powers which can be used for protecting and enhancing the environment.

The Commonwealth's foreign affairs power has been used on a number of occasions to achieve better management of the environment in accordance with Australia's obligations under international conventions and treaties. Without the Commonwealth's assertion of power under the World Heritage Convention, Tasmania's Franklin River and much of Queensland's Wet Tropical forests would not have been saved. Action by the Commonwealth under other treaties has been less dramatic and there is scope for much to be done for the protection of wetlands and estuaries, for migratory bird habitats and, in the future, when appropriate international treaty obligations are established, for many other important components of our environment including our many endangered species of plants and animals.

The trade and commerce powers of the Commonwealth, particularly the power to control the activities of trading corporations, have yet to be used in a direct manner for achieving the aims of environmental policy. Since the decision of the High Court in the Tasmanian Dams Case it has been clear that the use of the corporations power to limit and regulate the impact on the environment by companies has been an option available to the Commonwealth. I introduced legislation last year, the Australian Heritage Commission (National Estate Protection) Amendment Bill 1989, intended to realise this opportunity but which has not been debated.
The Commonwealth can, and does, attach environmental conditions to licences granted to industrial undertakings pursuant to its power to control exports.
The Commonwealth has full powers of government in respect of the Territories and it has such powers in respect of the coastal sea.

It is a matter of concern to me that the Commonwealth, in an initiative of the Fraser Government in 1980, purported to abandon its responsibility for management of the Australian coastal sea and hand this over to the States and the Northern Territory. This was supposedly achieved by the passage through the Parliament of the Coastal Waters (State Powers) Act 1980 and the Coastal Waters (Northern Territory Powers) Act 1980, with cognate legislation vesting the seabed in the States and the Northern Territory, and by means of corresponding legislation passed by the Legislatures of the States and the Northern Territory.

The coastal sea environment has since then become a cause for considerable public concern and one which the Commonwealth, as the responsible government under the Australian Constitution, ought to be responding. Pollution of the sea from ocean sewage outfalls is no longer merely a matter of aesthetics. It is affecting the lives of hundreds of thousands of people. It is ruining Sydney's famous beaches. It threatens the country's tourist industry. It is bringing the products of the fishing industry, justifiably or not, into disrepute.

Proposals for kraft pulp mills at Wesley Vale in Tasmania and at Grafton on the New South Wales north coast have raised many of the same concerns. Additionally, there is the justifiable concern that organochlorine compounds which are a component of the effluent from mills of this type will contaminate fish and eventually destroy the economic base of substantial parts of the fishing industry.

The response of the Federal Government to these concerns has been unimpressive. The Commonwealth involved itself in the setting of effluent standards for the proposed pulp mill at Wesley Vale not as the government directly responsible for the management of that part of Australia's territory and environment, but merely as the licensor of a proposed exporting industry. It behaved almost as though it were an onlooker, deferring as much as possible to the State Government. On the issue of ocean sewage pollution, the Commonwealth has involved itself even less, treating the problems as matters for State Governments to handle. It has accepted the Fraser Government's attempt to vacate this area in favour of the States as a fait accompli.

The Bill I have introduced is designed to dispel the illusion that the Commonwealth has no direct responsibility for our coastal sea, and to assist in the establishment of uniform national standards for the protection of this very significant part of the Australian environment.

The Bill would amend the Coastal Waters (State Powers) Act 1980 in order to give the Commonwealth express powers to formulate codes of practice for the conduct of environmentally sensitive operations within the coastal sea and, in the event that a State does not comply with and apply such codes, to make regulations for their enforcement.

Clause 4 of the Bill defines an ``environmentally sensitive operation'' to include the discharge of sewage or industrial effluent, the dumping of wastes and fishing within coastal waters which in turn are defined to include the sea bed and subsoil beneath those waters.

Clause 5 would empower the Minister to arrange for the formulation of codes of practice for regulating environmentally sensitive operations, subject to an obligation to consult with the appropriate Minister of the State and other Commonwealth Ministers, and subject also to a right in the public to comment.

I consider the provision for public involvement in the formulation of codes of practice to be most important. The pollution standards which the Commonwealth sought to negotiate with the Tasmanian Government and the promoter in the case of the Wesley Vale pulp mill were criticised for permitting vaguely defined organochlorine levels and for their lack of credible safeguards against the contamination of fisheries. Pollution standards for pulp mills subsequently promoted by the Commonwealth have been rejected by responsible organisations such as Ocean Watch which has a brief from the fishing industry in New South Wales to protect its resource. The Commonwealth must ensure that the public is consulted in the formulation of environmental standards and that the codes of practice that emerge reflect a real consensus.

The Governor-General would be enabled to approve codes of practice so formulated and which specify standards to be observed, practices and procedures to be followed and measures (including restoration measures) to be taken with respect to an environmentally sensitive operation conducted within coastal waters.

Codes of practice approved in this manner would be advisory, in the expectation that the States would regulate in accordance with their terms under their own laws. In the event that this did not occur, power is given to the Governor-General to make regulations which would prevail over conflicting State laws.
The Coastal Waters (Northern Territory) Act 1980 would be amended to achieve the same effect in respect of coastal waters adjacent to the Northern Territory.

It is my intention in introducing this Bill to draw attention to the unsatisfactory situation which presently exists in this country, where States bid against one another for polluting industries by offering varying environmental standards. The opportunities available to promoters of such developments to ``shop around'' for the most lenient jurisdiction in which to establish a new industry would be curtailed with the passage of this legislation.

The tendency of less developed States to regard the more polluted condition of waters prevailing in developed areas as some sort of ceiling to which they are free to rise before applying comparable environmental controls, would also be discouraged.
I commend the Bill to this House.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

This Bill proposes to amend the Bounty Textile Yarns Act 1981 to provide persons currently eligible for bounty under the Act with an alternative in the form of a once-off capitalisation grant paid in lieu of possible future bounty receipts.

The Bill gives effect to the Government's decision announced on 30 January 1990 to introduce an alternative scheme for textile yarn producers which gives a new impetus for restructuring the industry and achieving the textiles, clothing and footwear (TCF) plan objectives.

At the same time the scheme will generate net reductions in budgetary outlays in net present value terms. Capitalisation grants will apply only to the current bounty period and should not be seen as pre-empting arrangements for the industry beyond June 1995.
Production of most textile yarns has been provided bounty assistance since 1982 and this is continuing as part of the TCF plan which is scheduled to run to 30 June 1995.

Bounties for textile yarns are an integral part of assistance arrangements for the textiles industry. They have been preferred to tariffs as a form of assistance to help contain input costs to the downstream fabric, clothing and finished textile product sectors. This has enabled those sectors to operate with lower protection levels than would otherwise have been the case.

The TCF plan provides for progressive reductions in bounty rates to 30% of manufacturing value added by March 1994 and then maintenance at that rate until mid-1995. While costly in budgetary terms ($87.9m in 1988-89), this assistance is phasing down to a tariff equivalent of approximately 15%.

Spinning of yarns is the most lightly assisted activity within textiles and clothing production and it is at the forefront of the Government's efforts to restructure and revitalise these industries in Australia.
The yarns sector is the vehicle by which we can make real progress in developing an internationally competitive synthetic yarn industry and in adding value to Australia's wool clip and cotton crop.

A discussion paper was released last September for a review of textile yarn bounty administration by the textiles, clothing and footwear development authority. In subsequent consultations on that paper, a number of firms indicated that a once-off grant in lieu of ongoing bounty would help stimulate the investment necessary for them to become more competitive. In many cases, significant changes to manufacturing operations are required.

Hence the proposal in clause 8 of this Bill to amend the Bounty (Textile Yarns) Act 1981 by introducing a new part 3 for ``Capitalisation Grants'', as an alternative to ongoing bounty payments to textile yarn producers.

I should point out that, as proposed in this bill, applications for capitalisation grants will be open to all those who would be eligible for bounty assistance under the textile yarn bounty scheme. Further, introduction of capitalisation grants will be without prejudice to those who elect not to apply and instead continue receiving payments under the textile yarn bounty scheme.

Applications for capitalisation grants must be made to the textiles, clothing and footwear development authority, which is responsible for administering the TCF plan, pursuant to proposed new section 21b on page 3 of the attached bill. Applications should include details of anticipated bounty receipts to mid-1995 under the textile yarn bounty scheme, together with an estimate of the grant sought, and details of how the grant will be applied.

Applications must include a business plan outlining the applicant's business objectives in relation to the production in Australia of bountiable yarn and other TCF products and the marketing of such products, and the applicant's plans for achieving those objectives on a yearly basis against certain criteria specified in proposed subsection 21b (2); notably, the applicant's plans in terms of organisational restructuring, investment, research and development and sales and marketing.

The authority must consider the application pursuant to proposed new section 21c on page 4 having regard to whether the business plan is financially viable, whether it is consistent with the objectives of the TCF plan, and whether the making of a grant is consistent with Australia's International obligations, including obligations under the ANZCERTA agreement with New Zealand.

Additionally, the authority must have regard to whether the grant sought, or any lesser grant, would be likely to result in reduced budgetary outlays by the Commonwealth (in net present value terms) relative to that which would be the case if the applicant continued to receive payments under the textile yarn bounty scheme.

Following its consideration of the application, the authority must make a recommendation to the minister either for a grant equal to or less than that requested in the application, or no grant at all. The minister's decision must be advised to the applicant with a broad statement of the recommendation of the authority. Where an offer of a grant is made, the offer is subject to the applicant entering into a capitalisation agreement with the authority on behalf of the commonwealth. That agreement may be subject to such terms and conditions as the minister thinks appropriate for achieving the objectives of the business plan pursuant to proposed new sections 21e and 21f on page 5 and 6 of the bill.

Importantly, a failure to meet the terms and conditions included in a capitalisation agreement will, on demand, render the total grant repayable to the Commonwealth, pursuant to proposed new subsection 21f (5). Circumstances beyond the control of individuals however, such as sudden changes in economic conditions, would be an obvious mitigating reason should persons defer, or not be able to fully undertake, a proposed investment which has been nominated as one of the objectives of the business plan.

Finally, and as I mentioned at the introduction of this speech, a person who accepts the offer of a capitalisation grant becomes ineligible to receive bounty in respect of any textile yarn produced on or after the day on which the grant is made, as provided by proposed new section 21h.

The essence of the new part to the Bounty (Textile Yarns) Act which I have just described is to provide an alternative to bounty assistance that will encourage more rapid progress towards an internationally competitive textiles industry in Australia. Capitalisation grants offer the potential for major investments in new spinning facilities which would operate without bounties and without tariffs for the remainder of the TCF plan. That is, the dawning of an internationally competitive textiles industry.

Let us not underestimate the challenge facing the Australian Textiles Industry. Already there has been progress, for example, in the cotton sector with major modern facilities in Actil by textiles industries of Australia (South Australia), in Bonds Industries by Pacific Dunlop (New South Wales), and by Rocklea (Victoria and Queensland).

Capitalisation grants could be of value to firms engaged in restructuring the Australian textiles industry. They could provide for rationalisation and reconstruction of plants by individual firms, mergers between existing players, new entrants combining with existing producers to build new plants. Investment in buildings (provided they are purpose-built), plant, equipment and systems could embrace spinning or related manufacturing like knitting, weaving, dyeing or finishing.

This approach helps both those who have already invested in spinning as well as vertically integrated producers whose activities extend downstream from spinning. Investment requirements are ongoing and financial restructuring is needed to help those who have modernised get on to the business of manufacturing and international marketing.

Substantial effort is required to restructure and develop the Australian wool, cotton and synthetic fibre industry. As imports gain more liberalised access under the TCF Plan, firms must invest and become internationally competitive. Even more so, new investment is essential if Australia is to meaningfully add value to our wool and cotton crops.
Capitalisation grants are a potential vehicle for rebuilding Australia's textile industries while, at the same time, reducing budgetary outlays by the Commonwealth.
Financial Impact Statement
Under current textile yarn bounty arrangements, Commonwealth outlays between 1 July 1990 and 30 June 1995 are estimated in present dollar values on a financial year basis as follows:
$85.96 million for 1990-91; $83.04 million for 1991-92; $81.13 million for 1992-93; $76.67 million for 1993-94; and $74.14 million for 1994-95; total: $400.94 million.

The capitalisation grant scheme proposed in this Bill as an alternative in lieu of future bounty receipts, is conditional in each instance upon there being a lesser outlay by the Commonwealth on a net present value basis than the outlay required if the applicant had continued to claim bounty in respect of bountiable yarn produced without the benefits of a capitalisation grant. But the legal tangle does not stop there. No amounts have been paid to members of Parliament. The money is actually paid to Australia Post. Australia Post is thereby commissioned to provide services to members of Parliament.

I remind honourable senators that the High Court refused to make those declarations.

That is what the High Court proceeded to do. In the absence of any other judgments of the Court on these matters, I believe it was open, quite properly, to the Government to proceed in the manner in which it did proceed, legally. I am not disputing the proposition whether or not it had a moral claim to do so, but undoubtedly it was able to proceed legally. A member of Parliament was then legally entitled to proceed and use the services offered.

We are now faced with the exercise of whether we want to proceed with punitive retrospective legislation. This Parliament has done so before and will probably do so again, but on no occasion have I lent my vote to that and I do not intend to do so today.

Regarding the moral argument about what ought to have happened, I stand by the argument which I made last year-that is, the Government should not have engaged in this exercise. It ought to have referred the matter to the Remuneration Tribunal and the Tribunal ought to have made a determination. I do not know what the Remuneration Tribunal would make of this proposition and nor does anybody else here. Although they have not appeared to date, I presume that amendments will be brought forward to rectify all the other contexts which are undoubtedly in identical legal circumstances and were not, in fact, open to members to use. What is at hand it seems to me, from reading all the relevant documents, reading the High Court judgment, reading the opinions of the legal advisers, is whether the opinions were shopped for or not. I do not think it really did a great deal of good, because I know of many constituents who were very cheesed off with getting two, three or four letters in the post from the same individual within a month. Nevertheless, let us get the matter clearly in perspective. It is not really topping up; it was for a purely political purpose.

SPEECH.PARA: We are now in a position of having before us a piece of legislation which will retrospectively endorse that decision taken by the Minister in the other place. The question is whether we support this legislation, which retrospectively endorses that decision. I do not see the amendment proposed by Senator Parer as being in effect punitive retrospective legislation. Such legislation would be punitive only if there were a previous entitlement-and there was not a previous entitlement granted by the appropriate authority, in this case the Remuneration Tribunal. It had not made that determination.

It has been suggested by Senator Macklin that an analogous case is what happened when the Remuneration Tribunal abandoned the field as to parliamentary staff and it was taken over by the Government. That is a matter which I should like to see back in the hands of the Remuneration Tribunal; but the fact is that it was taken over by the Government and that was agreed presumably by all parties. In this case, however, we have the problem where the Remuneration Tribunal's determination is in existence and there has been a top-up for the purpose that I have mentioned. I heard what the Minister said as to whether the amount of money that has been expended can be recouped even if this amendment goes through. It certainly can be recouped. From whom is a moot point.

I agree with Senator Parer that it is one thing to get a verbal opinion, but quite another to get a written opinion, with reasons provided. I think that is the least that we should get here; but even if we got that I am not so sure that the Attorney-General's Department's opinion would necessarily be influential. I wonder whether the Attorney-General was asked by the Minister in the other place for his opinion when the Minister there made the decision to provide this substantial amount of money, $30,982, to each and every member of the House of Representatives. I wonder whether the Attorney-General was asked his opinion on that occasion, and I wonder what opinion he would have given in that circumstance. Was there any opinion available to the Minister at that time-and I am asking the Minister-as to the legality or otherwise of that decision?

TALK.START.PARA: —He got a friendly opinion.
—There was an opinion, was there, at that time?
—But it was wrong.
—But was that from the Attorney-General's Department?
—I believe so.

—If it came from the Attorney-General's Department, that makes me even more worried about the Minister's statement that we should now vote against the amendment because of an opinion from the Attorney-General's Department. If it was wrong in the first instance, who is to say that it will not be wrong in this instance as well?
—Order! Is the honourable senator seeking information from the Minister?

—Yes; no doubt that will come forward when the Minister responds. The question I am asking is as follows: prior to the Minister in the other place, the former Minister for Administrative Services, last year providing an extra amount of money to House of Representatives members, did he have an opinion which indicated that that decision would be quite proper, lawful and would withstand any challenge? If he did, it would have been a strange opinion, because subsequent events in the High Court have shown that it did not stand up to challenge. We are being asked by the Minister to reject the amendment moved by Senator Parer on the ground of an oral opinion with which he has indicated the Attorney-General's Department has provided him. I do not disbelieve the Minister. I am sure that the Attorney-General's Department has provided him with an oral opinion. But it is testing our credulity a little to ask now to vote against an amendment on the basis of such an oral opinion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Therapeutic Goods Regulations and the Therapeutic Goods (Charges) Regulations, as contained in Statutory Rules Nos 88 and 89 of 1990 and made under the Therapeutic Goods Act 1989 and the Therapeutic Goods (Charges) Act 1989, be disallowed.

There have been some consultations about this matter in the past hour and it seems somewhat confusing. For that reason it is not my intention, or that of others in this place, to have a long debate at this time.

This is an unusual situation because in this case the regulations require a positive motion of the Senate for their approval. Nonetheless, they are still subject to the 15 sitting day rule. Moreover the Act under which the regulations operate will not become operational until those regulations are passed. It is a somewhat confusing situation.

The Senate will recall that earlier there was some confusion as to whether the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) was seeking an adjournment of the debate or whether he was seeking to withdraw the regulations altogether. Certainly the Australian Democrats have some difficulty with particular parts of these regulations. However, let me put it on record fairly and squarely, as I did at the time of the debate on the therapeutic goods legislation, that we are in favour of it and we are also in favour of the broad thrust of the regulations. However, we do have difficulty with particular parts-the areas of advertising, fees, appropriate representation and the provision of information to the committees which will make assessments in these areas.

In view of the matters which occurred earlier this morning in relation to the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services (Mr Staples) wishing to allow a longer time, it seems appropriate that these regulations should be disallowed at this stage so that the decks are cleared and there are no regulations before either House of Parliament. That leaves the Minister in a situation in which he can, at a later time, bring back these regulations or some amended regulations which can then be considered. The sooner that is set in place, the clearer everyone will be. Then the definitive regulations, in whatever form, can be brought back and debated.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I indicated earlier this morning, the Opposition supports this proposal. When the Therapeutic Goods Bill was before us last year, the Senate amended that Bill to provide that the Act itself would not commence until after each House of the Parliament had approved regulations by a positive mechanism-that is, each House of the Parliament had to approve the regulations by a positive vote within a period of 90 days and with certain other technical qualifications. Last week Senator Tate, representing the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services (Mr Staples) put down a motion which appears on the Notice Paper. Originally it was to be decided today but subsequently, under standing order 77, it was postponed to a later day in order to allow that procedure to be followed. That was a motion that, in accordance with section 2 of the Therapeutic Goods Act, the Senate approves the Therapeutic Goods Regulations, as contained in Statutory Rules 1990 No. 88, made under the Act and tabled in the Senate on 8 May.

SPEECH.PARA: In the meantime, regulations were also being proceeded with in the normal fashion in terms of being gazetted and they have attracted the attention of the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances. Through Senator Colston, a motion was put down seeking their disallowance on the grounds that they may not be in conformity with the normal tests which the Regulations and Ordinances Committee applies to these matters. The same regulations attracted a motion from Senator Coulter, who sought to strike them down for different reasons-reasons which go to questions of consultation with the industry; whether they are perceived to be fair and proper on the basis of the charges involved and the exclusion of certain interests relating to herbalists and naturopaths; whether they are over bureaucratic and do not take sufficient account of the information available from overseas testing and licensing authorities; whether the costs and the fees are appropriate; whether there are appropriate appeals mechanisms; and whether there is a duplication of legislation between the Commonwealth and the States covering exactly the same areas of regulation. So, we have got ourselves into a slightly confused situation in which the motions of Senator Coulter, the Minister and the Regulations and Ordinances Committee-all on pretty much the same subject-are all floating around.

Then there is the question of whether the regulations have a particular standing under the Acts Interpretation Act, or whether they do not as a result of the passage of the Therapeutic Goods Act, and whether at a subsequent time section 2 of the Therapeutic Goods Act supersedes the provisions of the Acts Interpretation Act.

In order to bring about some resolution of these matters, we think that the course of action now proposed is correct-namely that pro forma, without a debate of the substance of the issues that I and the Regulations and Ordinances Committee have raised, we should simply strike down these regulations and allow the Government to go back and look at two matters.

Those matters are, first, the concerns about the actual issues which may need consultation. I understand that the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services is prepared to have some consultation with affected parties during the course of the recess. The second is to make absolutely clear, to the extent that we can, the exact legal position vis-a-vis the Therapeutic Goods Act, the Acts Interpretation Act and the regulation making procedures and mechanisms of this chamber and of the other place.

For that reason we will support the motion which has been moved. As a result, the decks will be cleared and in the Budget session the Government can come back, having sorted out the issues of principle and the legal questions which arise about the status of these regulations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

The proposal here is, as the Opposition was attempting to do, to leave out that particular subsection, because on our reading it will in fact limit the Remuneration Tribunal's range, and our feeling is that, for a sensible determination from the Tribunal, it must be given the broadest possible scope to look at all these matters and, hopefully, at some stage regularise the entire context.

Again, the study done last year certainly points the way to a wholesale rationalisation. I hope that this Parliament will do that, unlike what it has done in the past with regard to these matters where political advantage has been seen and taken, and that in fact the Tribunal's determination, when it has sat down and worked out what should be done, is allowed. A lot of fine words have been uttered in this debate so far about the Tribunal but, quite frankly, in terms of the history of this place, its reaction to the Tribunal has been, every time it has made a determination, to denigrate that determination.

I do not think one can have it both ways. There may be splendid people on the tribunal, but one cannot say that their judgment is so fatally flawed that, every time they make a determination, it happens to be wrong. If honourable senators believe that it is a good way of doing it, at some stage this Parliament should either commit itself to supporting the determinations of the tribunal or get rid of the tribunal, as I suggested the last time we went through this silly exercise.
