TALK.START.PARA: —I suggest that the second reading debate on the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2) 1989-90 be taken cognately with the Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 1989-90, Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 1989-90, Supply (Parliamentary Departments) Bill 1990-91, Supply Bill (No. 1) 1990-91 and Supply Bill (No. 2) 1990-91.
—If there is no objection, I will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus) has just said, and the Senate agreed, we are debating cognately a traditional package of six Bills-the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2) 1989-90, the Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 1989-90, and the Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 1989-90, Supply (Parliamentary Departments) Bill 1990-91, Supply Bill (No. 1) 1990-91 and the Supply Bill (No. 2) 1990-91.

SPEECH.PARA: The three Appropriation Bills appropriate moneys to meet essential and unavoidable expenditures which are additional to those authorised by Parliament in the Appropriation Bills presented following the annual Budget. The three Supply Bills-namely, Supply Bill (No. 1) 1990-91, Supply Bill (No. 2) 1990-91, and Supply (Parliamentary Departments) Bill 1990-91-seek appropriations for the services, including capital works, of the Government for the period from 1 July to 30 November 1990, by which date it is expected that the Appropriation Bills which will form part of the next Budget, the 1990 Budget, will have been enacted and they will, of course, subsume these Supply Bills. The Supply Bills are in their traditional form. They normally appropriate five-twelfths of the expected expenditure based on last year's expenditure of the Government to get its operations running through those first five months of the next financial year. I have no further comment to offer on those Bills.

Coming back to the three Appropriation Bills before the Senate, additional appropriations contained in the Bills generally fall into two categories. First, there are additional requirements of an ongoing nature which result primarily from cost and price increases and other parameter variations which have arisen since the Budget was drawn up-in this case now more than nine months ago. To the extent that the forecast parameters at that time were set at overly optimistic levels, a scenario with which we are only too familiar with our current Treasurer (Mr Keating), these parameter variations result in additional expenditures if they have been too optimistically forecast. That is therefore effectively a loosening of fiscal policy, and that is what we are seeing with these Appropriation Bills-a loosening of a fiscal policy which is already far too loose. I will come back to that later in my remarks.

The Government is very sensitive about these parameter variations, so sensitive in fact that its contribution, other than in relation to the national wage case decision, to the Additional Estimates is not available for public scrutiny. That allows the Government and the Treasurer to set unrealistic parameters and provide a false view of the economic situation for months before the additional appropriations are brought to account. We have had plenty of evidence of the Treasurer putting his head in the sand over the current state of the economy in recent times. Again, I will come back to that later in my remarks.

The second general category of additional appropriations relates to those required to meet commitments approved by the Government since the Budget was prepared last year. The amount sought in the additional appropriations this year in gross terms, an amount in excess of $1,000m and a net figure of $664.7m, is huge by recent standards. The net $664.7m compares with $217m last year, 1988-89, and only $89m in 1987-88. That huge increase compared with recent years is evidence of the vote-buying bill that was chalked up by this Government in the months preceding the election, and it is also the result of the gross mismanagement, by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in particular, of the debilitating pilots dispute last year. Of the total additional appropriations sought of $664.7m, nearly $125m is attributable solely to additional expenditures associated with the pilots strike. One can very strongly assert that the pilots dispute and the $125m that it has cost the taxpayer through these additional appropriations are due to the fact that the Government did not have the ability or the courage to tackle the pilots dispute through the proper channels and particularly because it was unprepared to take on the union movement at large as distinct from the Australian Federation of Air Pilots over the issue.

The Minister for Finance (Mr Willis) said in his second reading speech in the other place that the additional appropriations add 0.8 per cent to total estimated outlays. That figure is correct in a technical sense, but the additional appropriations do not include special or standing appropriations. The more appropriate measure of additional appropriations needs to consider the percentage increase in annual appropriations only. That shows an increase, not of 0.8 per cent but of three times that, namely, 2.3 per cent. This relaxation of outlays comes at a time when it appears that the forecast Budget surplus for 1989-90 is likely to be undermined by significantly smaller revenues than expected at Budget time and, as I say, accompanied by an expenditure overrun.

On the basis of the data available for the first nine months of this financial year, the increases in outlays and the shortfalls in revenue suggest that the Government could be facing a Budget surplus around 20 per cent smaller than was forecast at Budget time. The Budget forecast was for a surplus of $9.2 billion. There is every indication on the basis of the first nine months figures that that surplus will come in at less than $8 billion. This is just one manifestation, but one of many, of the loss of control which is evident in the Government's policy settings generally. It is for that reason that I move the following second reading amendment-which I think has been circulated-on behalf of the Opposition to Appropriation Bill (No. 3).
I move:
At end of motion, add ``but the Senate notes:
(a) the worrying relaxation of fiscal policy, as signalled by additional gross expenditure since the 1989 budget of over $1 billion;
(b) that the Hawke/Keating Government should immediately formulate a tighter fiscal strategy involving budget cut-backs;
(c) that this strategy should be accompanied by the announcement of a comprehensive anti-inflationary strategy that must include extensive labour market and micro-economic reform; and

(d) that the Australian economy cannot hope to deal with its stagflationary problems and enormous growth in foreign debt unless the Government adopts a tighter fiscal strategy and a comprehensive anti-inflation strategy as matters of urgency.''

I would like to look at each of those four points of major concern to the Opposition. Indeed, they are of major concern to the whole nation. In recent days we have seen exposed a government which is deeply divided in its views and in which the senior economic Ministers cannot even agree as to whether the economy is in recession or not.

This Government is clearly in chaos. It is deeply divided. A deeply divided government is a government which cannot govern itself, and a government which cannot govern itself cannot govern the nation. The Government urgently needs to reassess its fiscal position. There is increasing evidence for all to see that the Government's overall economic strategy is falling apart. Continued reliance on monetary policy has left this country struggling to sustain investments which will generate real returns, has crippled tens of thousands of home buyers and has put the dream of home ownership out of reach for many others.

The Government should reduce its reliance on monetary policy and tighten up on fiscal policy. Instead of that we find that we are now debating three Appropriation Bills which add up to additional expenditure in excess of $1,000m. The Government comes to Parliament to appropriate those additional funds. Yesterday the Treasurer told the Parliament, and on another occasion the Caucus, that he will look at some spending cuts in the run-up to the August Budget but that it appears the expenditure review that will be undertaken will be essentially a housekeeping exercise rather than one involving major cuts in programs. In his statements yesterday he also ruled out any tightening of wages or monetary policy.

The Treasurer is virtually admitting that he will not take any further action of a significant nature on the fiscal policy front. He has ruled out any tightening of wages or monetary policy and any change in the wage-tax deal with the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU), a deal which has cemented into the Australian economy and inflation rate of the order of at least 7 to 9 per cent, and he has ruled out any real further reduction in the public sector borrowing requirement. Indeed, there is every indication that the public sector borrowing requirement will increase next year.

It is clear that inflation is the No. 1 economic problem facing this nation. It is equally clear that Australia's record in this area is shameful. In 1988 Mr Keating said, accepted, that Australia's No. 1 economic problem was inflation. He did not address the issue then; nothing has changed since. When, back in February of this year, he was asked how important fighting inflation was Mr Keating was reported in the Australian as saying:
What we are about focusing on next year is inflation declining to a year average of about 6 per cent. At the moment, the real rate of inflation is running at about 7.5 per cent.

In other words, he thought that we might get inflation down to 6 per cent next year and seemed to think that that was an acceptable proposition. But even that prediction looks like coming unstuck. The consumer price index (CPI) was running at 8.6 per cent in the 12 months to March of this year. It has been rising, not falling.

Our inflation performance relative to that of our major trading partners is disastrous. Our inflation rate is running at about twice that of our trading partners, and has been virtually throughout the life of this Government. Indeed, on a comparative basis, that is, comparing Australia's inflation rate with that of our major trading partners, we have the worst record for inflation in our history.

The Governor of the Reserve Bank of Australia, Mr Bernie Fraser, recently put the Government on clear notice that inflation had to be tackled as the No. 1 problem. He said that the Government should take policy measures to halve the rate of inflation. He said that we need a circuit-breaker, that we are locked into a high continuing inflation rate which is leading to economic slowdown and economic recession, and therefore we have a stagflation situation in this economy. Mr Bernie Fraser pointed out-quite rightly, because it is so obvious-that we must get our inflation rate down and get some sort of circuit-breaker to break the pattern.

In response to that the Minister for Finance, Mr Willis, said, `If we could get a circuit-breaker that would be good but really there is nothing practical we can do'. At least that was one step up on the Treasurer's response which was, quite simply and bluntly, `We do not need a circuit-breaker because we have not really got a problem with the economy or with inflation in this country'.

If we do not tackle our inflation problem all the other fine words, all the other policies that might be adopted by governments, corporations or households, will go for nought. If we could see some light at the end of the tunnel in terms of the Government's approach to economic management across the board, then the present level of inflation, serious though it is, might be seen in a longer term context of falling inflation.

But that is not the case. Any serious anti-inflationary strategy by any government that is serious about trying to tackle inflation must have an anti-inflationary strategy that is inextricably linked to labour market and micro-economic reforms. Again back in February the Treasurer himself admitted in an article in the Sydney Morning Herald that the wage-tax deal struck with the ACTU, `would mean the inflation rate'-in Australia-`would continue to remain higher than that of its major trading partners for some time to come'.

Yesterday, I repeat, the Treasurer told the Caucus that the wage-tax deal with the ACTU would not be altered. In other words, the Treasurer yesterday said, `Inflation is going to continue high and this Government is not going to do anything about it'.

The Treasurer, though, obviously understands the problem. The problem is this: the accord cannot deliver sustainable wage increases which will allow us to regain our competitiveness or help us to trade our way out of our debt problems. But the Treasurer, having recognised the problem, is unable to deliver a wage system that will encourage and foster productivity because his hands are tied by his union mates. While he is taking that attitude, he is blasting the Leader of the Government in the Senate, the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button, in an incredible vitriolic, public, humiliating outburst, for dragging his heels in economic reform in the areas within the responsibility of his portfolio, namely, tariffs and protection.

On Monday of this week the Treasurer, in the most outspoken attack I can ever recall a senior Minister making on another senior Minister-and he was doing it, I might add, as the Deputy Prime Minister of this country-had the gall to attack the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce whilst giving the impression that everything that he, the Treasurer, has done has been rosy and has really been working towards tackling the significant problems facing this nation.

Nothing could be further from the truth. The Treasurer's record, the economic performance record of this Government, is the worst in our post-war history, particularly when we compare our situation with that of our major trading partners-and that is what we have to do if we are to look at where this country is going economically in the future.

The Treasurer, above all Ministers, is guilty in that regard. He showed in his comments on Monday in the middle of his vitriolic bucketing of Senator Button, who has just joined us, that he did not have a clue about the state of the car industry and it was about the car industry that he was bucketing Senator Button. He showed that he did not have a clue about the waiting lists and waiting times for vehicles in the industry. He had to be publicly corrected by Senator Button yesterday, and I am glad that he was.

The Treasurer has also demonstrated monumental inaction when after the 1987 election in a power duel with the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce he got the then Industries Assistance Commission (IAC)-it is now the Industry Commission-into his claws, because he was going to be the great maestro of micro-economic reform, and he went for months and months without utilising that very powerful resource that he had grabbed in a power struggle from Senator Button-namely, the IAC.

So when it comes to micro-economic reform, senior Ministers are brawling between themselves over the appropriate rate, the scope of reform and indeed who should be undertaking it. We have seen more rhetoric by this Government on the question of economic reform than we have seen in terms of most of its other activities. Rhetoric is the name of the game with this Government.

When one looks at the Government's record of what has been achieved in micro-economic reform since it placed it high on its agenda several years ago, one sees that the actual results have failed totally to match in any shape or form the rhetoric that has been expressed. In the areas of transport, the waterfront, shipping and telecommunications, which desperately need reform and restructuring, the results have been lamentably missing. Quite clearly, the process of micro-economic reform will not be undertaken by this Government.

The final point in the second reading amendment that I will mention briefly concerns the debt facing Australia, a debt which now totals not far short of $150 billion. Seven years ago, when this Government came to office, the figure was of the order of $30 billion. The debt crisis could not be better demonstrated than by the growth in the current account deficit and the net external deficit as a proportion of gross domestic product (GDP) since Labor came to power. In 1982-83, the last year of the previous coalition Government, the current account deficit amounted to 3.9 per cent of GDP. It grew to 5.4 per cent in 1988-89 and has been higher on other occasions.

The Economic Planning Advisory Council-EPAC-stated in its paper on external debt, which was presented last year, that a current account deficit of around 2.5 per cent of GDP was necessary in order simply to stabilise the debt relative to GDP, let alone get it down. The fact that this Government has failed to reach this target is evident in the ratio of net external debt to GDP, which has grown from a mere 13.5 per cent in 1982-83 to an astonishing and disturbing 32.2 per cent in 1988-89. I say `disturbing' very understandably and meaningfully because our debt is clearly running away at an unsustainable level. We now have a situation where at the end of December last year our gross external debt, as I said, stood at $148.1 billion. Until we have a government which is prepared to tackle the underlying problems which are leading to those manifestations of grave problems in the Australian economy and a government which is seized of those problems and prepared to take action, they will continue to multiply; the economy will continue to recess; and the living standards of every Australian-living standards which have been battered year in year out under this Government-will continue to decline.

The Appropriation and Supply Bills that we are debating cognately are only one small part of the total scenario, but they are a significant part because the second reading speech of the Minister for Finance, on introducing the Bills, demonstrated that the Government has no intention, through fiscal policy or any of the other major arms of macro-economic policy, of moving into a higher cog of concern over the economy. It has shown painfully over years now that it has no scope, no ability, no willingness and no skill at tackling the area of micro-economic reform. The lack of purpose on micro-economic reform and the lack of willingness to tackle the macro-economic reform issues are of great concern to this economy and mean that we are in for a very rocky ride ahead. It is inconceivable that the Treasurer cannot even agree with the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce that we have a situation of economic severity. The Treasurer is not even prepared to accept that.

It is about time the Treasurer got out and saw what is happening in the real world. It is about time he saw what is happening to people, households and small and large business alike in this country and moved himself into a higher cog of concern, because this country is going down the drain. It is going down the drain because of the breathtaking complacency of this Government. For that reason the second reading amendment moved by the Opposition to these Appropriation and Supply Bills is significant in highlighting the problems and the malaise that we are suffering and I hope that it will have the support of the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Australia is becoming an economic disaster area. The tragedy is that most Australians do not yet seem to recognise it, and believe that something will turn up-after all, it usually has in the past-and we will get out of the problem without any great exertion or sacrifice. We seem to me to be ominously like Britain was in the years leading up to the Second World War, when only a year before that war broke out Churchill had only three supporters in the House of Commons when he criticised the Munich surrender or, to use a different and much overworked analogy, we are like the first-class passengers on the Titanic enjoying themselves in the ship's entertainment rooms, and with the captain and navigator assuring them that they were on course.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at our situation. We have net overseas debts of $117 billion. Much play is made of the fact that this is not Federal government debt. That is a red herring. It is a debt of the Australian economy and the interest on it has to be paid out of the Australian economy. The fact that there is so much overseas debt is because we have been living recklessly beyond our means, borrowing overseas to maintain our living standards. That is the fault of this Government, although the public has not yet sheeted home the responsibility to it. But it will.

The interest bill on our overseas debt at the moment is about $12 billion a year and this represents 21 per cent of our export earnings-21 per cent and rising. For our overseas debt itself is rising by something like $20 billion a year. We are now the fourth most indebted country in the world, having just overtaken Mexico and the way this Government is handling things we will soon be top of the league.

People often talk scathingly of the American balance of payments deficit. Ours is per head, twice as high as that of the Americans. Our productivity in manufacturing, in shipping and rail transport is about half that of our competitors. Despite all the nonsense talked, particularly by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) during the election campaign, we are not catching up; we are falling further behind. Certainly, we made a few minor improvements, but our competitors have made greater ones.

In my view, Madam Acting Deputy President, the tragedy was that none of the key issues was closely discussed during the election campaign. The election campaign seemed to be a sort of auction as to who was going to be able to get interest rates down the most and the fastest. Discussion on interest rates seemed to be exclusively on their effect on home buyers, ignoring the fact that interest rates dramatically affect business investment and by holding the Australian dollar artificially high, reduce our international competitiveness. We are members of the world economic scene and the world does not owe us a living. We have to earn it.

I thought the whole election campaign was a tragic farce and started stirrings in my mind as to whether Australia is really governable. A country becomes ungovernable if the things informed people know should and must be done are not done because of fear of the reaction of voters or perhaps the obstruction of the bureaucracy. This was the reason for the collapse of the Argentine, once probably the wealthiest country per capita in the world. Informed people in the Argentine knew what should be done but they did not do what was needed because they did not dare to. Like the Argentineans, we have to change and our attitudes have to be tackled and changed as well.

Let us look at some of the issues that I do not think were properly discussed during the election campaign. One could not reasonably argue that the environment was not an election issue, or that it did not have a significant effect on the result. Yet, the debate, and the outcome, was curiously unsatisfactory. The problem seems to be that, for many, the environment has become a sort of religion. Yet, like religions, there are many sects.

First, there are the ex-communists. Many of the greens are re-ducoed reds. They have lost confidence, not surprisingly, in communism but now have a new cause. The one they have chosen might seem surprising because communist regimes, with command economies, have proved disastrous environmental managers-by far the worst in the developed world. Now these re-ducoed reds seem to want us to use the same command economy methods to wreck our environment.

Every religion has its fanatics, and the second green group are those who, to quote John Kerin, would like us to live in caves, eating grass, provided the grass has been killed in a humane manner. I do not think they will have many followers. We must be watchful that they do not influence our environmental policy in foolish ways.

The third, by far the largest group, comprises those who are genuinely and properly concerned about what we are doing to this earth. Our first task must be to clean up our own country-to stop the degradation of farming land, the salination and poisoning of our watercourses, the overclearing, and the pollution of our atmosphere and of our coastline. These will be costly to cure. But there will be economic as well as environmental benefits. To achieve the cure, the coalition will have to reconsider its attitude to Federal-State relations.

The economists have a lot to do too. It is perhaps not their fault that gross domestic product is now used for a purpose for which it was never intended. Yet we do seem to need a measure of economic progress and surely it must take into account the depletion of capital stock and environmental changes. We also need clear indications of the economic costs and benefits of various environmental improvements so that we can make rational decisions after looking at possible alternative uses for those resources.

Our contribution to world pollution problems is more difficult. We are not major polluters and we must beware of destroying our economy by trying to set an example which inevitably would be regarded as a curiosity rather than something to be followed. We must press for cooperative action on atmospheric and maritime pollution and, above all, on population. Humanity is like a colony of rabbits on a small island, breeding too fast and destroying the island. We must press for world action on all the key problem areas and we must maintain the agreed standards. We must not crucify our industry and destroy our international competitiveness by going beyond those standards.

We do desperately need economic development. Our basic problem is that we are consuming more than we are producing. And it is bizarre but consistent with the Treasurer's normal behaviour that he should describe as `beautiful' figures which showed a sharp drop in Australian production.

Our productivity in manufacturing and transport, except road transport, is atrocious. Take two examples: in Japan it takes 15 hours to build a car; in Australia it takes 35 hours. And this does not include the higher quality control in Japan. `Ah', you may say-as I am sure the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) is about to say-`but the Japanese have more robots', a point I will come to in a moment. So let us look at something where Australians and Japanese are using identical equipment. A container crane in an Australian port loads and unloads half as many containers an hour as an identical crane in a Japanese port. The whole Australian community, and our exporter in particular, pays the price.

It is not that Australians cannot be productive. Our primary producers are probably, per capita, the most productive in the world. But in the manufacturing and transport sectors we are bedevilled by what must be just about the worst industrial relations and pay fixing system in the developed world. This, too, was barely discussed in the election campaign. As the campaign went on, we seemed to be more and more saying that our policy was not all that different from the Government's.

Our industrial relations system is an unhappy mixture of three strands. There is the British tradition of multiple unions, often with a craft basis and with a very damaging tradition of `them' and `us', making for constant confrontation. The second strand is one we introduced ourselves, an idea that was popular in the late nineteenth century, a hundred years ago, of a highly legalistic, adversarial and centralised dispute settling and wage fixing system. And, finally, there is the very unfortunate division of responsibility between Federal and State jurisdictions.

The results are awful, seen in our very high level of industrial disputes by world standards and productivity in heavily unionised areas which is about half that of our competitors. Worst of all perhaps is the deplorable wage fixing system, which extorts high wages from businesses able to pay them and then, under the guise of comparative wage justice, inflicts them on businesses unable to pay them, with a consequent loss of jobs-forced on the workers, of course, by the trade union bosses despite the fact the workers might be prepared to forgo the wage rises if it meant retaining their jobs.

One of the more extraordinary statements during the last election campaign was that of the Treasurer, Mr Keating, who argued that the Accord-the deal done between the trade union bureaucracy and the Government, with the theoretically independent industrial commission merely a rubber stamp-was essential for wage restraint. It may be essential under our existing disastrous industrial relations system but many other countries, without any such accord and with economies working much better than ours, have managed to restrain unaffordable wage rises much more successfully than we have.

In my view, Madam Acting Deputy President, what we desperately need in this country is an industrial relations system that has three features. First, there must be a single union in each workplace. Secondly, the workers in each workplace must be sheltered from industrial disputes in other workplaces that do not concern them. Thirdly, the workers in each workplace must have an interest in the success of their enterprise, either through profit sharing or some other mechanism that involves them in the enterprise's success.

Other countries have systems like this, and such a system is vital if we are going to get out of our current economic mess. But the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) and the Government are moving in exactly the wrong direction. They are bemused, for some reason, by the Swedish model and are seeking to amalgamate hundreds of unions into 20 very large ones.

This would not even remotely achieve a desirable objective. We would not have a single union in each workplace. What we would have is two or three very large ones remotely controlled by distant very large bureaucracies with no real interest in the success of a particular enterprise, except in so far as successful wage deals in that enterprise could be used as a means of passing those wage rises across the board in the name of comparative wage justice.

Such a system as this would be a disaster. It is of interest that the Swedish model that the ACTU seems so enamoured of is falling apart. Sweden has now introduced a two-year wage freeze, a two-year price freeze, and the Government would, if it could, have introduced a two-year strike ban. The Swedish system is disintegrating. The only miracle is that it, like the eastern European communist economies, lasted so long.

Madam Acting Deputy President, one of the things the union movement does not seem to understand is the interaction of wages and interest rates. As I have said many times, we are living recklessly beyond our means and it is essential that we restrain consumer spending power until we can raise productivity so that we can afford to spend more. If we grant a nominal wage rise, not justified by increased productivity, the consequence is inflation which destroys the value of the wage rise. If, on the other hand, what is negotiated is a real wage rise, increasing effective spending power, the only weapon the Government has left itself is to raise interest rates to increase the cost of consumption and thus destroy the spending power that has just been granted by the wage mechanism.

I repeat: we are living beyond our means; we must hold down our standard of living until we can improve productivity. And after that, we can only justify wage rises which match improved productivity. Without that, we are stuck with disastrous interest rates forever, with all the damage they do to business investment and, through holding the Australian dollar too high, to our international competitiveness.

Our inflation rate is predicted by the Treasurer to be 8.6 per cent this year, though, as he must be the worst economic forecaster in Australia's public history, we will take that forecast with a grain of salt-it will probably be worse. The important thing is that no-one can see how, under current settings, the inflation rate is going to go down below 6 per cent. The trouble is that we are building inflationary expectations into our system. Our real labour costs are lower and our profit share is higher than it has been for 20 years. The public sector is in balance.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you going to compare it, as you have been doing over the last six years, with the United Kingdom inflation rate, Senator?

—No, I am not going to do that. The United Kingdom is having very similar problems to us. Because of these inflationary expectations, we have a high rate of price increase, a high rate of nominal wage growth and high nominal interest rates. The results are, again, awful.

SPEECH.PARA: The average Australian inflation rate during the 1950s and 1960s was 4 per cent; in the 1970s it was 9.4 per cent; and in the 1980s it was 8.7 per cent. In the 1950s and 1960s we were about in line with the average of the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD). In the 1980s under the Hawke-Keating-Button Government our inflation rate has been about double the OECD average. The damage that high interest rates do is enormous: They make our economy less efficient because they distort effort and investment; they create winners and losers and the winners and losers are not always those who deserve it; they erode the attraction of saving; and they make us less internationally competitive unless we are prepared constantly to devalue our currency.

I think a government-any government-has a responsibility to ensure the stability of our currency. But it is not a thing that should be trusted to politicians. There is always the political incentive that a little bit more inflation will solve the short term employment situation and be damned to the long term economic implications. All political parties have fallen for this. The economies that are working well have taken the responsibility for stability of the currency out of the hands of politicians and given it to an independent reserve bank such as the Bundesbank. People pressing for inflationary price or wage rises would know that, if they were achieved, the immediate reaction of the Reserve Bank of Australia would be to raise interest rates to destroy the value of the inflationary wage and price rises and that would act as a very strong disincentive, and the only practical disincentive, for such rises being sought.
An independent reserve bank, committed to the stability of the currency, works in other countries. Our system, obviously, does not work. Why do we not try something better?

Two taxation matters which were not discussed seriously in the election were, firstly, the capital gains tax and, secondly, the desirability of a consumption tax. I believe the capital gains tax is not primarily for revenue gathering; rather, it is a means of achieving equity between taxpayers and also avoiding distortion of investment. Capital gains are often almost indistinguishable income and it is very irritating for honest taxpayers-income taxpayers-to see capital gainers getting away with it. When people think the tax system is manifestly unfair, tax avoidance becomes an industry.

I must confess that I was not happy with the speculative gains tax proposed by the Opposition during the election. It did not seem to me to deal adequately with the question of tax equity. Neither am I impressed with the Australian Labor Party's alternative because it creates very severe investment distortions. If we exclude the family home from the capital gains tax, as is done at present, it means that there is a very strong incentive to invest in that area at the expense of more creative investments. As a consequence, we have far too much of our capital stock invested in housing, at inflated prices.

It is not coincidental that people in Australia, which has vast areas of land but no capital gains tax on homes, pay twice as much for a comparable block of residential land as people do in space-cramped England. We must bring the family home into the capital gains tax system. This, though, is one of the areas which people regard, rightly, as a political minefield. Although it needs to be done, it will never be done unless both major parties agree it is essential. Even then, of course, there will be the chance of a populist party-the Australian Democrats have always shown themselves prepared to be populist-jumping on the band wagon against it. But I think the Democrats can always be relied upon to self-destruct in other ways.

The other tax area which was not mentioned in the election campaign, though it has come to the fore since, was the subject of consumption tax. To my mind, the whole debate has been an absurdity, capped off by a piece of monumental farce by the Treasurer last week. What we should be looking at is the balance of our tax collections between direct and indirect taxes and whether such a balance is the right one for our economy. Of course a consumption tax is regressive; it is almost more difficult to avoid than income tax. By international standards, we have a very high proportion of direct taxes which may be damaging our creativity and productivity.

It seems absurd, though, that we are talking about introducing a consumption tax when we raise $24 billion a year from indirect taxation, $18 billion of which is from consumption taxes. What we should be looking at is not whether or not we have a consumption tax-we already have several-but whether our present system of taxing consumption is the most efficient. Our present system of wholesale tax is an absurdity, based as it is on differential rates of 10 per cent, 20 per cent, 30 per cent and now 50 per cent on different products.

What we should surely be looking at, without getting into the question of a balance between direct and indirect taxes, which is a different issue, is whether we should bring services into our consumption tax pool, why we do not have a single level of consumption tax so that the Government stops playing favourites and how to produce the most efficient and equitable tax collection. That is what we should be looking at. We should ignore the silly rantings of the Treasurer.

Of course, one of the problems we have, as I mentioned earlier, is that the Democrats may seek populist openings if the major parties start tackling some of these problems. They certainly have never been loath to espouse populist causes. In fact, their economic philosophy, as far as it can be determined, is identical with that of the late General Peron of the Argentine. I hope the Democrats will have noticed that this economic philosophy has brought the Argentine from being the richest nation in the world to being an economic basket case.

It is true that General Peron always managed to work in a reference to the poor, whom he described as the `shirtless ones'. But, as the previous Democrat leader, ex-Senator Janine Haines, lost her shirt in the last election, perhaps the Democrats can now claim even that similarity to pure Peronism.

We have real problems with our productivity in the heavily unionised areas which is why it is so important that we reform our industrial relations structure. A recent study of the Kodak (Australasia) Pty Ltd paper finishing plant found that at the time of study Australia was the least productive plant when compared with other plants in Canada, Britain and Brazil. The unit cost in Brazil was 30 per cent and in Britain 70 per cent of Australia's. The study listed the reasons for the low productivity in Australia as being low operating time, high unproductive paid time, union demarcations and poor work and management practices. I think one could say that this Kodak study was typical of much of Australia's manufacturing industry. We have had zero productivity growth in manufacturing industry in the last three years and have been below the OECD average since 1979. It must be remembered that we are improving from a base roughly half that of our competitors.

We must get more investment and people are not going to invest unless they think their investment is going to be productive. We have a long way to go. To get back to my example of the car industry, where the Japanese productivity is double ours, about 25 to 35 per cent of production in overseas car plants is done by robots while in Australia it is 12 per cent or less. Why would someone invest hundreds of millions of dollars in robots in Australian factories when they are going to be used for only 36 hours a week? Only one car plant in Australia works more than a single shift. Surely, if some one is going to invest that amount of money for robots he would invest in a country where they would be used for 168 hours a week-in Taiwan or Korea, or Japan for that matter.

We have a long way to go if we are going to attract investment. Improved industrial relations and attitudes are a vital first step. Our political stability is to be admired but our transport and ports are additional worries for investors. Also, we cause great worries with our environmental campaign. We must create a climate where people spending millions working out a feasible industrial plan for investment in Australia are confident that the environmental rules will not be changed late in the game. It seems, it has been claimed, that we have lost $12,000m in investment because of our environmental uncertainty-Kakadu and Wesley Vale are examples-and these investments could have earned us $3 billion a year. Certainly we must have tough environmental standards but they must be fair and consistent and not manipulated for short term political purposes, as is the habit of this Government.

I do not have time to discuss privatisation but everyone with experience in public administration knows that governments run businesses extremely inefficiently, have severe capital problems and are constantly pushed around by the demands of militant unions which know that businesses cannot go broke no matter how much they lose. We must get the Government out of as many businesses as poss- ible as quickly as we can. Just ponder one fact: during the recent air strike the passenger trains between Sydney and Melbourne were only half full. The reason was undoubtedly the cost. Railways do not pay for their track and do not pay any taxes and should be the most economical way of moving people between major centres. Yet to take a comfortable bus from Canberra to Melbourne costs $45. It costs twice as much to travel by train. The bus company has to run at a profit; the railways make substantial losses, which conjures up mind boggling thoughts of the amount of featherbedding and sheer idleness in the government run railways.

Mr Keating, like most partly educated amateurs in a technical field, is constantly clutching at gimmicks. Remember the J-curve, which was going to solve our balance of payments difficulties? We do not hear much of that now. Then there was deterioration of our terms of trade, which was causing all our problems. In the last couple of years the terms of trade have improved sharply, but we do not hear anything about that now, though on the previous reasoning of Mr Keating that should have reversed the problems of five or so years ago.

Now he has another gimmick: the balance of payments deficit is represented by investment in plant and equipment which is going to earn us export income in the near future. Quite apart from the fact that, as usual, he has got his statistics wrong and quite a lot of the investment is going to non-export producing buildings and so on, there is no way the amount going to plant and equipment will even remotely pay the interest bill on the monthly balance of payments deficit.

It must be admitted that Mr Keating was extremely bold in deregulating the finance markets, floating our dollar and so on, but he failed to deregulate a key area of our economy-the labour market. I think a good case can be made that if one is not prepared to deregulate the labour market, the other reforms are probably, on balance, harmful and it would have been better if they had not been made. I am not against deregulation. But it must be complete deregulation; it must not leave out a key part.

I have painted a gloomy picture because I am gloomy about our short term economic future under this disintegrating and, to use Senator Walsh's words, spineless Government. We must not lose sight of the fact that, as a country, Australia has enormous assets. We are the only country with a continent to ourselves. We have tremendous natural assets, we have no significant external threat, we have a homogenous and a reasonably well educated population, and we have a generally non-corrupt legal and public service system, which is extremely rare around the world. These are immense assets, but to make full use of them we must face up to our problems and solve them. I have listed the ones that occur to me and, if we can deal with all or most of them, we will again deserve to be called `the lucky country'. But it will not be done by luck; it will be done by courage and effort.
Debate (on motion by Senator Button) adjourned.

SALES TAX LAWS AMENDMENT BILL 1990

This Bill, and nine others I will introduce shortly, will amend the sales tax law to give effect to the announcement in the February 1990 Economic Statement of an increase in the rate of sales tax payable on ``luxury'' motor cars and station wagons (including four-wheel drive vehicles).
Where the wholesale price for sales tax purposes of such vehicles exceeds $28,793, sales tax will be levied at the new rate of 50%.
The amount of $28,793 is the tax-exclusive wholesale price, on which sales tax is calculated, equivalent to a $42,910 retail price.
This latter amount is the present upper cost limit on which depreciation is allowable on motor cars and station wagons for income tax purposes.
The wholesale price above which cars are taxed as ``luxury'' vehicles will alter each 1 July in line with the indexation adjustment to the income tax depreciation limit.
The increase to 50% in the rate of sales tax on ``luxury'' vehicles will produce a net revenue gain of $105 million in a full year.

The Bill will also ensure that motor vehicles specially fitted out for transporting disabled persons while seated in wheelchairs are only subject to tax at the general rate of 20%, not the higher 30% and 50% rates.
The cost to revenue of this amendment will be less than $3 million in a full year.
I present the Explanatory Memorandum which contains more detailed explanation of the provisions of the Bill.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
SALES TAX (NOS. 1-9) AMENDMENT BILLS 1990
These Bills declare a new sales tax rate of 50% for goods covered by the Sixth Schedule to the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act.
That Schedule is being added by another Bill in this package to which I referred earlier-the Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill.
The goods covered by the Schedule are motor cars and station wagons (including four-wheel drive vehicles) with a wholesale price for sales tax purposes above $28,793.
A more detailed explanation of the provisions of these Bills is also contained in the Explanatory Memorandum that accompanies this package of Bills.
I commend the Bills to the Senate.
GREAT BARRIER REEF MARINE PARK AMENDMENT BILL
Both Labor and coalition governments have in the past supported the protection and wise use of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park and I hope that this bipartisan support will continue.

It has been 15 years since the passage of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act and the creation of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority. Over that time practical experience gained from managing the marine park has highlighted areas where the operation of the Act could be improved.

The purpose of this Bill is to improve the operation of the Act by defining certain terms used in the statutory marine park zoning plans. This will overcome a problem highlighted in a recent case. It was found that the terms used until now permitted commercial operations even though the intention had been that they should be controlled. The Government is committed to ensuring that the short term commercial interests of some individuals do not harm this precious resource to the detriment of all Australians.

Zoning plans are used to manage the resources of the marine park. By regulating the type of activities permitted within the park the reef is protected from undesirable exploitation but remains accessible to the public for their enjoyment and appreciation.
Because the uncertainties raised by the recent case are common to all of the existing zoning plans it is important to incorporate clear definitions of the terms into the Act.

The Bill also ensures that where there is some doubt whether an activity requires permission under a zoning plan, there is a presumption that permission is required. There is no intention to change the operation of zoning plans which have themselves been passed by the Parliament. Indeed the purpose of the Bill is to clarify the original intention of the Parliament that the Great Barrier Reef is to be managed for all Australians and that in the interests of conservation and wise use, some activities must be regulated or even forbidden.
In conclusion the Bill represents the Government's resolve to improve the management and protection of one of the world's greatest natural assets, the Great Barrier Reef.
I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. Firstly, is it a fact that the Treasurer gained ministerial responsibility for the Industries Assistance Commission (IAC) shortly after the 1987 election? Secondly, is it a fact that it was not until the end of June 1988, about 10 months later, that the first terms of reference for an inquiry by the IAC were actually delivered to the IAC by the Treasurer? Thirdly, is it a fact that in the last year for which the Minister had responsibility for the IAC that body completed 11 references? Fourthly, is it a fact that last year under the stewardship of Mr Keating the IAC was able to complete only four references and during that period the actual number of references to the IAC was cut by half? Finally, are the Minister and the Government entirely satisfied with the number of references which have been given to and completed by the IAC or the Industry Commission in matters relating to Minister Button's portfolio since the IAC was transferred from the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce to the Treasury?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are a number of questions there. In answer to the first part of the question, which asks whether it is a fact that the IAC, as it then was, was transferred from my responsibility to the Treasurer's in 1987, yes that is a fact. I heard a speaker in the Senate today saying that there was a great power struggle between me and the Treasurer as to who should have the IAC in 1987. That is totally untrue.
—Why didn't you correct him at the time?

—Because the Government had at that time decided that the IAC should be used on a number of more economy-wide references than its traditional role of merely looking at industry assistance and industry specific assistance. That was the rationale behind that. There was no fundamental disagreement about that happening at all. In answer to the question as to when the Treasurer resumed responsibility for the IAC--
—Ten months.

—The interjection is that it took 10 months for the first reference to go. I must say I did answer a question similar to that just asked on 23 May 1988. Senator Lewis asked me a question then on this issue. On that occasion he asked me about an inquiry into non-tax government charges and so on. There was a period of delay at that time. That was because the Government was considering the nature of economy-wide references and there was, as Senator Lewis pointed out today, some delay at that time. I think there were reasons for it. If Senator Lewis looks at my answer of 23 May he may find that it encompasses those reasons.

ANSWER.PARA: It is true that in the last year when I was portfolio Minister for the IAC, 11 references were dealt with by that body but they were industry-specific references. Throughout the period in which the IAC was under my administration it had a lot of references and it dealt with them.

I would further make the point, in case it has been overlooked by anybody in the current debate, that this Government, from the time it came to office until 1987 when there was a proposed change of role for the IAC, adopted the recommendations of every report that we received from the IAC on industry-specific matters, except for two. I refer first to the chemical and plastics industry, where we took a harder line on tariff reduction than the IAC had recommended; that was done on my recommendations to the Government. The other exception was the textile, clothing and footwear industry, where the IAC gave us three options to consider. Sadly, in the course of discussing the future of that industry those three options became the focal points of debate; but we did not adopt the IAC's preferred option in respect of the textile, clothing and footwear industry. I am not sure whether it is true to say, as was said in the fourth part of the question, that last year there were only four references completed by the IAC. But I am pretty sure of one thing: they would be much larger references than the industry-specific references which used to be sent to the IAC in the old days.

The question asked whether the Minister and the Government were satisfied with the number of references currently being dealt with by the IAC. My answer to that question is absolutely yes. The IAC has a two-year forward work program, which was announced in the last Budget. It includes a number of very important economy-wide issues, such as export franchising and distribution arrangements; the mining and minerals processing industry; the commercial tariff concession system; energy generation and distribution; railways and so on. I table the list of current references to the IAC, which is a very comprehensive work program.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. I refer the Minister to plans he announced on 11 February this year, as the former Minister, to seek public comment on the membership and objectives of a national working group on coastal management. Will the Minister indicate what response, in the form of submissions, he has received to date and whether the working group on coastal management has now been formed?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —There cannot be many more important environmental issues in Australia than that of coastal management. Clearly as a nation we have not managed our coastal waters all that well, especially in the last few decades where we have seen increased pressure on our fishing grounds, and where pollution both from industrial sources and sewage is causing so many problems. That is why the Government took the decision to try to get some coordination into coastal zone management. Obviously, with six States having primary jurisdiction over our coastlines, there have been too many different rules and it has been very difficult for industry, be it tourism or those who discharge effluent, to know what the future holds.

ANSWER.PARA: We have tried a cooperative approach by attempting to get a working group to look at these issues. On 14 February this year we advertised in the national press and in coastal regional newspapers seeking public comment on the task, on the mode of operation and, indeed, membership of the working group itself. I am informed that the public response has been pretty substantial. State governments have responded directly, as has local government, some industry leaders and individuals, as well as environmental groups.

The Department is currently analysing those responses, and the responses include suggestions as to who should actually be on the group. Given the fact that the working group is supposed to have completed its task by July 1991, I would think that in the next month or two the Minister will make the final announcement on its mode of operation and membership. I hope that we can all make sure that the report is completed on time because there is a sense of urgency about getting some rational solutions to the problems of coastal management in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. Is it correct that the motor vehicle industry currently has an effective rate of protection of 104 per cent and that by the end of the current plan in 1992 it will still be 86 per cent? Is it correct that the current levels of protection amount to $4,000 per vehicle for the average consumer?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —First of all let me say that there is considerable debate about the calculations of effective rates of assistance. There is disagreement among various bodies in relation to effective rates of assistance. However, those rates are high for the motor vehicle industry, there is no doubt about that. In terms of the second part of the question, which relates more to the cost to the consumer, the effective rates of assistance are not a measure which is in any sense useful in determining that cost to the consumer. Effective rates of assistance are essentially used to determine the relative allocation of resources between various industries. For example, in the Opposition's period in government, when tariff rates generally were very high, effective rates of assistance were much more important in determining the distribution of resources between industries than they are now.

ANSWER.PARA: The effective rates of assistance in the motor vehicle industry probably arise basically from differential component costs with other countries and also as a result of the export facilitation program, which is part of the motor vehicle plan and which helps to raise those effective rates of assistance. Those matters will be examined in the course of the Industry Commission's inquiry which is about to take place.

As to the second part of the question, those figures are bandied about a lot. I would not be able to comment on their accuracy. Essentially the consumer is concerned about the price of cars, and the price of cars manufactured in Australia varies of course from one model to another. One assessment has been done by the Automotive Industry Authority in relation to the Toyota Camry which shows that the price of that car is only marginally different from its price in the United States of America, for example. Some of the figures used in determining this issue of what any industry costs this country are a little out of date.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. I understood the Minister to concede that the figures for effective rates of assistance are high, and I accept that there may well be controversy about them. But the fact remains that assertions have been made as to specific levels and I ask the Minister whether he is seriously suggesting that he does not have a view as to the accuracy of those figures or that he does not have a preferred view of any other specific figure. As far as the $4,000 per vehicle is concerned, did I understand the Minister to say that he had no idea when he said that he really could not comment on the accuracy of that figure? If he cannot comment it would seem that his Department is not in any position to counter the figures which have been very clearly put on the table by the Treasurer.
—What I really said was that I do not know how meaningful those figures are in terms of the cost of motor vehicles to consumers and so on.
—But do you quarrel with them?
—I said there were a number of ways of assessing effective rates of assistance and I conceded that they are high.
—Do you argue with those figures or not?

—No. The point I am simply trying to make is that, having conceded that the effective rates of assistance for the motor vehicle industry are high, I query the importance of that statement in terms of assessing the motor vehicle industry in relation to other industries.
—But are those figures right or not, in your view?
—I am not going to carry on a continuing babble of conversation.
—I would like an answer.
—I gave Senator Alston an answer to the first part of the question. I am not going to add to it.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Has the Minister received a report from Comcare concerning its first full year of operation? Can the Minister advise honourable senators whether any changes in the level of premiums can be reported as a result of Comcare's performance during this period?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I have received a report from Comcare on its first year of performance. I can report that Comcare premiums for 1990-91 are now expected to fall by 25 per cent. The premiums paid for the 194 government agencies covered by Comcare will fall in money terms from $215m in 1989-90 to an expected $174m in 1990-91. This represents a significant reduction of 19 per cent in nominal terms or 25 per cent in real terms for average premium rates. Premiums paid by agencies can be expected to fall from 2.6c to 2c for each wage or salary dollar. It will make Comcare premiums the lowest in Australia for a scheme as comprehensive as this. Although the Queensland scheme, it should be pointed out, is lower, it is certainly by no means as comprehensive as Comcare is.

ANSWER.PARA: This significant reduction illustrates the effectiveness of Comcare, especially when it is considered that the current scheme, which began only in December 1988, was not expected to break even for its first five years of operation because of the high benefit levels. The primary reason for the reduction is Comcare's success in reducing the incidence and duration of workplace injuries. That has meant that Comcare has developed an integrated approach to rehabilitation. Case managers are located in workplaces where they are able to liaise with management, unions and employees. That has enabled a more personalised care program and a better implementation of the procedures instigated by Comcare. This is a laudable outcome and one that establishes the efficacy of the Government's actions in making the reforms to Comcare that it did last year.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Social Security and I refer to the Minister's answer to a question I asked on 9 May about suspension of unemployment benefit in which he admitted:

QUESTION.PARA: There is also the problem of how one equates the employment prospects of individuals with the employment prospects generally in an area. That is where quite a number of mistakes have been made.
The Minister went on to say:

That has resulted in some discussions between my Department and the Commonwealth Employment Service . . . whose job it is to make those assessments, and we will ensure that those problems do not occur in the future.

I ask the Minister: Firstly, does the Commonwealth Employment Service (CES) have information available to it which enables its officers to adequately determine the employment prospects of an individual in any particular place of residence? Secondly, can the Minister assure the Senate that the Department of Social Security accepts the responsibility of showing that an individual's employment prospects have been reduced and that the onus is not upon the recipient to prove that this is not the case.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —In answer to part 1 of Senator Powell's question, obviously I am not the Minister responsible for the Commonwealth Employment Service. Nonetheless, we have to work very closely with it. I am satisfied that the Commonwealth Employment Service collects adequate data on the prospects of employment in any individual profession or trade as well as taking an overall view of each region. I do not think there would be any way to improve those statistics. They are very regularly updated and I think the CES is pretty thorough.

ANSWER.PARA: The problem I referred to the other day occurred because the CES was not taking the extra step of looking at the individual's employment prospects; it was simply relying on the regional profile of an area. QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: UNITED STATES NAVAL AND AIR BASES

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister for Defence read the report in today's Sydney Daily Telegraph that the United States (US) Government may be seriously considering the establishment of major United States naval and air bases in Australia to replace bases that may be closed in the Philippines? Would the Minister welcome discussions with the US authorities on this matter; or does he consider the proposals to be misinformation designed to place pressure upon the Aquino Government during the negotiations on the Philippine bases that begin this week? Will the Minister undertake to remind US authorities of Australia's policies on foreign military bases on Australian soil in order to avoid any further embarrassing reflections on Australia's sovereignty.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I did read the article in this morning's Daily Telegraph. The Government has not been asked about relocating any US facilities from the Philippines to Australia. A Pentagon spokesman confirmed on 15 May that the US has not begun negotiations or discussions with any of its allies about possible relocation. Indeed, the Rand Corporation report referred to in media reports is one of several reports which canvass various possible options that might be considered by the United States if the negotiations with the Government of the Philippines on continued access after 1991 are unsuccessful. The Rand report was completed without reference to US Government policy, and has not been endorsed in any way by the US Government.

ANSWER.PARA: The position of the US Government is that it wishes to continue to use the facilities at Clark and Subic for as long as the Philippines is agreeable and under terms acceptable to both sides. Exploratory talks on continued US access after the present military bases agreement expires in September 1991 began in Manila on 14 May. The Australian Government has made clear the importance it attaches to the United States remaining actively engaged in the Asia-Pacific region. For this reason the Government has expressed support for the retention of the United States bases in the Philippines while recognising that the negotiations are a bilateral matter between the United States and Philippines governments.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for his reply, which was not prepared in response to my question, and I draw his attention again to parts two and three of my question in relation to whether the Minister would welcome discussions with US authorities on this matter, or does he consider the proposals to be misinformation designed to place pressure on the Aquino Government? Further to the last part of my question, will he undertake to remind the US authorities of Australia's policies on foreign military bases on Australian soil?
—Could you repeat the last part of the question?

—Will the Minister undertake to remind United States authorities of Australia's policies on foreign military bases on Australian soil in order to avoid any further embarrassing reflections on Australia's sovereignty?

—I think the gist of the supplementary question was: Is the Rand Corporation putting out publicity that places pressure on the Philippines Government? I cannot really get into the mind of the Rand Corporation. I have absolutely no idea what the motive for that is other than what it normally does, and that is produce think-tank options. On the final point, I think the honourable senator can leave it in the hands of this Government to organise its relations with the US on the most cordial basis.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Does the Minister recall my warning about the crisis in the wool market and its detrimental impact on Australia's balance of payments in a question to him as long ago as last August, when I told him that purchases at auction by the Australian Wool Corporation had risen from 5.1 per cent to 46 per cent of wool offered? In the light of the continuing crisis in the wool market, does the Minister agree that he was wrong to ignore my warnings and that, by giving the wool industry unjustified confidence in the market at that time, he has contributed to a delay in corrective action being taken, just as the Treasurer says he has delayed change in his own portfolio?

—In my political career I have always wanted to have more confidence that the wool industry and everyone outside here is desperately listening to Question Time in the Senate, Senator Chapman's warnings and my answers. I recall no publicity about the honourable senator's question or my answer at that time, so perhaps they did not benefit from his warning or my answer. This question is, if I might say so, appropriately addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy.
—You gave the misleading answer before.

—I am just making the point that, on this occasion, perhaps it should be directed to that Minister. —No, I am saying that you made a mistake.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: HENGYANG DARWIN PTY LTD: AWARD BREACHES

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. I refer to negotiations between the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU), the Department of Industrial Relations and Hengyang Darwin Pty Ltd. These negotiations were in regard to award breaches committed by Hengyang by not observing proper payments and conditions of work carried out in the Darwin trade development zone by foreign employees. Can the Minister inform the Senate about the progress of these negotiations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, my Department with the Clothing and Allied Trades Union of Australia, I think representing the ACTU, met Hengyang in Darwin at 7.30 a.m. Darwin time today. Hengyang is a Hong Kong company set up in the Darwin Trade Development Zone and appears there in the guise of Hengyang Holdings and Hengyang Darwin. There is another company, Darwin International Textiles Pty Ltd. Between the three of them they employee 92 foreign workers recruited from the People's Republic of China. The two Hengyang companies are in the business of manufacturing jeans for the United States market and, in the case of Darwin International, producing knitwear for Europe.

ANSWER.PARA: Honourable senators will recall that the Business Review Weekly last Friday printed an expose of the scandal of the Trade Development Zone in Darwin revealing allegations of award breaches, breaches of contract, underpayments, bad working conditions, the breakdown in the normal courtesies that we would expect in the work force, human rights breaches, and inhumane living conditions. On Friday I indicated, along with other Government Ministers, that I shared the concerns that have been brought to attention by that article and condemn the Northern Territory Government for not exercising its monitoring responsibilities to see whether the undertakings that were given were carried out properly. However, today I can report that a substantial claim will be lodged against Hengyang Holdings for underpayment of wages-the actual quantum of money is being more properly compiled at the moment-and that through the Department of Industrial Relations we are investigating what the underpayment may be for Darwin International, which employs some 22 foreign workers in its own right.

This morning Hengyang Darwin acknowledged its liability to pay $574,000 as underpayment of wages for 27 foreign workers from December 1988 to February 1990. The final decimal points are to be settled. I am pleased that the company has admitted its liability. I hope that with speed and expedition we will be able to clear up the problems that might be associated with Hengyang Holdings and any liability that arises from our investigations of Darwin International. Hengyang Darwin wishes to repay those workers over a 12-month period at a rate of one-third now, one-third soon, and one-third at the end of the 12-month period. The negotiations are stalled at that point. We are seeking immediate repayment.

The trade development zone concept is a good concept in our view, but it is a pity that it has been brought into disrepute by the Northern Territory Government not properly honouring its obligations to see that what occurs within the Trade Development Zone is proper, that companies working there honour their agreements, and that there is not the sense of scandal that associates itself with these companies. If the concept is to succeed this sort of thing has to be cleared up quickly; otherwise a cowboy image will linger.

I have just been handed a press release from Hengyang Darwin which I think is quite extraordinary. It explains the admission of underpayment but makes the point, inter alia, that it was not aware that, being in Australia, they needed to pay Australian rates of pay; they thought they could pay Chinese rates of pay. Now that has been drawn to their attention they say they will clear it up. I think that is a extraordinary admission.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Justice. Is the Government satisfied with the role played by public officials in the failed Operation Seville, that is, the growing of a multi-million dollar marijuana crop under sanction? Now that some 12 months have passed, why has the Government not prosecuted those police and public officials who sanctioned the illegal crop? Why has the Government not launched an independent inquiry into such public abuses which have facilitated and supported organised crime?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think honourable senators will be aware that at this very moment a coronial inquiry is being conducted into the murder of Assistant Commissioner Colin Winchester. I understand that that particular coronial inquiry is moving to discuss the Seville operation and the various marijuana plantations in its next phase of hearings, which I believe are due to commence in the middle of June. That particular inquiry is being undertaken according to the rules that regulate coronial inquests and ought to be allowed to take its course.

ANSWER.PARA: As Senator Hill will know, if certain evidence is produced, the coroner can commit any persons to trial as a result of matters which come before him in the inquiry into the circumstances surrounding the killing of Mr Winchester. At the moment a coronial inquest is being held, admittedly into the circumstances surrounding the death of Colin Winchester, but the coroner has indicated his intention to hear matters relating to the Seville operation in so far as that might cast light on the circumstances of the killing and perhaps point to the person or persons who were responsible for that killing.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I have a supplementary question. As the Minister is aware from evidence received yesterday, that coronial inquiry is not likely to be completed before the end of this year, which is a long period after Operation Seville. As that is an inquiry into the death of Winchester and not an independent inquiry launched into public officials' involvement in a failed multi-million dollar marijuana crop, is it therefore not the proper body to be conducting such an inquiry? Should it not, rather, be conducted by an inquiry specifically set up for that purpose?

—The Government does not believe that anything has come forward which would lead to a decision to institute an inquiry of the kind I take Senator Hill to be referring to, a body vested with the powers of a royal commission, into the circumstances surrounding those particular plantations. I believe that we should await what may be revealed in the coronial inquiry during the course of the next several months before any decision is taken in relation to the necessity for a further inquiry with quite different rules of evidence and different objectives. A royal commission, as honourable senators know, is not required to have in its mind, for example as the National Crime Authority (NCA) does, that its job is to assemble admissible evidence. There has to be a very careful balance between the interests of the community in unravelling these matters and the proper rules of evidence and objectives of the three types of inquiry which can be held into this matter, namely, the coronial inquiry, the NCA type of inquiry or the royal commission type of inquiry.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Industrial Relations and concerns International Labour Organisation (ILO) convention No. 156 on workers with family responsibilities. Has this convention come into force yet in Australia? If so, can the Minister advise the Senate of its implications for Australian employees and of what measures the Government intends taking to advance the interests of workers with family responsibilities as a consequence of ratifying ILO convention 156?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Australia has decided to adopt and implement convention 156, but it does not actually come into force until 30 March 1991. The Commonwealth Government is, as well, in consultation with State and Territory governments and from 1991 on will be obliged to report regularly to the ILO on Australia's implementation of the convention.

ANSWER.PARA: On 2 March the Prime Minister, in announcing the Government's fourth term agenda for women, said that a work and family unit would be established in the Department of Industrial Relations. The aim of the unit will be to improve attitudes and practices in the workplace and to work with employers, employees and unions to integrate the needs of workers with family responsibilities in the award restructuring process; to consult and liaise with relevant State, Territory and Commonwealth bodies; and to ensure that Australian promotional commitments under the convention continue to be met. He also announced on 2 March a community education program to be coordinated by the Office of the Status of Women to educate workers, unions and employers about their respective rights and responsibilities in relation to the convention.
