Convention No. 156 recognises the need for a more equitable sharing of family responsibilities and the provision of support services and appropriate working conditions for workers with those responsibilities. It recognises as well that women should be able to participate in employment on an equal basis with men. The convention is designed to facilitate the combining of work and family responsibilities. Ratifying countries are obliged to take account of the needs of workers with those responsibilities in relation to their terms and conditions of employment, vocational guidance and training, community planning and services and social security. The convention can be implemented in stages.

There are a number of steps that this Government-through the departments of Social Security, Employment, Education and Training, Industrial Relations and a number of other departments-has already taken to comprehensively implement the terms of this convention.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce advise the Senate whether the high technological project known as the Cape York Space Agency (CYSA) is being abandoned because of, firstly, the perception of potential overseas participants of Australia's precarious economic situation and, secondly, the level of barriers to development?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Cape York Space Agency was one of two consortiums that proposed the building of a space base in north Queensland. As the honourable senator would know, two sets of feasibility studies were done. The Government has said that provided it is satisfied that the projects are economically viable and environmentally not detrimental to the Cape York Peninsula, those proposals could go ahead.

ANSWER.PARA: The obstructions to the proposals going ahead at the present time are, I think, twofold. There is, first of all, a land use study commissioned by the Queensland Government in conjunction with, I think, the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories-certainly, there was liaison between the two governments about that land use study-which will examine the environmental issues. However, the other obstruction is not anything to do with the Australian economy, as I understand it.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a perception.

—No, it is very much to do with the United States Congress and whether the United States Congress will permit the use of US satellites which are launched by Soviet rockets. The CYSA wants to launch any rockets from that possible space base site using Soviet rockets. That is the most economical way to do it.

ANSWER.PARA: There is concern in America which is motivated I think by rather historic reasons and also motivated partly by commercial reasons from United States companies that have interests in providing rocket launching facilities to the world. There are those two pressures against the Cape York space proposal being allowed to proceed. They are the two issues which are obstructing the development of the space port at Cape York at present.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. Is the Government aware of plans by Telecom Australia to recycle old telephone books into environmentally friendly insulation material? Can the Minister advise whether other paper items such as newspapers, cardboard boxes, paper bags, used paper from the Public Service and other outlets, magazines and old school books could also be considered for recycling? If they could, will the Minister advise whether the Government has plans to collect other materials for recycling?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Jones was kind enough to give me notice of this question. I might be good at recycling a few good things but I am not good at recycling phone books. I needed the notice. It is true that Telecom has recently signed a contract for a two-year trial period with Cellulose Industries Pty Ltd, a Melbourne based company, to recycle old telephone books into building insulation. The conversion process, which was developed by the company, involves shredding old books and then treating the shredded material with a fire retardant. This product is environmentally friendly and poses less of a health risk to installers and handlers of asbestos or fibreglass. The honourable senator asks about items other than phone books. By the time this industry really gets going I would hope that we would not have phone books in Australia but that we would follow the example of the French and have computer terminals which replace phone books.

ANSWER.PARA: The second part of the question relates to waste paper and magazines for use in cellulose insulating material. Again, that industry supplies about 10 to 15 per cent of the Australian insulation market and uses a fraction, roughly 930,000 tonnes, of waste paper which is recycled by Australian industry today. That industry is developing.

Finally, the honourable senator asked me to advise whether the Government had any plans to collect other materials for recycling. A considerable quantity of waste paper and cardboard is already being collected from public service establishments for recycling. That contribution by the Government is only part of an Australia-wide trend towards recycling. Industry is accepting the challenge and using waste materials for recycling. I had a meeting with the plastics industry yesterday, which is concerned to develop recycling in that industry. I am sure that it is true of other materials such as glass, metals, textiles and oils which in the past have been discarded and not used.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. In view of the fiasco in the wool industry, with the Australian Wool Corporation being forced to buy 90 per cent of offerings this week, will the Minister indicate whether Mr Kerin has had discussions with the Corporation regarding the option of cancelling further sales until the new reserve price is set-indeed, if there is to be a new one? If he has not does he intend to, for there are another 800,000 bales for sale by the end of June?

—The question asks me whether Mr Kerin has done something. I certainly have not, because this matter is not really in my province. I only represent the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy here, but I do not act for him outside this chamber. I do not know what discussions he has had with the relevant authorities on this matter, but I can inquire of him and obtain an answer as soon as possible. Let me say that whether or not the reserve price comes down, now that the Opposition parties have apparently decided to support the Government legislation, I believe that the pressure on the reserve price will be that it will have to fall.
—That is what you wanted, wasn't it?

—That is what you have agreed to, is it not? That will mean that when we as a government are seeking restraint throughout the community, some elements of that restraint will apply to wool growers as well.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Land Transport. First, is the Minister aware of the considerable discussion and debate currently taking place in South Australia regarding the requirement by the Federal Government for all States to move to a blood alcohol limit for drivers of 0.05 if the States wish to receive additional Commonwealth funding for road maintenance? Secondly, in light of the fact that there was a significant fall in alcohol-related accidents in New South Wales and Queensland in the early 1980s when those States moved to a 0.05 limit, resulting in lives and millions of dollars saved in accident costs and property damage, does the Minister support the lowering of the limit throughout Australia to 0.05? Finally, will the Minister guarantee that he will require a reduction in the blood alcohol limit to 0.05 in South Australia before grants to upgrade roads are made?
—Hear, hear!

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to hear that supportive interjection from the other side of the House. The answer to Senator Lees's question is yes, I do support the lowering of the blood alcohol limit to 0.05, as of course does the responsible Minister, Mr Brown. I would like to correct one misapprehension that has been bruited about, that the acceptance or rejection of the 10-point package will affect the Commonwealth road funding generally in respect of States. That is not the case. In fact, the Commonwealth has deliberately offered a substantial incentive package of additional road funding in exchange for an agreement for moves to be made by the States in agreement with the Commonwealth to attack two clearly recognisable and definable areas that cause massive loss of life and injury, and, in purely financial terms, great loss to the public purse. I refer to speed and booze.

ANSWER.PARA: I have a personal view, which I am sure is shared by a great many senators, that people who drink should not drive at all. In terms of the individual tragedy, distress and damage that they can cause. I think that motor vehicle drivers should be placed under the same restrictions as airline pilots and should not be allowed to drive with any level of alcohol in their blood. That is my own personal position. But in order to advance some lesson in the carnage that is being wrought on roads around Australia, the Commonwealth has directed an incentive package in exchange for agreement to reduce the level to 0.05.

There are a number of States, and certainly my own Territory Government, which are not prepared at this stage to agree to that. The question of the 10-point package is very specific. It is being offered as a package and it can be either accepted or rejected on that basis. If there is no agreement on 0.05, the black spots package, as it has become known, will not be provided to the governments concerned, and I think that that is appropriate.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is appropriate-all or nothing.

—In response to the endless and mindless interjections of Senator Alston, let me say this. I served as a divisional officer with St John Ambulance in the Northern Territory for eight years. I personally carted more dead bodies and bits of bodies off the road than I care to remember. I can honestly say that in those eight years I attended hundreds of serious motor vehicle accidents. The Northern Territory has the worst road fatality record in Australia. In respect of the accidents I attended, in my experience not one serious motor vehicle accident where death or injury occurred was not related directly to alcohol abuse. I commend this program. I urge all State governments to respond positively and to set a national limit of 0.05.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Defence. Can he advise what percentage of gross domestic product (GDP) he regards as necessary to achieve our required defence capability, as established by his predecessor in the White Paper of 1987?
—That is not an easy question to answer because first of all we have to establish what defence capability we want--
—As established by your predecessor.

—Senator Newman has had her question. We also have to establish the basic amount of money available for the priorities of the Government and then put it to the best possible use. That naturally involves a lot of prioritising in defence and, from her knowledge of defence matters, Senator Newman would be well aware of the various projects that are either in place or in prospect. The real task is to manage that amount of money. I do not think it is all that productive to set a specific amount of GDP. We could say that 5 per cent was ideal if we wanted to squander money all over the place. It is how we manage the money and how effectively we put it into the programs that is important, not the percentage of GDP allocated.

—Mr President, I have a supplementary question. Do I take it from that answer that the Minister is rejecting the requirements set out in the White Paper of 1987 and the 3 per cent of gross domestic product set out to achieve that capability?

—The reference to 3 per cent in the White Paper is not the eleventh commandment and it was never meant to be so. It was set as a target figure. In recent years when expenditure of GDP, from the Government's point of view, has dropped from 30 per cent to 23 per cent, all sorts of economic realities have come into our thinking. My job and that of the Defence Department is to make sure that we are able to meet either low level contingency threats or future high level contingency threats. That means that we have to build a basic platform in defence so that if in future there is a high level contingency threat we can expand that platform. In my view it is essential that that platform is adequate. But that is not strictly related to whether defence spending should be 2.3 per cent, 2.6 per cent or 2.8 per cent of GDP; that really has nothing to do with it. It is the way in which the money is spent, the way the force structure exists, and our capability and readiness. This is the important aspect and this is the challenge for the next few years.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Defence and concerns the transfer of North West Cape to full Australian control as announced by the Prime Minister prior to the recent election. Has the Minister identified a source for the $30m required to operate the station each year? Can he indicate whether the capital equipment and installations at the station are approaching an age at which extensive capital maintenance will be required? Can he indicate what the average annual capital bill is likely to be and whether this bill will go up as the station ages? I further ask the Minister whether the Government intends to go ahead with the transfer despite the massive operating and capital costs involved and will he give an undertaking that the funds will come from the Defence budget and not be obtained at the expense of other more worthy items outside the defence area. Finally, I ask why there was such a discrepancy between the figure of $30m a year given by his predecessor in terms of the cost of running the North West Cape facility, and the figure given by Washington analysts of $70m for staff services alone and a total cost of more than $100m by the time any agreement for transfer of control is completed?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I remind Senator Vallentine that on 12 March the Prime Minister said simply that the United States had agreed to discuss an Australian proposal to take over and operate the naval communications facilities and the Australian Defence Force facility, rather than keep them running as a joint facility. Under our proposal, Australia would manage the station and facilitate the passage of US Navy signals to US submarines. The primary function of the station is to communicate with submerged submarines. It provides the only means of communicating with our submarines and we use that capability extensively.

ANSWER.PARA: North West Cape will become even more important to Australia over the next 10 years as our new submarines join the Royal Australian Navy. They will make the submarine squadron an even more critical element of Australia's defence and our defence self-reliance. The operation of North West Cape as an Australian defence facility will therefore further enhance our drive for self-reliance. It shows that Australia itself is willing to take responsibility for ensuring that the essential element of a submarine capability is maintained.

We cannot state the costs definitely because they will depend on a number of factors, including the outcome of negotiations with the United States and changes to the station which should cut operating costs. As a guide, and contrary to the speculation of the anonymous analysts in Washington referred to in the question, the station's operating costs now run at $30m a year. About 80 per cent of that is spent on a staff of over 700. New technologies offer scope to reduce the staffing levels considerably. I add only that, as well as enhancing Australia's defence self-reliance, this forward-looking proposal will also make a new and constructive contribution to our alliance with the United States and support our shared interests in the stability of the Asia-Pacific region.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday in Question Time Senator Bjelke-Petersen asked me a question on taxation zone rebates. I have obtained an answer from the Treasurer. As announced by the Prime Minister in December last year, the Government is currently reviewing aspects of the zone rebate arrangements. A review will be completed in time for consideration in the context of the 1990-91 Budget. I am not in any position to pre-empt the outcome of that review at this time.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Watson proposing that a matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The need for the Government to implement measures which will respect the integrity of Australians as taxpayers and to protect both taxpayers' rights and the revenue.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is an urgent need for action to be taken on the part of the Government to remedy some glaring deficiencies in the Australian taxation system. These problems are particularly significant with the introduction of partial self-assessment for individuals, and as from 1 July 1990 full self-assessment for companies and superannuation funds. The nine million taxpayers-I repeat nine million-in Australia are nowadays at the mercy of officers of the Australian Taxation Office. The Government, in its haste to introduce self-assessment, has principally addressed those issues that create the framework to satisfy Australian Taxation Office procedures and to increase the revenue. But in the process taxpayers' rights have been ignored. We therefore call on the Government at the earliest practicable opportunity to implement the recommendations of the McKinsey report to reduce the costs of uncertainty, complexity and distrust at present amongst Australian company and individual taxpayers.

SPEECH.PARA: The move towards self-assessment has created uncertainty. Self-assessment demands certainty. Yet this certainty of the legislation has been eroded by a shift of the responsibility for the assessment from the Australian Taxation Office to the individual. As a result, the rights of Australian taxpayers have been ignored, sacrificed and, I believe, plundered by this Government with the introduction of self-assessment because there is no longer a balance between the safeguards for taxpayers on the one hand and administrative convenience on the other. The responsibilities that the new system imposed by self-assessment on individual and corporate taxpayers are now quite enormous. Urgent action is needed in the areas of disclosures, commissioners' rulings, penalties, amendments and objections.

Taxpayers have to battle with a tax ruling system and a tax Act that is ponderous and riddled with gaps and inconsistencies. The need for a simplified system is urgent. This lack of balance occurs directly from the way in which this new system was grafted by the Government onto the existing legislative framework designed to permit self-assessment. The only significant changes that have occurred were technical in nature and aimed at improving the efficiency and lowering the paper load of the Australian Taxation Office. Today, in this democratic society, as a result of this hasty drafting and introduction of legislation, more power is given to a duly authorised officer of the Australian Taxation Office than is granted to a police officer in the prosecution of a criminal offence.

It is not surprising that there are calls from taxpayers far and wide for a Bill of Rights for taxpayers. A police officer's powers, for example, of search and seizure under the Crimes Act are clearly stated. A search warrant is issued only when a justice of the peace is satisfied of certain specific matters and that its scope will be limited to a particular place. While there might be certain justification for the Australian Taxation Office's much publicised raid on Citibank, the methods used highlight the problem. In fact, some on the other side of the chamber might seek to criticise my choice of this case, but the responses of the judges involved in relation to sections 263 and 264 of the Crimes Act deserve comment, for the judiciary were indeed very concerned at the application of these particular provisions. In addition, the methods used highlight the problems of overzealous activity: thirty-seven officers from the Australian Taxation Office, including a locksmith, arrived unannounced at the Citibank's premises for the purpose of making and removing copies of documents in relation to an alleged form of tax avoidance scheme.

While some of the documents inspected related to the scheme, most of them related to other taxation matters. The Australian Taxation Office, under section 263 of the Act, has the right of full and free access at all times to all buildings, places, books, documents and other papers for the purposes of the Act. This power extends to any appropriately duly authorised officer. Yet the problem is that there is no outside check on whom they contact or where they enter, as with a police officer. In fact, Justice French, commenting on sections 263 and 264 of the Act, stated that the Commissioner and his officers are armed with powerful investigative instruments, and he said that the very width of those powers demands a watchful concern that their limits are not exceeded. Further, Justice Bowen and Justice Fisher felt obliged to make the following observation:
We consider that it is unfortunate that . . . a degree of specificity was not a mandatory obligation.

So an officer of the Australian Taxation Office does not need a search warrant. He does not even need to inform under oath a justice of the peace of his specific intentions. In fact, he does not even have to hand the taxpayer a list of the taxpayer's rights or obligations. I would have thought that would have been the first and fundamental thing that he should have done.

We have a case in Victoria where a man from the Australian Taxation Office walked into a small business and asked for the books and records. There was not a lot of room in which to work. He took the filing cabinet, and that man-a small businessman-was out of business for several weeks before the documents were returned. Not one extra cent of tax was paid; no writ, no summons, was issued. The official produced only his card and said that he wanted the documents. The taxpayer, unaware of his rights, handed them over obligingly, and, of course, his stubs and all these sorts of things-the cheque books, paying-in books-went with them. Had he realised his rights, had he gone to one of the big eight, he would have been told of his rights and what he could keep, et cetera. But we should not have to go to those lengths. We are told that the Taxation Office is supposed to be helpful. What sort of help is given by putting a man out of business for a number of weeks?

These calls for taxpayers' rights and protection come not from the blatant tax avoiders, for whom we have absolutely no sympathy-I ask honourable senators to take note of that-but from the judges, former members of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, the former Deputy Commissioner of Taxation in Victoria, the Taxation Institute of Australia, other taxpayer bodies and the public, John Citizen.

These people who have seen or suffered first-hand from some overly zealous action often do not have an axe to grind. They believe in justice, fair play and, in modern parlance, a balanced playing field. I have in my possession information relating to a small milk bar proprietor, who inadvertently forget to return some unused group certificates, duplicate copies of used certificates and, naturally, the annual reconciliation of those documents. It was an honest clerical oversight. The papers were filed in the drawer instead of being forwarded. There was no loss of revenue and scarcely any effect on the efficiency of the taxation administration at all, but what happened? There were no reminders or friendly telephone calls but, rather, a summons, a prosecution and a fine-a prosecution not on one count; the prosecution was for three offences. What did the magistrate do? Fines and penalties of over $800 were imposed through the civil court system.

This system does not concur with this notion of voluntary compliance-the proper attitude required from the Taxation Office-because `voluntary' implies a willingness on the part of the taxpayer. To misuse the court process rather than use the telephone is a non-achievement of a voluntary compliance-a level of coercion reminiscent of the failed bureaucracies of Eastern Europe. A common advertisement to the community from the Tax Office states: `Your taxes building a better Australia' but, without proper recognition of taxpayers' rights, the community response will soon become: `Your taxes building a bitter Australia'.

Mr Peter Roach, a former member of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, claims that taxpayers may not have adequate protection from harassment by the Australian Taxation Office and he ought to know; it is his day-to-day bread and butter. He says that officers can extend or change the audit at their discretion, especially where they perceive a lack of cooperation or even indifference on the part of the taxpayer.

The business community also is deeply worried about the real scope and the practical exercise of the Commissioner's and his officers' powers of access under the Act. It appears, particularly from the corporate section of Australian taxpayers, that the officers do not always act without prejudice, or without fear or favour. In fact, the business community is beginning to fear that a genuine anti-business feeling is being shown. There has been an enormous shift of resources in auditing the top 100 companies with success, they state, being widely publicised in the press. But the publication of the companies' names implies that they are tax cheats, yet the records actually show that, in percentage terms, corporate Australia is a no greater tax avoider than the rest of the Australian tax paying community. This auditing is combined with frequently publicised newspaper comments from officers of the Tax Office who are engaged in these audits. I mention just one or two to indicate the sort of publicity they are seeking and I quote from one of them:
When you come to the swamp and you're armpit deep in the slime, it's easy to forget your job is to drain the swamp.

These are the sort of comments coming from audit officers within the Australian Taxation Office that are grabbing headlines in newspapers. I might say in the Commissioner's defence that he has publicly resiled from these attitudes expressed by some of his officers. He has adopted a much more even-handed approach in the papers he has delivered to various professional organisations. However, the point is that these sentiments must permeate down through the ranks to the audit staff and to the people on the job.

I must say that some of these previous examples that I have given to the Senate today about the abuse of taxpayers' rights and the future practices that these examples appear to condone do not concur with the stated objectives of the Taxation Office. I instance-and I have to be even-handed because I have a lot of respect for Mr Boucher and what he is doing-his address to the tax liaison group. The Commissioner stated:
The Tax Office aims to become an organisation of people equipped, trained and committed to helping taxpayers and other clients carry out their responsibilities under the law.
That is a great statement which I think is wholly endorsed. He later went on to say:
Our key business is to help taxpayers and other clients do what is expected of them under the tax laws.

The key word in both these addresses is `help'. Does the Australian Tax Office encourage voluntary compliance by making examples of people who have made honest mistakes? In the same speech he goes on to say:
The corner-stone of the whole edifice of the ATO-
that is under self-assessment-
is voluntary compliance, with service as the key element in achieving that.

Would not some recognition of the taxpayer and of his rights help in this? Should not the individual be given some protection under the law? Australian taxation officers will then not be encouraged to be what I term overzealous. Then we would have-this was implied-a true spirit of voluntary compliance which should always be encouraged under self-assessment.

If we examine what is happening with other countries which have gone down the path of self-assessment, we can then compare their performance with ours in Australia. In fact, if we look at five countries, as the Institute of Chartered Accountants and the Taxation Institute of Australia did, and compare access powers of revenue authorities, without exception we find that the policy position differed significantly from the current practice of self-assessment in Australia. Australia is the only country in which the revenue authorities have unrestricted access. Accordingly it is felt by many taxpayers that protection must be based on some other criterion that presently exists under the Act. It is recommended that this be developed by having regard to the basis on which a taxpayer's return has been compiled. This is important, given the fact that we have moved away from section 170.

It has been argued that if a taxpayer has adopted a reasonably arguable position for a particular item-that is, he has adopted his position in preparing his return based on rulings precedented, and internal and external tax advice-then there should not be any basis for a culpability penalty. That should be fair; that should be basic. But we have not got that. This will require a clear definition to be enshrined in the law. It is too fundamental to be dealt with through just the ruling process.

Taxpayers have 60 days in which to object to an assessment, while the Australian Taxation Office now requires records to be kept for four years after lodgment and it can require an audit in any one of those years-even earlier. The taxpayers have no enforceable rights after the 60-day time limit for the objection. It is considered by many dealing in this area that taxpayers should now have corresponding rights after the 60-day limit for objection. Equal rights would give the taxpayer four years in which to raise an objection. If we have it on one side, we should have it on the other.

It is the view of many that where a taxpayer adopts a reasonably argued position in relation to an item in a return, it should not be necessary for him to disclose this fact in his return. This is the position in the United States. It will be reasonably difficult for corporate taxpayers since in the future under self-assessment they will perhaps have no more than a one-page return, and there is a limit to what can be put on that page.

The point is that if the taxpayer's position proves to be wrong in the eyes of the Taxation Office, he should not be penalised for the interest on the penalty; he should be penalised only by the penalty. It would be necessary to keep proper documentation of the contentious issues. If full disclosure was required on these one-page returns, it would effectively be a de facto return to the old system. In addition, in the area of the question of interest, we have a number of problems. Because the payment and receipt of interest are not even, there is a difference between what is paid by the Taxation Office in certain cases of overpayment arising from an objection or appeal. In one case it is assessable; in the other it is non-deductable.

But let me finish on a very positive note. I have lots of other examples to give but I want to be constructive in this debate, to try to help the Government, which I hope will help the taxpayers. Firstly, I think we should be looking at moving towards a bill of rights, whether enshrined in legislation or, as a minimum, certainly in some regulatory form. As I mentioned, there is no obligation on the Tax Commissioner to notify a taxpayer or give a notification of a taxpayer's rights on audit.

Secondly, communications of advice between all registered tax agents and their clients should be confidential from the Commissioner's standpoint. The taxpayers have a right to know of the Commissioner's view on the interpretation of tax laws, especially where contentious issues are involved. An overhaul of the self-assessment system has a number of glaring deficiencies.

In other words, we should make the Commissioner's administrative rulings binding on him. There should be binding commitments between the Taxation Office and the Tax Commissioner in relation to audit negotiations. The making of the tax penalties, especially culpability penalties, should be made much fairer. There is a need for a simplification of the taxation system. I am glad to say that the Government is making some tentative moves in this area, but it is a big job. In relation to self-assessment there is a need for a concept to replace the old full and true disclosure requirement, having regard to the basis on which the tax return has been prepared.

Finally, the integrity and the privacy of a man's home and his place of business needs to be respected. Higher regard for the taxpayer by the Australian Taxation Office needs to be encouraged because the taxpayer needs to be able to approach the Tax Office with trust, without fear of prejudice, without fear of excessive high penalties. But the legislation as it now stands is bad law; it needs to be rectified.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —When this matter of public importance was first drawn to my attention the wording seemed to be positively delphic. It took some consultation with a large number of colleagues and others to be quite sure of the nub of this particular argument. Let me address some of the points that seem to me to be raised by the letter, even if they were not all mentioned in Senator Watson's speech. The first is the reference to respecting the integrity of Australians as taxpayers. I assume that by that honourable senator is saying, although he did not actually refer to it, that we should assume that most Australians are honest and deal with the tax system accordingly. Although the honourable senator did not say anything about it I do not have any difficulty with that point. The whole concept of self-assessment and voluntary compliance is based on it, and I think it is a valid point. I am not sure that it takes us very far as a basis of planning but it is correct and I do not argue with it.

SPEECH.PARA: Then we get on to the nub of the argument, the question essentially of the balance between protection of rights and protection of revenue. It is very important that we look at that balance, that we talk about striking that balance, but nobody would argue with that. There has to be a balance; it is almost a question of definition. The questions are: Where do you strike it and how do you maintain that proper balance? In practical terms this Government has massively redressed the imbalance that had been created. When we came into office, of course, there was an imbalance entirely in favour of people who did not want to pay their tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish. Section 260 of the Income Tax Assessment Act is the lie because of the High Court, not because of anything you did.
—There was no doubt that most wealthy Australian taxpayers regarded paying tax as entirely voluntary. Senator Baume wishes it had been different but everybody-
—You are rewriting history.
—Everybody knows-
—Order! Senator McMullan has the call.
—Who do you blame?
—The High Court.

—The only thing I agree with in all the interjections is that the High Court was substantially responsible for the problem. I have no disagreement with that. But the absence of a capital gains tax was equally fundamental in the problem because it left a gaping hole. It said, `Written invitation: if you do not wish to pay your tax, please go through this door'. That was the situation that had the balance entirely skewed in favour of those who-
—What sort of door have you left for the cash economies? You have done nothing about it. It is selective indignation.

—We now find that a lot of people are paying tax who never thought they should have to pay tax, who thought that the right to be protected was their right not to pay tax, and they are now substantially concerned about this.

SPEECH.PARA: I never noticed any expressions of serious concern about the rights of ordinary pay-as-you-earn taxpayers who in those days had to pay much more tax than was their proper responsibility because so many people who should have been paying tax were paying nothing. There was great concern about the possibility of voluntary compliance because so many ordinary Australian men and women resented the fact that they were the only ones paying tax: if you were not paying pay-as-you-earn tax you were paying nothing. There is no doubt that that door was wide open. A lot of honest taxpayers were paying their tax and a lot of dishonest people were rorting the system. The key to the change has been the introduction of the capital gains tax.

I agree with some of the things that Senator Watson said. I thought that there were some positive elements in his contribution, and I welcome them. There is no doubt that a cooperative relationship between the Taxation Office and taxpayers on the question of voluntary compliance is the necessary key to the tax system because, firstly, most Australians are honest and pay their tax as they believe they are obliged to do-some do not and certainly in the decade leading up to 1983 all too many did not; but there is no doubt that even then most Australians were honest and they remain so-and, secondly, voluntary compliance is vital because there is no alternative. We cannot have a system of large-scale collection of tax without substantial voluntary compliance from the overwhelming majority of honest taxpayers.

Voluntary compliance-the enthusiasm and preparedness of ordinary Australians to meet their obligations-is significantly undermined when they do not have respect for the integrity of the system under which they are paying. That respect comes from and requires an acceptance that all are paying their fair share of tax, and certainly that has been substantially enhanced.

Some of the things that have been done to enhance that respect are part of what has generated the concern to which Senator Watson was referring-for example, the increasing emphasis upon and publicity about audits of the top companies. I make no apology for the increasing emphasis on that. It is an entirely proper use of Taxation Office resources. It is entirely efficient. There should not be publicity about individual taxpayers but about the fact that that process is going on and that it is successful, is entirely proper and appropriate and is welcomed by the overwhelming majority of Australians, and by me.

In a system of voluntary compliance there are those-I am sure that Senator Watson and all people of good will would agree with me-who have to be made to comply voluntarily and those who require significant encouragement to comply voluntarily. It is important that we continue to have a significant aspect of our tax system putting pressure on those people to so comply.

I want to say something about the administration of the Taxation Office, the tax system, the Australian Commissioner of Taxation and the fact that sometimes the Commissioner and his officers do take controversial decisions in the pursuit of revenue. I refer to a Senate committee decision of 1987. Dealing with the ruling system it said:

The Commissioner is entitled to test the law where he regards it as in doubt, where the Commissioner considers it desirable in order to protect the revenue. Arguably, the Commissioner has a duty so to do.

That is true, but not that he has to. His obligation to Australian taxpayers is to take decisions to protect the revenue and the Senate committee was absolutely right to find that. However, his administration is not unfettered. His discretions are not and cannot be unfettered because he acts within the body of Australian administrative law-the legal system as a whole and the administrative law framework in particular.

Australia has a very well developed legal system and now, due to the legislation of the previous government and this one, a well-developed body of administrative review of administrative actions and a comprehensive system of administrative reforms to assist people in dealing with the Government. All these are appropriate, including the role of the Ombudsman and review available under the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act and the Freedom of Information Act, et cetera. We have to see that that context within which the administrative initiatives of the Commissioner for Taxation take place are significant protections for the rights of Australians. They are proper protections and significant protections against abuse of power.

In addition we have had by the Tax Office and the Taxation Commissioner the preparedness to accept the need for powers to be exercised carefully and professionally and, more importantly for the purposes of this discussion, within administrative guidelines. We must set parameters to the circumstances and the manner in which various powers will be exercised. These guidelines are being developed and settled in consultation with tax practitioners, businesses and others. There are guidelines about the conduct of large case audits and about the exercise of access powers. There are guidelines setting out how tax officers should deal with taxpayers, about the provision of assistance and advice, about problem resolution and there are guidelines being developed about the conduct of smaller business audits and settlement guidelines. Senator Baume may not have worked it out but they are not a very well kept secret.

One of the other good things that is happening in the Tax Office is the consultative process. There are representatives of the Business Council of Australia, the various business groups and other welfare and community groups represented on the Commissioner's advisory panel who know how these guidelines are developing and who are properly aware of the processes developing in the administration of the Australian tax system. They do take place. That is relevant within the question of judicial review because as many honourable senators would know there is a substantial precedent to establish the fact that failure to comply with such guidelines can well be taken into account in judicial review of administrative action. This is properly so and the precedent exists.

Obviously this question of the high profile audit has generated some concern because very many people with significant power in our community and with access to the media have been adversely affected and have been expressing very forthright views about the conduct of these audits. There are enormous amounts of revenue involved. It is substantial and proper for any business-like organisation that is applying its resources to take account of the revenue return on the resources it applies as one of the factors it takes into account in determining the distribution and application of its resources. Audits are not merely taking place amongst the largest companies. Small businesses are being audited and individual taxpayers are being audited. Everybody knows, and I assume accepts, because it is so obvious that a necessary corollary of self-assessment is audit. This is properly so.

It is not the slightest bit surprising that a substantial proportion of the resources being applied to audit of taxpayers is being applied to the biggest taxpayers not because they are necessarily considered less honest than others nor more honest but because that is where the revenue is. They are the largest taxpayers and it is the place where the greatest majority of errors could have a substantial impact on the revenue. There will be some controversial cases arising out of that. There will be contests about the interpretation of the law. This is properly so because it is a perfectly legitimately process.

I briefly refer to a couple of matters that Senator Watson referred to with which I agree and which are useful for us to put on the record. One is the question of simplification. There is no doubt that a very major requirement of the Australian tax system is simplification. It is a very much misunderstood concept. We cannot have a simple tax system, in some senses of the word, operating within a very complex society. It is a law to regulate complex procedures. It is not going to be as simple as some other pieces of legislation. But it certainly requires simplification in a different sense of the word, that is, making it more comprehensible. Even if it was only presented in a more orderly fashion that would make it much easier. The simplification project which the Treasurer has initiated is a very substantial simplification process. It will not be quick. It has been assessed that it might take five years.

TALK.START.PARA: —But the damage in the meantime.

—But it cannot be quick and the honourable senator would understand that. I want to emphasise, as I have to groups with whom I have spoken in recent times, that no changes will take place in that intervening period. The first stage of that simplification process will be the production of a discussion paper this year. That will be before the end of the third quarter of this year. That process is well under way. It will be a substantial contribution to the debate about the Australian tax system but it will not of itself be a reform. It will be a discussion paper from the Tax Policy Division of Treasury and the Tax Office. It will not necessarily be the Government's view.

SPEECH.PARA: It is important that we also have an emphasis and expansion of some of the aspects about self-assessment. As soon as possible we need to have full self-assessment for ordinary taxpayers and to provide help to them to enable them to properly discharge their obligations. Those sentiments which are reflected in Senator Watson's speech are appropriate and shared. He said that he respected the way in which Mr Boucher was conducting the Tax Office. They were some of the matters to which he referred. I welcome that and I share his view in that area.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about rules?

—I would like to have a long discussion about rulings but that takes me on a tangent. There is one other point about rulings that Senator Watson referred to. That was the question of the need to address the matters raised by the McKinsey report. That is a matter which I have discussed with the Commissioner. I am assured that there has been a fairly tight timetable set down for response to the McKinsey report. I say `response to' because it is a report. Not everything that it recommends will necessarily be taken up, and nor should it, but a response to that will be prompt and comprehensive. A large number of the matters which it raises which are valid have been, and others will be, taken up fairly quickly. I do not want to divert into a big debate on that point. It is a bit of a tangent but I did want to refer to it. I think it is a valid point.

SPEECH.PARA: It is true that we always have a need to maintain a balance between the rights of individual Australians, not just as taxpayers but as citizens, and their obligations and rights to protect the revenue. If one wants to look at the John Stuart Mill view of liberty where we are talking about one's right to pursue one's chosen course of action in so far as it does not interfere with the rights of others that is a very appropriate step to take. If one pursues one's individual course of action in such a way that one artificially minimises or attempts to avoid one's proper taxation obligations that does impinge upon the rights of others. It is very easy to look at it in isolation and say, `I have a right to organise my activities to minimise the tax and pass the tax responsibility on to somebody else'. That is the point, the nub of the rights argument. When one pursues it in that fairly traditional liberal way, in the proper sense of the word, one passes one's tax obligations to other citizens or deprives other citizens of the revenue base from which they are reasonably entitled to expect assistance.

I think that we have to look at rights and look at them fairly comprehensively-not in the artificial sense of a bill of rights. In so far as this relates to tax, I am not initially attracted to the idea of a taxpayers' bill of rights. The Australian situation is dramatically different from those countries which have looked at that. But in coming towards a conclusion, I am delighted about this new-found concern with rights.

We have had more comprehensive debates in this Parliament in the few years since I have been here and in the wider Australian community expressing concern about the rights of Australian citizens and about the concept of a slightly wider bill of rights that might have gone into our Constitution. That, however, foundered on the rock of this Opposition across the way. Members opposite with great enthusiasm were prepared to take this narrow and petty view which undermined a proper extension of rights to Australians. But those opposite have now discovered a wonderful passion for a bill of rights for taxpayers, but nothing about a bill of rights for the rest of Australians in all their other body of activities that go on out there in their day to day relations with government and with other citizens. It is a new-found concern, but it is very welcome. It might lead to a review of their attitude to the Human Rights Commission, which they are always proposing to abolish at each election. Fortunately, they keep being rejected and so the problem does not arise. The right to so organise one's business affairs that one minimises one's tax seems to be a much more important right than the freedom of assembly, freedom of association or freedom of speech. That is not a view that is shared on this side of the Senate.

I think that it is important that we maintain a balance between rights and revenue, and it is a matter that needs regular review and review each time the law is changed. There is a better balance now than there has been for a long time-not perfect, but better. There is increased voluntary compliance; there is increased respect because more taxpayers regard the tax system as fair. I make no apology for supporting decisions that have been taken to protect the revenue, to protect the rights of honest taxpayers from those who would pass their proper obligations on to them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K. .

TALK.START.PARA: —This matter of public importance has been raised in a climate where there is growing disquiet concerning the way the integrity and rights of the ordinary taxpayer are being treated under our system of taxation. Senator Watson outlined, I thought very succinctly, the difficulties that a taxpayer faces with a system of self-assessment which has been superimposed on a system which was designed for another purpose. The wording of this matter of public importance has been very carefully set out, because we are concerned that the integrity and the rights of the taxpayer and the revenue both require protection. Senator McMullan in his speech said that it is a question of balance, and it is that question of balance which this matter of public importance is designed to address.

SPEECH.PARA: During the last 12 months there has been a tremendous outpouring of writing, discussion and publishing by people who have a genuine concern that the area of taxation law has now become uncertain. If there is one thing that our system of the rule of law requires, it is that the law be certain. We have seen former senior officers of the Australian Taxation Office (ATO) commenting on this situation. Mr Ray Conwell recently spoke at a conference and was reported as saying that the growing freedom of action expressed by the Taxation Commissioner, Mr Boucher, is one of the least certain matters facing the citizens of this country. Mr Boucher chose to respond to Mr Conwell's criticisms of the way in which the Taxation Office is presently being administered by saying:

You see, there is a very strong obligation on those who are critical of existing arrangements to get beyond critical mode, and to offer in a positive fashion alternatives to the situation they denounce.

That is exactly what this matter of public importance is about. Mr Boucher wanted people to put forward positive suggestions, and that is what is happening today. On 22 April, for instance, a press release from Marketplace Communications dealing with the question of uncertainty and unfairness was put out saying that the Taxation Institute of Australia had expressed the following view:

Our experience is that individuals using the self assessment system underestimate their tax obligations and this problem would be compounded unless sensible legislation was introduced across Australia. The legislation as it stands could have far-reaching ramifications for the entire economy and each individual in Australia.

The President of the Institute said that the penalty for misleading or inaccurate information could get as high as 200 per cent of the avoided sum. However, in most cases it would be between 40 and 50 per cent. The Taxation Institute has called on the Government to implement safeguards to protect taxpayers' rights as well as the Government's major revenue collection framework.

Historically, I would go back to an important appraisal, namely the report of the Joint Working Party on Self-Assessment in June 1989. That was a very responsible group of individuals-three from the Australian Taxation Office, one from the Australian Society of Accountants, one from the Australian Taxpayers Association, and one from the Taxation Institute of Australia. That working party set out in its report many concerns. Perhaps I could paraphrase them into simple English, so that this debate is useful to people who are not familiar with the jargon which has become part and parcel of all taxation discussions. That joint working party which reported was set up as a result of matters raised by the National Tax Liaison Group. It was proposed that the Commissioner should agree to the formation of a working party to look at particular concerns relating to the self-assessment system.

The working party met in June 1989 and made these sorts of recommendations. The first was that there would be a further working party established to carry out some of its recommendations. The second was that the Australian Taxation Office consider separate legislative provisions for the imposition of interest, so that penalty provisions deal solely with culpability-that is, wrongdoing, not innocent mistakes. The third was that a consistent approach be adopted between interest paid and interest received. At present if the Commissioner makes a refund and pays interest on it, that interest is assessable income in the hands of the taxpayer and must be dealt with in the next return. But the converse is not true. The proposal put forward is that there ought to be a consistent and even-handed approach to interest, so that if interest is paid by the taxpayer there be a deduction if interest received from the Taxation Office has to be declared as assessable income.

A fourth recommendation was that Income Tax Ruling IT2157 be amended to ensure that where there is no legal precedent or income tax ruling pertaining to a situation, no-culpability penalties should be imposed where a taxpayer's stance is genuinely arguable. In other words, with self-assessment having been superimposed on the system that was designed for a taxpayer to put his documentation forward, a bureaucratic decision will be made about it, and either an amendment will be made or subsequently the assessment will be issued. We now have a situation where the taxpayer is obliged at the time of the lodgment of his return to make a judgment about the current system of law. At the time of that lodgment he is not entitled to make what he considers to be a fair appraisal, but he must predict and anticipate what the Commissioner may determine to be his interpretation. So there is no room in the system presently for a fair, honest and legitimate interpretation of how the law stands without risking penalty.

Fifthly, it was recommended that appropriate actions be taken to make all penalties capable of being reviewed, which is presently not the case. Sixthly, it was recommended the position relating to professional privilege for lawyer and non-lawyer registered tax agents be reviewed to ensure that tax advice be treated consistently. At present if a tax agent is also a lawyer, then privilege attaches to the advice given. If the tax agent is not a lawyer, but an accountant or the like, then no such privilege attaches. This is clearly unfair. By the way, the Australian Taxation Office did not support that--

TALK.START.PARA: —Where did these recommendations come from?
—As I indicated earlier, they came from the Joint Working Party on Self-Assessment of June 1989.

SPEECH.PARA: The seventh suggestion is that the terms of reference for the suggested working party include the roles, obligations and responsibilities of the Australian Taxation Office, taxpayers and tax practitioners. It is not surprising that the number of people who have their tax returns prepared for them by tax agents is as high as 70 per cent. That is a commentary on the complexity of our system, but in turn, in a way, it makes self-assessment possible and it also makes the next projected phase-electronic returns-possible.

The eighth recommendation was that the Australian Taxation Office should continue to improve the effectiveness of its education and assistance programs; ninthly, the Tax Office should continue to improve the design of the return forms; and tenthly, the ATO should implement an advisory and assistance program for taxpayers selected for audit.

The eleventh suggestion is that the Tax Office impress upon its staff the fact that they should adopt a more reasonable approach in applying the substantiation rules in cases where it is obvious that the expenditure has been incurred. The twelfth recommendation is that the terms of reference for the suggested working party-the one which was listed in the first recommendation-should include consideration of the information required in income tax returns and time limits for amendments of assessments.

The thirteenth recommendation is that the ruling clarifying the operation of section 169a (2)-the one that requires the Commissioner of Taxation to pay attention to questions raised in documents furnished in returns by individual taxpayers-be expedited because there is no time constraint on the Commissioner at present. I understand that there is a ruling pending from the Commissioner but at present it is only in draft form.

The fourteenth recommendation is that the terms of reference for the proposed working party include consideration of the feasibility of dispensing with the issuing of notices of assessment. The fifteenth recommendation is that the terms of reference should also include consideration of the strategic direction of self-assessment.

As I said, all that happened in June 1989. Perhaps one could say that as a direct result of that review we have received the report by McKinsey and Co. on Tax Office reforms. That was the report that was referred to by my colleague, Senator Watson. It is an important report in that it too makes certain recommendations, again calling for the need for clarity and certainty.

The report breaks up its recommendations into three categories, the first being the Australian Taxation Office itself. As I have said, this matter of public importance debate is designed to have not only the integrity and the rights of the taxpayer acknowledged but also the rights of the revenue so that this is a balanced discussion. The McKinsey report sets out its concerns about the Tax Office. It is concerned about the undersupply of quality advisings and resources and about significant staff turnover.

From the point of view of a tax agent, there is uncertainty and complexity in applying the income tax law. For example, once a return has been lodged, and the law then changes, what is the obligation on the taxpayer with regard to amending that return under the self-assessment system? The lodgment program deadlines which were imposed upon tax agents are also of concern to them. Again, for large companies there is uncertainty and complexity in complying with income tax law. Inconsistent execution of the audit program is also a problem.

The cost question is very real. The sorts of amendments that have been brought about during this Government's period in office have made the law far more complex. These amendments have caused accountants to be in great demand and have also resulted in the loss of expertise from the Tax Office itself because of the growing demands of the private sector to have expertise to cope with the new laws as they are introduced.

In terms of benefit to the Tax Office, the self-assessment system is of quite considerable value and one would hope that the current cost of $1.10 for collecting $100 worth of revenue could be decreased to something like 45c. There is considerable benefit to the Tax Office in the self-assessment system, but fundamentally those people who write and practise in the area will say that the only way the self-assessment system can work is if the taxpayer is honest and wishes to comply with the law.

The way the law is presently framed means that a taxpayer can wish to comply with the law-he may find himself in what we can describe as the newly created culture where people believe that they have an obligation to meet their fair share of taxation-but the uncertainty and the way in which the discretionary powers of the Commissioner are exercised means that it is often a matter of luck as to whether an ordinary taxpayer is determined ultimately to have complied to the satisfaction not of the law but of the Commissioner's interpretation of it.

Uncertainty in a system which is dependent on the rule of law is not acceptable and this matter of public importance debate is designed to draw the Government's attention to the need for amendments to make it certain so that the honest taxpayer who wants his or her integrity respected by this system can comply with the law, which, in turn, he or she respects.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the first time that I have spoken-leaving aside a bit of yelling out across the chamber-since I have moved to my new position. After a bit more than 12 years on the front bench, I cannot go much further back without going out the door, as Paul Keating said in similar circumstances about someone else-I have forgotten who it was now.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Watson has long known a great deal about the detail and minutiae of the taxation Act, and I freely concede that he knows more about it than I ever did. However, sometimes I think that this intense scrutiny or focus on detail causes him to lose sight of some of the fundamentals. I believe that to some extent he is being used in this debate today by people much less worthy than himself. I am sure that Senator Watson would never fiddle his tax return or do anything scungy about anything else either, but there are people in the Liberal Party of Australia who have done and would like to continue doing so.

For some time there has been a campaign-some would even call it a witchhunt-against the Commissioner of Taxation personally and the Australian Taxation Office, organised, I suspect, by a not very large minority but one that is very influential in the Liberal Party. The Liberal Party has traditionally been soft on tax dodgers. The record shows it. In Western Australia in the early 1980s more than half of the Liberal Party finance Committee were ultimately shown to have been up to their ears in bottom of the harbour tax dodging activities. John Howard incurred the permanent wrath of a large part of the Liberal Party establishment because he was the Treasurer who introduced the unpaid company tax legislation in 1982. That is one of the reasons why he is not the leader of the Liberal Party today. He could even have been occupying a higher office than that.

TALK.START.PARA: —You cannot say that he did nothing about tax rorts. You cannot have it both ways.

—I have not said that he did nothing. When finally forced to, because of the scandals exposed by the McCabe-Lafranchi and Costigan reports, the Fraser Government did act-about 10 years after it should have acted. It took action which, as Senator McMullan has said, had there been a capital gains tax in Australia at the time, would never have been necessary.
—Stop repeating history.

—I am moving to the present. The Opposition, through its policy to emasculate the capital gains tax legislation, would expose the taxation system to the same fraud that almost wrecked it in the late 1970s and early 1980s.

SPEECH.PARA: It is true that the tax legislation is voluminous. The reasons for that result from decisions of the High Court of Australia, to which Senator Michael Baume referred earlier, through the 1970s and early 1980s. The legislation is written with the intention of covering every possible loophole that anybody could think of. Of course, the enforcement rules are pretty tough for the same reason. That is a reaction to the judgments that were handed down by Barwick's High Court. Of course, Barwick comes from that group of people, who are still around in the Liberal Party of Australia, who are soft on tax dodgers and who were involved in it themselves. He was a Liberal politician and a High Court judge. He started doing a bit of tax dodging and finished up doing a bit of forging; but I will come to that in a moment.

It was revealed in 1981 that the then Chief Justice of the High Court occupied a house in Sydney which the 1974 records of the Corporate Affairs Commission showed was owned by a company called Mundroola Pty Ltd. It was the Barwickfamily company. The 1974 returns listed Sir Garfield as a director of that company. He occupied the company house. The tax law at the time required that either he declare on his personal tax return an imputed rental-include that as assessable income-or that he would be paying rent and the company return would need to show that he was paying rent on the house and the company would have to declare that as company income. Because of section 16, of course, nobody knows for sure-it was never revealed officially-whether either of those things were done.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. Is it proper to impugn the integrity of a former High Court judge in a debate-apart from anything else, in a way that is totally irrelevant to the matter before the chamber?
—Senator Baume, the matter that you raise does not cover former High Court judges, I regret to say.
—I have no doubt that you do regret it, Madam Acting Deputy President. But this is a bit of history that is worth re-examining because a lot of questions have still not been answered.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, when this was revealed in 1981 the then Chief Justice was acutely embarrassed. But within a week or two a letter turned up-a letter of resignation as a director of Mundroola Pty Ltd, with Sir Garfield Barwick's signature on it, dated 1974. Was that not convenient! The letter of resignation, backdated seven years, appeared shortly after it was exposed that the extant records of the Corporate Affairs Commission showed that Barwick was still a director of the company and that he was occupying the company house. I took some forensic advice at the time about this letter concerning the precision with which the age of paper and ink could be dated. The answer that I got back was that they could perhaps be dated in decades but not in single years. That was most unfortunate because, had it been possible to establish the age of paper to single years and it could have been established that the paper on which that letter was written was only, say, two years old, the document would unquestionably have been a forgery. Unfortunately, that sort of precision is not possible; it can be dated only in decades.

Another matter arises from this. As I said before, in 1981 no returns had been lodged with the Corporate Affairs Commission of New South Wales since 1974 for the company called Mundroola. Of course, that is a breach of the Companies Act. As far as I know, no prosecution was ever initiated against the company for its failure to comply with the Companies Act. I do not know why no prosecution was launched. But let me say that the Sydney legal establishment is widely regarded as having a very permissive attitude to a lot of fairly anti-social activity and this would not have been the first time that the Sydney legal establishment had closed ranks to protect its own.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I take a point of order on the question of relevance. I believe the Senate would like to hear from Senator Walsh his deep knowledge of income tax and its application to the matter before the Senate at the moment. I believe he could contribute a lot but he is missing that opportunity.
—I do not think you have a point of order, Senator Watson. But I ask Senator Walsh to make his remarks more relevant than they have appeared to me to be over the last two or three minutes.

—Thank you, Madam Acting Deputy President. I am not canvassing any rulings or opinions from the Chair. But I personally regard the actions and career of Garfield Barwick as highly relevant to any matter concerning taxation.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Watson and Senator Bishop seem to me to be a little bit confused. They recognise that self-assessment on cost efficiency grounds is an extremely good idea and that it will reduce the cost of administering the tax Act. But they will not accept the quid pro quo that, if we have a self-assessment system, we will necessarily have a lesser degree of certainty than if the assessment is done by officers of the Australian Taxation Office. Self-assessment is an efficiency measure. Senator Watson even complained-I think I got his words down exactly-about the measures which were aimed at the efficiency and reducing the paper load of the Australian Taxation Office. I do not see anything wrong with having a system which aims to enhance the efficiency and reduce the paper load of the Australian Taxation Office.

Then there were the references, most of them probably disorderly, to the cash economy, about which Senator Watson, and I think Senator Baume, were complaining. I am also concerned about the cash economy. If they have any constructive ideas about how to deal with the cash economy, I and, I am sure, the Government would welcome their being put up. However, one of the remedies which it is often asserted would substantially damage the cash economy, that is, a movement towards consumption taxes instead of income taxes, would have a minimal effect, for reasons that I canvassed in an article earlier this week.

Senator Bishop gave a number of recommendations from a joint working party of June or July last year, on some of which, I agree, there seems to be a prima facie case for action, although somewhere close to the top of the list was the old argument about taxpayers having to borrow money to pay taxation assessments but being denied the cost of borrowing that money to pay their taxation assessments. Really, I would be extremely surprised if in the real world that actually matters, which, of course, does not exclude or oppose the idea of making some changes in that direction.

Another matter raised was that no penalties should be applied where a taxpayer's stance in a self-assessment judgment is arguable. The trouble with that is that it comes down to the judgments of some other people of what is arguable and what is not. It is an invitation to taxpayers to try to extend the law or the principles to their personal advantage.

The last point I want to make is that I do entirely agree with Senator Bishop, with one rider, about the privileged position of lawyers giving tax advice to their clients vis-a-vis the position of accountants. I agree that it is rather absurd that it should be the case that the lawyer can plead the fifth, so to speak, but the accountant cannot. It is particularly objectionable when one is aware of how much the legal profession has contributed-how directly it has connived and contributed-to tax evasion and avoidance in Australia over the last couple of decades. I think Senator Bishop's idea is an excellent idea; it should be done, provided that the privilege now enjoyed by the lawyer is stripped away from the lawyer and that the lawyer has the same status as the accountant, and not the other way around.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I start off my remarks today by congratulating Senator Watson on bringing this matter of public importance to the Senate. Senator Watson has done a great service to the Senate and the Parliament with his detailed and diligent pursuit of taxation matters over many years now, and I thought that his contribution today reflected a very deep knowledge of the whole subject of taxation.

SPEECH.PARA: I think today's debate has been a good debate with one exception, I am sorry to say, and that is that, as Senator Watson intimated in his interjection to Senator Walsh, I had hoped that Senator Walsh, with his long experience as Minister for Finance, would have addressed his mind today to the real issues of today's matter of public importance. He did address his mind towards the end, but I am afraid that most of his contribution was a rehash of the old hatreds that Senator Walsh exhibited so strongly towards certain persons years ago.

Let me put the record straight on a couple of things that Senator Walsh said. He said that the Fraser Government did not take action for very many years on tax avoidance and that, indeed, it required the reporting by Costigan and McCabe-Lafranchi for the Fraser Government to act. It may have been just a lapse of memory on Senator Walsh's part, but that is a total historical inaccuracy. The fact is that it was the Fraser Government, with John Howard as the Treasurer, that started and almost completed the legislative process which led to the smashing of the tax avoidance industry. The first Minister for Finance in the Hawke Government, Mr Dawkins-I am not sure whether he did it deliberately graciously-did acknowledge very early in the first term of the Hawke Government that the tax avoidance industry had been smashed.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Commissioner said so, too.

—Senator Michael Baume reminds us that the Commissioner of Taxation at the time agreed with Mr Dawkins's remarks that the tax avoidance industry was largely smashed by the time that the Hawke Government came to office. It was smashed because of the diligence of the Fraser Government and particularly the then Treasurer, John Howard.

SPEECH.PARA: Indeed, the first legislation-I am talking from memory now-to tackle the massive tax avoidance problem that had arisen in the 1970s, not because of the actions of government but because of a highly legalistic interpretation of the tax Act by the High Court of Australia, was brought in by the Fraser Government. The legislation to smash that tax avoidance industry that had built up was introduced in 1978-79, and that was three years before Costigan and McCabe-Lafranchi reported. So it is very important to set the record straight. Senator Walsh was just plain wrong today on that.

By contrast, I acknowledge the very constructive contribution of Senator McMullan to the debate, because one of the good things about the topic for discussion today is that it is not, or it certainly should not be, a party political issue. It is a matter that affects all political parties, but it also affects all Australians in an equal way. What we are saying simply is that, whilst we agree with the general thrust of the movement in the taxation administration area towards self-assessment, there are various deficiencies in the way in which that has been progressed. We have gone from one extreme in the area of tax administration and court interpretations to another.

The lack of balance that exists in the current system is very well described in a paper prepared by the Taxation Institute of Australia-it was a submission on the case of taxpayers' rights under self-assessment of income tax-and I read one of the early paragraphs of that paper, because I think it sums up an important essence of what we are talking about today:

The lack of balance under the current system arises because of the way in which the new system was grafted onto the existing legislative framework designed to permit assessment by the Australian Taxation Office. Only minimal changes of a technical nature have been enacted to give effect to the new system. These have been directed primarily at relieving the ATO of its responsibility to formally assess returns. What this means is that, existing provisions, for example, relating to penalties and to ensuring that taxpayers provide sufficient information to the ATO to enable an assessment to be made, are no longer appropriate where the responsibility for assessing taxable income has been shifted to the taxpayer. For example, applying the current penalty regime, an error in calculation by a taxpayer in an assessment, could be treated as providing the basis for the imposition of culpability penalties on a taxpayer. However, the taxpayer may have merely sought to properly discharge his or her responsibilities under the present law to the best of his or her ability.

One of the fundamental problems with the tax laws at the moment is that they are so extraordinarily complex that I believe a full understanding of the taxation laws in Australia defies the wit or knowledge of any practitioner in Australia, let alone the average Australian taxpayer who only really takes an interest in these matters when he or she has to fill in the annual return.

We have an extraordinarily complex set of laws. It is a set of laws that has been added to in the last five years to the tune of, I think I am right in saying, 800 additional pages of tax legislation-an amount that is beyond the comprehension of people to take in. That has also led to an enormous lack of certainty in taxation laws.
