When there is that uncertainty and that complexity, our view is that it is entirely wrong to put taxpayers in a self-assessment situation where a totally honest mistake can lead to culpability penalties being imposed rather than the normal sort of penalty that would apply to a much lesser inference of offence.

Until we get a change in the administration and operation of the taxation laws that we have at the moment, we are going to put more and more honest taxpayers at risk. That is what we are talking about. We are not talking about the small number of taxpayers who deliberately rort the system. We are talking about the risks that are now exposed to average taxpayers who are honest and have no intention whatsoever of attempting to do anything other than the right thing.

It is critically important for the integrity of our taxation system and the integrity of taxpayers that there be public confidence in the administration of the taxation regime in Australia. Every day a worryingly growing number of examples of a lack of confidence in the Tax Office and its administration are becoming public. Senator Watson, I think Senator Bishop and also the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan) praised the work of the Taxation Commission, Mr Boucher.

I want to make it clear that we are not in any way attacking Mr Boucher in our remarks today but what we are saying is that the laudable objectives to which he aspires can be achieved fairly and equitably only if the people who are much lower in the ranks of the Taxation Office than is Mr Boucher in his exalted position, the people who actually have to do the work, take a sympathetic and proper attitude towards their tasks. In recent times there have been several examples of an approach by the assessors to their work that I believe indicates a very dangerous trend, because it tends to cast more and more people in the role of wrongdoers. They are only trying to do the correct thing but, because of the complexity and the uncertainty of the law, they do run the risk of not always getting it 100 per cent right.

In his remarks, I think that Senator McMullan acknowledged the concerns that we have expressed about this matter today. He talked about the need for voluntary compliance as we talked about the need for voluntary compliance and there is no disagreement on that matter. He talked about the need for greater balance than now exists and we are talking about the need for greater balance. So in principle I think there has been a very healthy meeting of the minds on those very important issues. I have mentioned that the tax laws are incredibly complex. In addition, the Commissioner still has wide discretionary powers.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is inconsistent.
—As Senator Watson says, the wider the discretion of the Commissioner, the more the certainty of the law is lessened--
—It is essential under self-assessment.

—Which Senator Watson again says is essential under a self-assessment system. The situation also now exists where, over many years, a body of rulings has been given which now, in many cases, is seen to be out of line with the actual law. The rulings are being changed or differently interpreted in such a complex way that they are now increasingly out of kilter with the actual law. Some taxpayers are then in fact being penalised through having acted in accordance with a particular ruling which is subsequently changed. Because of the change, the taxpayer is then seen to be in a situation that requires penalty. In my view, that is absolutely inequitable and it flaunts the basic rule of law under which we can operate any proper system. So, that is a major problem.

SPEECH.PARA: The penalties are not appropriate in promoting effective self-assessment and the Australian Tax Institute has raised, very rightly, the concern which it has, and which I certainly share, that the hastily conceived measures that the Taxation Office put together to be rushed through the parliamentary system to meet the last year's Budget session indicate that the Taxation Office seems to regard these matters as basically settled and that all that is required is a little finetuning. We believe, as does the Taxation Institute, that much more than finetuning is required. If we are going to be fair and equitable to taxpayers and take proper account of taxpayers' rights-and the protection of taxpayers' rights is one of the fundamental points made in the wording of our matter of public importance today-as well as the equally legitimate requirement to protect revenue, much more than minor finetuning is required.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Short has said that there is a lot of agreement today between the various parties in the debate and I think that is right. There seems to be a fair amount of thunderous agreement. We really need to work out some sort of solution to the problems that arise.
—We gave it to you.

—First of all, Senator Watson, it should not be confined simply to problems associated with people who have to pay tax-we all have to do that. One aspect of this matter of public importance that surprised me was that it was confined to people who have to pay tax. The Opposition seems to say that the only people who matter in this area are people who have to pay tax. What about the similar provisions, for example, that exist under the Social Security Act. Senator Watson spoke-and I go to it-about section 263 of the Income Tax Assessment Act, but may I say that blind indifference has been shown to section 164 of the Social Security Act. It seems to me that, in a chamber such as this, if we are going to talk about--
—It might be the same principle, but it is a different subject.

—Hold on, Senator Short. Senator Watson, or it may have been Senator Bishop, spoke about the need for the culture to change. We are not going to change the culture of the country or the way we enforce our law in this nation if concerns are simply confined to taxpayers' rights. What about the social security recipients and the people who have to go before the Independent Commission Against Corruption in New South Wales? What about the National Crime Authority and all those things where, over the years, rights have been modified, if not denied? I would have thought that it was a most surprising approach that, when the Opposition speaks to I think the first matter of public importance in the new Parliament, the one thing it should come down upon when talking about civil rights-and this has much to do with civil rights-is the question of taxpayers. That is an area where, I am willing to agree, there have been intrusions on rights and where wrongs have been done to people. But concentrating simply on taxpayers is certainly a very blinkered way of looking at this whole area.

SPEECH.PARA: I think that the problem associated with what we do is more pronounced in the area of tax collection than in any other area. Opposition Senators say, for example, that they regret-and I accept that what they say is absolutely correct-what happened during the 1970s when, following Curran's case, awful things were done by people to avoid tax. The culture in those days was that it was very smart indeed to avoid tax. The situation is now different.

Senator Short said that the great change took place in the days when Mr Fraser was the Prime Minister. It is interesting that Curran's case was not overruled until John's case, which was decided in June 1988. In the context of what Senator Short says, it is interesting to note the comments in a press release by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) which states:
Special Prosecutor Roger Gyles in his 1984 report estimated that the revenue forgone because of the avoidance and evasion in the late 1970s and early 1980s ran into billions of dollars.
He described it as follows:
Tax avoidance and evasion of this kind in such volume is extraordinary in absolute terms but almost incredible in relative terms having regard to the small Australian economy.

When it is said that this is a thing of the 1970s and that the problem of collecting a proper amount of tax is a matter of the 1970s, that is wrong if we accept what Special Prosecutor Roger Gyles had to say. If we look at the year in which the Johns case was decided-the decision was given in February 1989-again that is an indication of the problem that was planted into the taxation law in the 1970s and persisted right throughout the 1980s. It was only with remedies such as the imposition of a capital gains tax, a fringe benefits tax and the substantiation provisions that the tax system was remedied. I do not think people deny even today that there are rorts that go on in the system, but certainly not as much as there was.

Because things are now better and we have been in a mood of consensus-I hope this is conceded-and we are now in a better situation brought about by the Government that is now in power, people now say, `Since the system is working properly, there is no need for it'. It is a bit like the sorts of things that are said in respect of unions. It is said, `Things are now so good, employers are now so concerned about the employee, that there is no need for laws that protect the safety of workers and there is no need for laws that protect their wages'. The fact of the matter is that as soon as those laws are removed there are terrible examples of the most fearful injuries brought about by the lack of safety, reductions in wages and so on.

It is quite clear that, unless we have effective laws, the system breaks down and what pertained before comes about again. If we did not have a solid tax law, a solid regime by which tax is collected, then the problems that arose in the 1970s and 1980s would occur again. That is not to concede the very valid points that are made that, if a system is set up that needs to be severe to correct a wrong, that severity should last for a particular time only, and that when the worst excesses are removed that severity should be modified.

The point I make is this: Too facile a solution has been offered here today, which is to the effect, `Let us remove these various procedures that have been put in place'. It is not only in Australia that we get these problems. If we look at what happened in England with the case of Inland Revenue Commissioners v. Rossminster Ltd, we see the problems that occur. In that case a judicial warrant was given before the Inland Revenue people went about the collection of documents from the particular person from Rossminster Ltd, and still the problem occurred.

I think Senator Watson made a very valid point when he said that the power resides in the Commissioner of Taxation to issue a certificate to enable his officers to go and collect documents and to investigate. What he is saying-I agree with him-is that there ought to be some sort of regulation of that. Even a judicial warrant, as was shown in the Rossminster case, does not necessarily ensure that. Indeed, I have often wondered-I might delay on this point now-how effective the giving of judicial warrants is, because the judge simply has to go on the affidavit sworn by the person applying for the warrant and there is never really a means of checking it up. I say that there should be. I would have thought that is the sort of thing members of the Opposition would have come out with today in this debate. I thought they would have pointed to something rather practical instead of simply saying, `Things are bad, let's change the law'.

The real concern in all this, the real hard ball to get, is: How do we change the law? What do we do? That is the difficulty. We do not hit the hard ball by simply concentrating on the taxation Act. We have to look at the system of issuing warrants and of allowing investigative people to collect documents. That has to be considered in an open-ended way rather than simply limiting it down to a taxation area.

To be fair to the Taxation Commissioner, it has to be said that there has been a growing need for investigative bodies to get documents and to obtain information quickly. Given the way things operate now and the technology of the times, where things are done by computer, documents can be sent rapidly, and people can leave the country quickly, there does need to be a system whereby people who are going to enforce the law can meet the modern facilities that technology gives to people who might be breaking the law. In England the Mareva injunction, which has now been adopted out here, has been developed, as has the Anton Pillar order. If we look at the general context of the problem we have here, we see that there is a need to change the law. The question is whether or not the law has been changed properly not only in respect of the taxation Act, but also in respect of the Social Security Act and other Acts such as that.

I think that this has been a useful debate. It has been a debate that has been much too limited because it has been confined to an area where people do recognise that something drastic had to be done given the erosion of the tax base in the 1970s and 1980s. I do not know how many examples have been given today-I have not counted them-but I do not think there have been very many of where the Commissioner has acted in a draconian way.

On that subject, people have called for certainty in the law. They have said, `What we ought to do is so define the law, so make the law, that nobody can but know what it is and nobody can do anything but obey it'. It just does not work that way. We have had that tried again and again. The problem always is that, no matter how we define the law in this Parliament, there will be means of getting round it. What has to be done-as has been said here today-is that a balance must be struck between the effective collection of tax and the protection afforded to the taxpayer. Everybody has recognised that, but what they have not recognised here today is that that problem is simply part of an overall problem. I keep coming back to it because I think if anybody deserved a debate in this context it was the social security recipients rather than the taxation payers, because they are the ones who have suffered more from the sorts of things that have been said here today.

It has to be remembered that, in striking the balance, the tax Act is complex because the people, including accountants and lawyers, who have acted in this area over the years have had fertile minds which have got round the various laws that were much more simple. The law is more complex because it needs to be complex. It is very interesting that people criticism the law for being complex and yet in the same breath say that the law ought to be so written that nobody could do anything but know what the law is.

The two propositions put by the Opposition are mutually contradictory. If we want something simple, we cannot have it certain. That has been shown over the years. What needs to be done, not only by the Commissioner but also by us here today, is certainly to debate it in a rational way but to remember that the quick fix solutions-and that is unfortunately what has been suggested over on the other side today--

TALK.START.PARA: —No.
—Yes. The problem has been analysed. The solutions that the other side has provided are quick fix solutions, and quick fix solutions are recipes for disaster.
—Quite the contrary.
—With great respect, Senator Short has not suggested a reasonable, viable and sensible solution to the problem that he raised. That is the real difficulty he faces today.
—Senator Bishop mentioned about 15 recommendations, for example.
—All very simple ones. That is what I am talking about.
—Order! The discussion is concluded.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON ENVIRONMENT, RECREATION AND THE ARTS

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report on environmental impact of development assistance: Government response

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the Government's response to the report of the Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts on environmental impact of development assistance and seek leave to move a motion in relation to the document.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
Motion (by Senator Tate) proposed:
That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —We, of course, have only just received the Government's response to the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts on the environmental impact of development assistance and therefore my comments today will be but preliminary. The response is appreciated because we regard the Committee's report as particularly important. We are also pleased that the Government, it seems, has chosen to accept the bulk of the Committee's recommendations.

SPEECH.PARA: Madam Acting Deputy President, the Committee's report was a ringing indictment of the Government's record in this vitally important area, and I remind you of some of the concerns it expressed. The first was the lack of assessment of the environmental impact of programs by the Government. Of 121 projects with potential environmental significance that were examined, 45 per cent had gone through the planning and design phase without consideration of environmental effects. As the Chairman of the Committee noted in his tabling speech, half of the money that was spent on 45 per cent of the projects actually went to projects with negative environmental impact.

The Committee recommended that the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau (AIDAB) address environmental aspects clearly from the first stage of the planning cycle-that is, project identification-and conduct environmental impact assessments for aid projects. I am glad to note that the Government has accepted this recommendation.

A second concern was the ability of AIDAB to monitor and assess the environmental impact of its projects. That ability was expressed by the Committee to be inadequate. AIDAB did not have personnel to review the environmental impact of aid projects, and that is not surprising as nobody assessed the environmental impact of projects at the planning stage. I note that the Government has also accepted this recommendation. However, although it has set up an environmental group within the Appraisal, Evaluation and Sectoral Studies Branch, the staffing, I regret, does not quite measure up to the Committee's recommendation as the minimum need.

The Committee envisaged that six professional staff would be necessary in this area. As I understand the position, the Government has only three professional staff yet working. It remains to be seen whether these officers will in fact be full time on environmental matters but certainly at least the sentiment of the Government within its response today, that is, that it accepts the spirit of the recommendation, is something that we are pleased to note.

The third area of concern expressed in the Committee's report that I wanted to mention was its concern about the program of aid for environmental projects. The Committee recommended that a much more significant program of aid for environmental projects should be developed by the Australian Government. The Committee's observation makes mockery of the Government's claims regarding its achievements on the environment. The Government, as you would be aware, Madam Acting Deputy President, has made much of its environment assistance program. Yet if one looks at the fine print of that program one finds that the budget is only $20m over four years. The 4.1 per cent allocated in the year 1989-90 is of course a minuscule proportion of this country's total aid budget. It is interesting to note the reaction of the Australian Council for Overseas Aid, which is the peak body of the non-governmental aid organisations. As it said in its letter to Senator Evans on 3 May:

Statements that 30% or more of country programme funds are for environmentally related projects must be recognised for what they are-a smokescreen to cover the fact that very few of the projects funded under Australia's bilateral aid programme have been specifically designed to enhance protection of the environment or to alleviate environmental degradation.

Although the Government says that the Committee's recommendation is `accepted within the context of the Government's overall resource constraints', only a very small proportion of Australia's aid budget goes to environmental projects and one must regard somewhat cynically the claims that were made by the Government in the last election campaign that a great deal would be achieved by the environment assistance program when that is analysed and seen to be such a small program.

A fourth area of concern raised by the Committee concerned multilateral organisations, and the Committee recommended a much closer monitoring of the environmental impact of programs carried out. Although the Government has indicated that it concurs with this view it has not set out the measures that would be taken to put this commitment into practice. There is no mention at all, for example, of how it would monitor World Bank programs as they affect the environment. We urge the Government to address this important area.

The Committee made a number of other worthwhile suggestions which we are pleased to see that the Government has accepted. I hope they will be implemented speedily. Among a few of those that we consider to be more important, I mention AIDAB's obligation under the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974-75 to make it legally binding by having such obligations spelled out in a memorandum of understanding with the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. The Committee criticised the lack of a memorandum of understanding, given that the former Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment advised four years ago that such a memorandum of understanding would be negotiated with AIDAB.

The Government also accepted the Committee's recommendation that disbursements made through non-government organisations be assessed for environmental soundness, and that is something that we also support.

In summary, the Committee has certainly made a worthwhile contribution in this important area, particularly in translating policy into practical application. We are pleased that the Government has picked up and accepted a number of the Committee's recommendations. I have demonstrated a few areas in which deficiencies still exist and we urge the Government to address those deficiencies as a matter of some urgency.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to address a few remarks to the Government's response to the report on the environmental impact of development assistance by the Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts. I refer in particular to part (c) of the Government's response entitled `Accepted subject to the availability of resources and/or development of appropriate institutional arrangements'.

SPEECH.PARA: In the context of the United Nations recommended level of development aid, Australia is not performing particularly well and, in the light of that, there is considerable scope for increasing the overall level of aid which Australia gives. The particular constraints to which attention is drawn in this section are usually economic constraints and this is precisely the area in which I would suggest that the Government could move much more forcefully in increasing our aid. Recommendation 4.32 states:
The Committee recommends that a much more significant program of aid for environmental projects should be developed by the Australian Government.

In this connection, I think it is significant that right at this time a conference on the global environment is being held in Bergen, Norway. That conference is a follow-up to the Brundtland Commission report entitled Our Common Future. Newspaper reports in recent days have indicated that the United Kingdom and the United States of America in particular have not accepted the recommendations from a number of other countries that the developed world needs to assist the underdeveloped world specifically in environmental areas which are of global significance. Attention has been drawn there both to greenhouse and ozone depletion.

In this respect, it is worth remembering that Australia is the third worst country on a per capita basis in regard to greenhouse damage and that, as regards ozone depletion, it is the worst offender in the world on a per capita basis. So not only do we need to direct attention to changing our own technology here but also it would seem to me that, having done so, this is very much an area in respect of which we would be able to and should assist other countries to follow down that road which we will hopefully map out.

About 18 months ago I went to China to address an environmental conference in Beijing. The principal reason for my going was that China, which has 60 times our population, used at that stage only about 50 per cent more chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs) than does Australia. It does not require a great deal of imagination to see what would happen to the stratospheric ozone if a country with a population 60 times the size of ours increased its per capita consumption of CFCs by a factor of 40.

It is particularly distressing to find that at the current conference the United States and the United Kingdom in particular are apparently turning their backs quite deliberately on the proposal that they should develop a new and alternative technology and then help less developed countries to adopt that technology.

I would hope that the response by the Government to recommendation 4.32 does not presage that Australia will follow down that same road but that, on the contrary, will move much more positively into this area to increase foreign aid, specifically in relation to this recommendation, in those areas where considerable global environmental damage is being caused.

The other point that I want to pick up is in relation to recommendation 4.34 in part (d) of the Government's response headed `Partially Accepted'. Recommendation 4.34 relates to the World Bank, of which, of course, Australia is a member. The recommendation is that Australia's representation on the World Bank board and at the Asian Development Bank should pass from the Treasury to Foreign Affairs and Trade and that Australian nominees for executive directors should be Australian International Development Assistance Bureau officers.

I draw attention here to the fact that historically the record of the World Bank in relation to very many of its fundings of so-called development projects has been absolutely disastrous. Indeed, the World Bank was quite heavily involved in assistance to Indonesia in its trans-migration program which involved the movement of people from heavily populated Java into what Indonesia chooses to call West Irian. That not only had quite disastrous cultural consequences for the people of West Irian but also proved to be environmentally disastrous as a result of the clearing of tropical rain forests. Ultimately it proved to be economically disastrous in terms of the attempts to establish settled agriculture in cleared tropical rain forest areas.

I guess it is worth saying here in the context of the threats which have been mentioned in several programs recently in relation to Indonesians wanting to settle in north Australia that my understanding is that the movement of people from West Irian back to Java now exceeds the movement of people from Java to West Irian as a consequence of the failure of those programs.

As recently as the middle of last year the World Bank appointed Herman Daly, a former professor of economics at Louisiana State University, an economist par excellence who has pursued sustainable steady state economics. Indeed, in 1971, I think it was, he edited a book called Toward the Steady State. He has continued to publish extensively in this area on sustainable economics. Herman Daly was appointed as a senior economic adviser to the World Bank. One would hope that, as a consequence of this and various other moves made by the World Bank, the World Bank will move away from the conventional economically predicated view of development towards a more environmentally sympathetic development view.

The Committee's recommendation in this respect, based on that same sort of consideration, was that our representation on the World Bank should pass from the Treasury-in other words, from the tight and narrow economic consideration towards one which takes a much broader perspective. It is therefore disappointing to find that the Government is not accepting this recommendation. The Government specifically says that successful candidates for Australia's representation on the World Bank board will be selected on merit by the Treasurer, admittedly in consultation with the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade.

I will not detain the Senate for much longer. However, I find that recommendation also rather distressing. One would hope that a body as important and with as much money to spend globally as the World Bank should be influenced more strongly towards a wider range of considerations, specifically consideration of the environment, in the sorts of development proposals which are put before it and which it considers desirable to fund.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am speaking on behalf of numerous concerned community groups in relation to the Government's response to the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts on the environmental impact of development assistance. These groups have identified a number of areas in the key Senate Committee recommendations which they believe the Government must deal with. The approach to these recommendations should be taken as a benchmark of the Government's commitment to real change in the aid program.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn firstly to the section dealing with Australian aid for the environment in paragraph 2.11. The Senate Committee has recommended that a much more significant program of aid for environmental projects should be developed by the Australian Government. The current level of funding under the environment assistance program was only $4.1m in 1989 or 0.36 per cent of the aid budget for that year. This is less than one-twelfth of the $93m spent on assisting Australian companies to obtain contracts overseas. So in proportion to that effort, it is not a substantial amount. Statements that 30 per cent or more of the country program funds are for environmentally related projects must be recognised for what they are, a smokescreen to cover the fact that very few of the projects funded under Australia's bilateral aid program have been specifically designed to enhance protection of the environment or to alleviate environmental degradation. It is also very wrong to suggest that the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau (AIDAB) is facing a choice between increasing the level of aid for the environment and seeking to ensure that no aid project has adverse environmental effects. These are not mutually exclusive objectives. Additional funding must be provided so that AIDAB is not forced to make such difficult choices.

The Australian Government's response must set targets for the percentage of the total aid budget that will be allocated to the environment assistance program-for example 2.5 per cent in 1990-91, up to 5 per cent by 1992-93, and 10 per cent by 1995-96. The increased funding for aid for the environment should not be at the expense of AIDAB's general sustainable development aid program. This will require an increase in the level of aid, cuts in programs such as DIFF, the Development Import Finance Faculty, which I have heard referred to as the program which assists Australian business enterprises to find contracts overseas, or a mix of these measures. It should not result in a cut in the important areas where the aid budget is already devoted to environment programs.

Secondly, in the area of multilateral organisations, paragraph 4.22 of the Senate report, the Committee recommended close monitoring of the environmental impact of Australian funding for multilateral organisations such as the United Nations Development Program and the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA), without specifying exactly what steps need to be taken. The Australian Government response must explicitly detail the measures that will be taken to implement this commitment. Of course, there is a very big question mark over an agency such as IAEA. It is a case of the nuclear industry monitoring itself. There are not enough checks and balances in that system. And, of course, there is inadequate funding, which is why the Australian Government has been asked to increase, or should consider increasing, the amount of finance available to IAEA but ensuring that it is not a case of the police policing themselves.

The next area of concern is environmental legislation in developing countries. The Senate Committee recommended that Australia provide assistance in drafting environmental legislation. There is a serious lack of such legislation in Fiji, Tonga, the Solomon Islands and Vanuatu-all Australian aid partners-according to a November 1989 AIDAB sponsored workshop on environmental assessment for development planning. It is not enough for Australia to continue to say that we are not providing assistance because we have not been asked by the central finance or planning ministry of the countries concerned. It is hardly likely that the Australian Treasury, if it had been asked about Australia's development requirements in the 1960s or early 1970s, would have placed the lack of such legislation high on Australia's priority list.

It is a case where the Australian Government really needs to take the initiative. Australia should provide funds through an organisation such as the International Union for the Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources, which is specifically earmarked for this purpose. It is likely that there will then be considerable interest from the recipient countries. It is a case of Australia generating the ideas rather then writing for the specific requests to come forward.

The next area of concern to non-government organisations (NGOs) involved in the aid area is that of the memorandum of understanding (MOU), referred to in paragraph 6.43 of the Senate Committee's report. It is essential that AIDAB's legally binding obligations under the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act be clearly spelled out in a memorandum of understanding and not just letters of agreement, as the Government's response indicates. The memorandum of understanding must do certain things. I will outline four things which an MOU must do. Firstly, it must require environmental assessment of all environmentally significant projects, regardless of cost, location or nature. Suggestions that all projects less than $5m in value should be exempted from environmental assessment must be rejected. One hundred and ninety-eight out of the 258 projects funded by AIDAB over the years 1987-1989 fell into this category, including the Australia-Malaysia and Australia-Indonesia nuclear technical assistance program, about which many NGOs have grave doubts. All projects should be subject to an MOU.

Secondly, the MOU should contain a list of categories of projects that should be considered to be environmentally significant unless the contrary is established. This is a similar procedure to that adopted under the New South Wales Environmental Planning and Assessment Act. The list could include hydro-electric or irrigation dams, power stations, mines, irrigation schemes, heavy industry, commercial logging in natural forests, commercial fishing operations and the undertaking of preliminary investigations or the supply of equipment or expertise for such projects.

There is a third area that must be included. There should be clarification that, if an environmentally significant project proposal is referred to the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (DASETT) and the Minister decides that an environmental impact statement (EIS) is warranted, any such environmental impact statement will be released for public comment in Australia, even though it applies to an overseas situation.

Fourthly, the MOU must require that, in assessing whether a proposed project is environmentally significant and whether an EIS indicates an unacceptable level of environmental impact, AIDAB shall take into account such information as is available to it on the views of people in the recipient country. It should not be acceptable for Australia to ignore the existence of widely publicised and well-supported public concern in another country when making a decision about aid to that country. In other words, they should go beyond governments to get information from the public in the recipient countries and particularly the NGOs in the recipient countries, which, after all, are in a very good position to make their views known and their claims on any aid projects.

The next area of concern to NGOs in this country relates to the NGO advisory body. The Senate Committee explicitly stated that a formal body to incorporate NGO advice into the planning cycle should be established. The need for such a body is now urgent. The time is past when Australia's aid program can avoid close scrutiny. Unless provision is made for NGO participation in decision forming processes, the program may be placed at risk by ill-informed criticism. It is not acceptable to suggest that existing structures are a surrogate for the new body the Senate Committee recommends. The role of the AIDAB-NGO committee for development cooperation is clearly confined to matters relating to activities of NGOs and does not extend to include reviewing the suitability of proposed bilateral aid projects. In other words, the government to government projects are outside the terms of reference of the present informal structure. Furthermore, the committee has no representation whatsoever from environment or conservation NGOs. That is an area which we believe should be rectified immediately.

The Australian Council for Overseas Aid suggests that the proposed NGO consultative committee on Australian overseas aid contain three representatives of development NGOs and three representatives of environment NGOs. It should be chaired by a deputy director-general. DASETT and Treasury should have observer status on that consultative committees.

The next area of concern is that of training, as outlined under paragraph 8.14 of the Senate report. AIDAB is currently planning to train its staff in environmental assessment. This is a welcome initiative. However, the Senate Committee's recommendation went much further, in recommending that the training program extend to providing staff with skills in `developing environmental awareness . . . in relation to developing countries'. It is not only important that training cover both positive action to enhance the environment and measures to prevent further degradation of that environment; it is also vital that both staff and consultants be trained. As most of the project design work is undertaken by consultants, it is essential that they be sympathetic to environment objectives and fully aware of government policy and legislative requirements in this area. AIDAB should make the completion of a training course in environmental awareness and assessment a prerequisite for the engagement of a consultant.

The environment unit, which is referred to in paragraph 8.20, is also of concern. The Senate Committee called for the establishment of an environment unit with six full-time, experienced professional staff working primarily on environmental assessment and related matters. There are currently only three professional staff in the relevant section, with one position vacant and recently advertised. Of the three incumbent staff, only two have formal qualifications in environmental science, and only one is an experienced AIDAB staff member. Given the policy workload on these staff, it is unlikely that any of these staff would have much time available to undertake a significant amount of environmental assessment work. The extra personnel are urgently needed. The Government's response should include a commitment to establishing an environment unit with six environmental specialists, by the end of 1990 at the very latest.

I refer to comments made about the Brundtland report. The Senate Committee called for AIDAB, the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade and DASETT to jointly review the implications of the Brundtland report for Australia's international relationships. The Brundtland report has far-reaching implications for Australian trade policy, the regulation of overseas investment by Australian corporations, the negotiation of international treaties and international cooperation in a wide range of areas, including through the provision of official development assessment.

It would be totally unacceptable if this recommendation were to be watered down to a review of the implications of the Brundtland report for AIDAB. Given that the Brundtland report is directed at protection of the global environment, while simultaneously meeting the development needs of poorer countries, it would seem appropriate for both DASETT and AIDAB to have major roles in the task of reviewing the implications of Brundtland for Australian Government policy.

The annual environment audit, referred to in paragraph 9.14, is another area of concern. The Committee's proposal for the preparation of a detailed annual environmental audit of Australian overseas aid projects is strongly supported. This audit should be made publicly available within 14 days of its submission to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Again, the NGOs are stressing the importance of public consultation and public information, which is the hallmark of democratic decision-making. It is not much good if a detailed audit is made available to the Minister but then sits gathering dust on the Minister's desk and never sees the light of day.

The International Fund for Agricultural Development (IFAD) also needs some clarification. The Senate Committee recommended that the Government give immediate consideration to a further increase in funding for IFAD. To the Government's credit, it has already acted on this recommendation. However, whilst the additional $500,000 for IFAD announced by the Minister for Foreign Affairs in March this year was most welcome, and came as a result of community lobbying from around Australia, it really is only a drop in the bucket compared to the $64.3m funding provided to the mainstream institutions-for example, the World Bank and the Asian Development Bank. Australian contributions to IFAD have historically lagged well behind those of countries such as Norway, Canada and Sweden. In the most recent year for which comparative data are available, Australia's total contributions to the World Bank were 139 times larger than its contribution to IFAD. The equivalent ratios for other countries were Sweden 73 times, Norway 48 times, and New Zealand 29 times. The Government should therefore announce a program for progressive increases in the level of funding for IFAD, especially in relation to funding for other international agencies, such as the World Bank. I shall say more on that later.

The next area of concern is that of advice to Australia's executive directors on the multilateral development banks, which is referred to in paragraph 12.9. The Senate Committee called for transfer of the governorship of the multilateral development banks and face to face meetings between DASETT, Treasury and AIDAB officers prior to the preparation of any advice for Australia's executive directors. In this they were echoing the views expressed by the Joint Parliamentary Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence, when the latter body said:

A proper Australian position on the Bank approach to structural adjustment, Third World debt, or the impact of aid on the environment cannot be achieved by the current resort to telephone calls or faxes.

In other words, there needs to be greater community consultation here and that consultation should go far beyond the Department of Treasury. Two all-party parliamentary committees have now clearly stated that the multilateral development banks are first and foremost development institutions, and should thus come under the authority of the Minister with responsibility for development assistance-that is, the Minister for Foreign Affairs. The Senate Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts did this in full knowledge of the early December Cabinet decision not to act on the Joint Committee's recommendation. This suggests a need to give serious consideration to its proposals. Face to face meetings between the responsible officers should be instituted immediately pending a review of last year's Cabinet decision on the governorship of the banks.

Next, I come to a review of Australia's involvement in multilateral development banks. The Senate Committee called for a thorough review of all aspects of Australia's participation in the multilateral development banks to be undertaken by AIDAB, DASETT and the Department of Foreign Affairs. This proposal is of the utmost importance. ACFOA, among many other community groups-and, of course, ACFOA is an umbrella for many of those community groups to which I am referring-would add that the review must extend to include the role of NGOs as well in the International Monetary Fund; the review must involve an opportunity for public input and the final report of the review must be publicly available. Scrutiny of our foreign aid and development issues is very important indeed.

There is an increasing body of opinion in the Australian community that is very concerned about how our foreign aid money is spent and that in relation to other areas of budget it should be increased. Any suggestions that this review could be undertaken by Treasury officials would quite understandably be viewed as unrealistic. Treasury officers undertaking an internal review of their own work can hardly be expected to adopt a truly independent approach. We need to get away from the economic rationalist approach as the only approach to Australia's contribution to international funding of development issues overseas. This is where that narrow tunnel-vision approach is inappropriate. If Australia's aid is to be effective, as most NGOs involved in this area would want it to be, it will seek to help people at the grass roots and will be responsive to the calls from NGOs in other countries. Only by involving the community in Australia and by listening to NGOs in the countries that we are seeking to assist will we get a sensible expenditure of Australian taxpayers' dollars in the foreign aid development area.

On 18 August 1989 the following matter was referred to the Committee of Privileges:

Whether there was an unauthorised disclosure of the report of the Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade on visiting nuclear powered or armed vessels, and whether a contempt was committed by a person who made such an unauthorised disclosure.

One member of the Standing Committee, Senator Irina Dunn, advised the Committee of Privileges that she had orally briefed media representatives about the report, which also included her dissenting report, on the day on which the report was due to be tabled. As indicated at paragraphs 22 to 24, these included the unexpected delays which occurred in the tabling of the report, and the declaration by Senator Dunn that she did not intend to obstruct the Committee or the Senate, as evidenced by her not taking advantage of opportunities to do so at any time throughout the inquiry. In particular, the Committee draws attention to Senator Dunn's apology, quoted at paragraph 23 of this report, and reminds the Senate that, in similar circumstances some years ago, when a comparable apology was made, the Senate took the matter no further.

The Committee has therefore made the following findings in relation to the matter referred to it: Firstly, the Committee has concluded that, while it is open to the Committee and the Senate to find that a contempt has been committed, in the light of all the circumstances as outlined above such a finding should not be made. The Committee has also taken the opportunity to address a number of other matters arising from its consideration of this reference. The reason for that is that nearly all these resolutions or orders have had the effect of curbing the power of the Executive in relation to the legitimate exercise of the functions of the Senate as a chamber and all of them have been an attempt to redress the balance between the Executive and the legislature.
—So how long should they last?

—The answer to Senator Coates's question is that they should last at least as long as we have a government like his, which is determined to do whatever it can, whenever it can, to devalue the Parliament as an institution. That is how long they should last. They should last as long as it is necessary that the House of Parliament elected by the people, or as the Senate, in its representative capacity, has to fight continually against the attempts of the Australian Labor Party to turn the parliamentary institution into another arm of the Caucus, the Australian Council of Trade Unions, or the Labor Party machine in which the rights of individuals or members of parliament are constantly jeopardised by the numbers in the machine.

SPEECH.PARA: Nearly all these resolutions relate to matters of accountability of statutory bodies, the consideration of annual reports, the requirement that Ministers answer questions by a specific time, or at least provide to the Senate information why they should not answer questions by a specific time, why questions on notice continue not to be answered by the Executive, why there needs to be some capacity within the Parliament to ensure that an input to the questions of appropriation and staffing are in fact taken on board and not simply at the fiat or whim of the Minister for Finance of the day, particularly when we have Ministers for Finance who consistently attempt to use the power of the purse to prevent the executive Government being placed under the proper degree of scrutiny which the Parliament ought to impose on them.

This was the same nub of the debate we had earlier today about the powers of the Commissioner of Taxation. We know full well that the Labor Party's approach in these matters is to take any opportunity that arises to devalue the rights of individuals vis-a-vis the rights of the State or the Parliament vis-a-vis the Executive. That is the very nature, the very essence, the very raison d'etre of the Australian Labor Party. As far as questions relating to responses by the Government to parliamentary committee reports are concerned, of course we understand why it is that the Labor Party would not want any discipline imposed on the Government to respond to parliamentary committee reports so that they can--

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government's record on this has outdone yours.

—In terms of responding to parliamentary committee reports, the Government's record has got better only to the extent that the Senate has been prepared to put in place mechanisms to demand that degree of the accountability and to take necessary action when that accountability was not met. That is why the Senate has these continuing orders and resolutions which have been usefully gathered together in the same book as the Standing Orders. There are even, I might say, questions dealing with, for example, retrospectivity in taxation legislation. Of course, one can understand why Senator Coates would want to say, `Of course, the Treasurer announced something on some day in some press release.' The areas which, as I say, are covered in these resolutions and orders of the Senate of continuing effect do not simply deal with mechanical matters or procedural matters; they are properly the questions of the Standing Orders, but they do, in fact, go to all the sort of things I have indicated, including the establishment of the Senate Standing Committee on Appropriations and Staffing.

SPEECH.PARA: The proper work which that Committee has done-frustrated as it has been by the decisions of Caucus so that people from the Labor Party on the Committee have not been able to exercise a judgment on the merits of the matter, but simply on the basis of the decision which they have been told to go forward and peddle in the Committee-is of some considerable importance.

Therefore let me make it quite clear that the view which the Opposition takes about these matters is that, so long as we have an executive government which treats the Parliament with the contempt which this executive Government has shown for the Parliament, the resolutions and orders of the Senate should have continuing effect indefinitely.

Twenty-three senators are no longer here. That being the case, how can we say that those who accepted the original resolution are representatives of this Senate?

This situation will be even more marked after 30 June when we have further departures from the departures from the chamber. As for Senator Crichton-Browne's being concerned about this particular resolution in relation to the Parliamentary Information Systems Office, I think that he is well off the mark. The resolution referred to parliamentary departments. It says:
That the Senate declares that no changes in the structure or responsibilities of the Parliamentary Departments should be made until--
(a) particulars of proposed changes have been provided to all Senators;
(b) the Standing Committee on Appropriations and Staffing has examined the proposed changes and reported to the Senate; and

As Senator Coates mentioned earlier, that particular resolution was passed with the background of the possibility of the parliamentary departments being amalgamated or re-formed in some particular way. When we look at PISO we are looking not at a parliamentary department, but at an office within one of the parliamentary departments and it has just been relocated from a place in a parliamentary department to a place in another parliamentary department.

Even if the resolution is still valid-a view which I dispute strongly-it is quite irrelevant to PISO's move. PISO was moved by the Presiding Officers. I am not quite sure whether the Speaker is involved or whether he has to take note of a Senate resolution-if it is still valid-and I do not believe it is valid.

TALK.START.PARA: —He wasn't even advised about the resolution.

—As Senator Coates says, the Speaker was not even advised of the resolution. It would be quite ludicrous for the Speaker to have to take account of a Senate resolution, just as it would be quite ludicrous if the House of Representatives passed some resolution and our President had to adhere to that.

SPEECH.PARA: In summary, I just mention certain points. Firstly, I think it would be kind of Senator Crichton-Browne to acknowledge the fact that that part was put in the thirteenth report so that we would not have to have a minority report, but it does not indicate the support of those who did accept the thirteenth report for the resolution. Secondly, I do not believe that that resolution is any longer valid unless we actually move it in this place and accept it once more. Finally, the move of PISO from one parliamentary department to another-even if that resolution were valid, which I totally dispute-is not relevant to the resolution.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sheil Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a member of the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs, I welcome the report on the accommodation of people with disabilities. I compliment the Chairman on her handling of the Committee. It was a busy committee, which did a lot of work, and she handled it with a certain delicate sensitivity which was appreciated by all of us.

SPEECH.PARA: I draw the attention of honourable senators to the report because I am sure it will have an enormous impact on their lives and their future electoral work with their constituents. The report contains the most momentous upheaval in the management of people with disabilities that we have ever known. I welcome that change. It will mean a complete dismantling of most of the institutions that have looked after these people for many years, the return of people with disabilities to the community and assistance being provided to them in the community setting.

The history is important, because the changes have been occurring over the past 10 or so years. The changes emanated from a conference held in Europe, which was attended by people from Australia, when it was mooted that the accommodation in institutions of people with disabilities was really doing them a disservice and that they could regain their self-pride and self-image if they were given the opportunity to take part in ordinary communal life.

Immediately upon the return of delegates from that conference, the Minister at the time, former senator Don Grimes, instituted an inquiry and widely consulted people with disabilities. Unfortunately, at that time he did not extend that inquiry to include the people providing service to people with disabilities in institutions, and they felt left out.

The Disability Services Act arose from the Minister's consultations with the patients. Nobody could quibble with the principles and objectives of the Act. The dissenting report-by me, Senator Walters and Senator Knowles-does not quibble with the Act, but with the fact that there are no regulations to the Act, which is being administered by flexible guidelines. This has thrown the industry into consternation, as it is being asked to disband itself and send disabled people back into the community.

We are not arguing with that; all we are arguing about is the fact that there are no regulations to administer the Act. Similar situations have arisen and were discussed in the Senate today, in the matter of public importance relating to the administration of taxation legislation, and in relation to the Therapeutic Goods Act, the regulations of which were thrown out today.

Nobody could dissent from the sentiments of the aims and objectives of the Therapeutic Goods Act. We dissented from the fact that there were no proper regulations for the Act, which would not come into effect until the regulations were accepted by the Senate and the House. The Senate threw out those regulations today because they were completely impracticable. Similarly, the Disability Services Act does not have regulations by which the administration can be brought into a sensible order.

The sorts of institutions that are being asked to disband themselves and to return the people with disabilities to the community are all nursing home institutions, except perhaps for aged care centres, cerebral palsy centres, crippled children's centres, multiple handicapped centres such as Multicap Meadows, and centres for the intellectually handicapped.

Over many years the Government fostered the development of these institutions. It subsidised them heavily, licensed them and insisted on proper standards for them. People developed a lot of expertise in many areas of looking after people with disabilities. One can understand their consternation when all of a sudden they were told that they were no longer wanted and their institutions had to be sold to provide the money for the sorts of services that the Government thought should be provided.

The centres had been attempting to concentrate their services so as to give a better service to people with disabilities. I am thinking particularly of the cerebral palsy centres, which had admission facilities for parents to stay with their children while they were accepted into the institution, training facilities, medical aids, special transport arrangements, schools and half-way houses for those who were thought to be capable of getting back into the community. The centres were asked to sell up and provide services of a completely different nature.

The mechanism that the Government used was that the centres would no longer qualify for funding if they did not do what the Government said-sell up and move their patients into the community. Unfortunately, it has taken a long time to explain to the institutions that what is proposed is a better, more progressive and more enlightened system, but we are in a transition phase that has really left them querulous.

Now the situation is that the centres have to put a plan to the Government of how they will attempt to accommodate the Government's requirements. If this is acceptable to the Government, by 1992 the centres are expected to have transferred all their patients from the institutions into the community.

Just reclassifying the homes and reclassifying the patients will not solve the problem. If the patients are to be moved into houses that accommodate no more than three or four people, many staff and a lot of support will be needed for those people to be able to manage in the community.

The Government feels confident that the costs of doing this will be about half the cost of accommodating people in institutions. I think that is an overconfident estimate, because, in the classification of patients, the degree and type of disability are not matters of consequence. People with even the most severe disabilities can be accommodated in small houses, provided there is enough help and the Government will pay for that help. If that can be done for half the cost of what it costs now, I will be very surprised, but I would be happy to be surprised, because I am sure that the system that is coming in is a lot better for the patients than the one we had in the past. What I am quarrelling about is the way it has been brought in, because it has caused so much consternation to the industry.

We will uncover a big well of disabled people in Australia who are now being looked after at home, but who will want services provided under the Disability Services Act, which will increase the costs. Without saying any more about it, I draw attention to that.

I draw attention also to the number of people with head injuries who will appear because of the road toll and will qualify under the Disability Services Act. They number in the thousands. Victoria alone had 2,500. We have uncovered the fact that psychiatric disabilities were not covered by the Commonwealth Government, and we have drawn attention to that in the Act. Those affected were always looked after by the States, and they now really should qualify under the Disability Services Act.
I welcome the report and I hope we can act on it. I hope that costs are able to be contained by the Government and that we deliver a better service to people with disabilities.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very proud to have been a member of the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs, which produced the report before us now entitled Accommodation for People with Disabilities. The Committee was asked to address itself to four specific terms of reference with regard to the implementation of the Disability Services Act 1986 in the area of accommodation for people with disabilities. Concern had been expressed that some people with disabilities-not patients, as was mentioned by Senator Sheil, but people with disabilities, particularly those who are profoundly intellectually disabled-could not live satisfactorily in the community; that the new system of independently styled living in small group homes would cost a great deal more than living in institutions such as nursing homes; that there might be insufficient care available for these people; and, finally, that a less restrictive living environment might prove to have more disadvantages than benefits.

SPEECH.PARA: In short, the concern was not with the principles of the Act, which are supported by all political parties, but rather with the implementation of those principles. The principles of the Act are very clearly set out in the report on page 103. In short, those principles espouse that people with disabilities should be accorded basic human rights of dignity, choice, the ability to achieve as reasonable a quality of life as is possible, and to participate in decisions which affect their lives.
With regard to the four concerns, the report states:
The Committee has found that people with intellectual disability have been proven to be able to live in the community in a range of accommodation options, provided sufficient support is available.
Indeed, I take the point here which Senator Sheil made: that it is vital that that support is available, otherwise this simply will not work.

Along with other members of the Committee I saw many examples of such people living relatively independent lives in small homes. For the most part these homes contained three or four people. Some of the houses had to have some minor structural alterations for purposes such as to accommodate a wheelchair going through a doorway; in some cases, bathroom facilities had to be adjusted. In some of these smaller homes the carer lived in; in others the carer had to be there for a few hours in the morning and again in the evening. In some cases additional care was necessary.

I saw people with intellectual and physical disabilities who had spent years of their lives, indeed, in some cases all of their lives, in institutions, successfully making a go of living independently in such homes. I think of one case of a 40-year-old woman, a cerebral palsy sufferer, who had lived all of her life in an institution. She was living with great delight in a home with three younger women, one of whom had just celebrated her twenty-first birthday party with great gusto. In another State I saw a home which contained four intellectually disabled men. They also had lived all of their lives in an institution and, again, were making a successful go of it in a group home where they had a carer who lived in.

With regard to the funding, the Committee could not report conclusively on that score. Certainly the transitional stage is proving expensive; nonetheless the Committee felt that once the transitional phase was through, then it would not be more expensive but we were given information which led us to believe that it would cost less finally.

The Committee found that people living in the community had access to a greater range of services than those living in institutions who, by definition, had access for the most part only to services which could be provided by those institutions.

Finally, the Committee concluded that people with disabilities are advantaged by a move to a less restrictive living environment. If there is the possibility of disadvantages these can usually be overcome by adequate preparation and training where necessary before the move is made. In fact, most of the people who moved from institutions to an independent form of living were given training in independent living. Of course, living independently was felt to be the best possible training for that.

There is no doubt that the Disability Services Act is a brave move which requires courage from everybody concerned, including the community at large. Just as caring institutionalisation was seen to be a brave move some years ago, now times have changed. Society has changed and we have moved from a position of, first, a non-acceptance of disabilities to one of acceptance; we moved to care and protection of people with disabilities; and now we have moved to a position of encouragement of fulfilment for people with disabilities in order for them to lead lives of greater independence.

By necessity some parents find themselves in a state of anxiety and, as I said, very understandably so especially when these parents are ageing and they see their adult children moving from a caring, protective institution to a form of life in which they will have greater independence. Naturally enough, these parents are concerned about their adult children.

I believe that it was a very good thing that the Committee carried out its inquiry. We did uncover examples of insensitive communication from the Federal Government Department concerned to institutions which had caused a great deal of misapprehension. I felt that the Committee was able, in some way, to assist in that circumstance although there continues to be a great deal of anxiety out in the community. We have found that some institutions had already moved on a voluntary basis towards the changes mooted by the Disability Services Act and those that had done so were extremely successful. Other institutions are seeking to do that, and I believe that in some cases they may need a little more time than the Act allows because it really will not work at all if the carers of people with disabilities feel that they are forced to make these changes. We saw frequent examples of where, initially, the carers in institutions and the parents of the people with disabilities did not want to make the changes, but, having seen those changes successfully made by others, could not wait to have the changes made for the people for whom they cared.

In conclusion-because time is running out-it is up to the States to assist very much in this process. The Commonwealth will rely on States for housing and transport considerations. The story was the same from all the States. They realised that they would have to make a contribution, but the States have suggested that the Commonwealth should put more money in their direction for the application of this Act.

We found that there is some flexibility. In fact, the Department of Community Services and Health informed the Committee that the Disability Services Act is flexible enough to enable those who, after informed choice, choose to remain in their present type of accommodation to do so. I think that statement in itself will set to rest many of the anxieties which are held about the Disability Services Act. It may well be that regulations should be produced. I feel it is better that these regulations be produced at a later stage rather than earlier, because it is by the very application of the Act itself that I think we can see what needs to be done.
I commend the report and a reading of the conclusions and the recommendations of the Committee.
