SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the first report of the Australian Horticultural Corporation (AHC), which was established under the provisions of the Australian Horticultural Corporation Act 1987. Australian listed companies have five months in which to get their reports to shareholders but it has taken until May 1990 for this report to be tabled in both the Senate and the House of Representatives. If this were a corporation listed on the Stock Exchange, of course, this would be far too long a period because, although the report is dated November 1989, it should have been in our hands much earlier. After all, the Parliament was sitting.

SPEECH.PARA: Section 8 of the Act says that the functions of the Corporation are to encourage, assist, facilitate, promote and coordinate the marketing and sales of horticultural products. The principal products dealt with by the Corporation are apples, pears and citrus fruits.

Recently in Tasmania the media have drawn the public's attention to a crisis in the Tasmanian apple orchards. Some orchardists were having to dump large quantities of apples due to a reduced Australian demand for juicing apples. It is claimed that the Australian juice concentrate manufacturers were not buying locally because of the availability of a Chilean product at $1.40 a litre compared with $2.50 for Australian grown juicing apples.

Tasmanian producers were not involved in these sorts of overseas purchases but the total demand for Australian juice was reduced as a result of this product. The information that Chilean apples may well have been treated with the chemical alar has been publicised, so some manufacturers may move their preference back in favour of the Tasmanian brand or the local product.

However, in following this matter up, it was apparent that local growers hold the Australian Horticultural Corporation, rightly or wrongly, responsible for the present lack of a local market. They thought it was the responsibility of the Corporation to prevent the Chilean product from being dumped in Australia. This, in fact, was not the case. However, the fact that Tasmanian growers vented their frustration at the Corporation is symptomatic of their basic disregard for the Corporation.

Before the Corporation was formed the Tasmanian branch of the Apple and Pear Growers Association voted at a national apple and pear growers meeting against affiliation with the AHC. They were outvoted by other States on that occasion. However, during its first 12 months of operation, as covered by the report before us, the AHC has been unsuccessful in endearing itself to Tasmanian growers who opposed it in the first place.

Tasmanian growers pay quite a substantial levy to the AHC, and one concerned grower told me that he was disgusted with the Corporation because the Taiwanese market has been opened up recently, with an import quota of nearly 50 tonnes, but the AHC sent a delegation of five people for a visit. If this in fact did happen, I too am quite unimpressed.

There are many other complaints. The upshot of it all is that at the next meeting of the Corporation, to be held in August, the Tasmanian contingent will likely move that the Association disaffiliate itself from the Corporation. If the vote goes this way I hope that the Federal Government will take note, be bold enough to make the tough decision and either axe the AHC or revamp it in such a way that it has the support of the growers of the products that it is supposed to be encouraging, assisting, facilitating and promoting-certainly by acting promptly and efficiently to stop dumping of overseas products on the local market.

DEBATE.TITLE: APPROPRIATION (PARLIAMENTARY DEPARTMENTS) BILL (No. 2) 1989-90[COGNATE BILLS:APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 3) 1989-90APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 4)1989-90SUPPLY (PARLIAMENTARY DEPARTMENTS) BILL 1990-91SUPPLY BILL (No. 1) 1990-91SUPPLY BILL (No. 2) 1990-91]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to the Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 1989-90, the Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 1989-90, the Supply (Parliamentary Departments) Bill 1990-91, the Supply Bill (No. 1) 1990-91 and the Supply Bill (No. 2) 1990-91 here tonight, I want to address my remarks to a major area of the Government's micro-economic reform agenda, and in particular the area of telecommunications.

SPEECH.PARA: It has been noted that the new Minister for Transport and Communications, Mr Beazley, has made significant statements with regard to the policies which were outlined during the election campaign. He has stated his continuing opposition to privatisation in the telecommunications area and an objection to complete deregulation. He has been quoted as saying that he takes this position because of concern about possible increased costs that would occur should privatisation or total deregulation take place. In particular, early this month he did so in a significant interview on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) Lateline program, quoted the next day in the Sun newspaper, for one, in Melbourne.

The same Minister is insisting on a degree of deregulation and, in particular, on competition in the telecommunications area, in particular for Telecom Australia. He said in the Melbourne Sun of 3 May that options for the telecommunications industry included the introduction of a private operator to challenge Telecom, or increasing competition between the other Government operators, the Overseas Telecommunications Commission (OTC) and Aussat Pty Ltd. Of course a number of inquiries are under way in this whole area.

The coalition too, it is worth noting, has Telecom in its sights. This was part of the election campaign, of course. As the Sunday Age said on 21 January, the coalition aims at a Telecom monopoly. Opening Telecom to competition and increasing services to the public in the first parliamentary session was a goal of the coalition should it have been returned to Government.

While the Minister may be opposing privatisation in pushing for a degree of deregulation, he is certainly moving down some of the track that was attractive to the Opposition during the election campaign.

This issue has been given prominence by the release of the draft report of Austel-the Australian Telecommunications Authority-on mobile telephone services. The most significant recommendation of that draft report, which was released early in April, was that the Government license three mobile telephone service operators to introduce competition in the telecommunications area. This draft report has gone out to industry for comment and discussion before final recommendations are made to the Government. It seems rather unbelievable that a recommendation for three operators in this report comes in a report which finds that there are not three operators in the mobile telephone service area anywhere else in the world and indeed that where there are duopolies there has been no improvement in service or price for the consumers.

The report focuses very much on what we should be doing with regard to the Telecom monopoly in particular. Many comments have been made about what appear to be aspects of the report that do not tend to make much sense. The report acknowledges, among other things, Telecom's excellent performance but then went on to recommend competition. It has not been able to find international evidence that having two additional competitors in the market would create any improvement. It simply asserts that. There is concern that this sort of report should be providing far more by way of evidence in making such a significant recommendation.

The report argues, again I think rather oddly, that changes in technology have undermined the rationale for a continued monopoly and that the market can support three competitive networks without harm to Telecom and, presumably, in the consumers interest. The argument that the development in technology is a good reason to break up Telecom was rejected. It was put by the Fraser Government in the 1982 report of the Davidson Public Inquiry into Telecommunication Services in Australia and rejected by the Labor Government when it first came to power. Yet we now find it again in this report. What I suggest is that the Labor Government should again reject that as an argument in this case. Telecom has proven its ability to utilise new technology and to pass the benefits on to the consumer. I will make more remarks about that shortly.

I now want to look at some of the other responses that this report generated in the community, in particular the response from Telecom itself. It is now a matter of public record that Telecom's response was quite strong. In responding to the report Mel Ward, the Managing Director of Telecom, pointed out that he believed that if that recommendation was to come into play the assumption that timed local calls were unacceptable would have to be `retested'. The spectre of timed local calls-they have been opposed on a number of grounds, not least on social justice grounds-was raised again in debate and will stay in debate while ever the question of this degree of deregulation and competition is accepted without evidence. As we have seen already in the Austel report, there has been a proposal without significant evidence.

Mr Ward also said at the time that as part of the cross-subsidy ability which Telecom has under its monopoly the subsidies that ensure rural users pay the same price for connection as that paid by city subscribers, even though the actual cost might be many hundreds of dollars more, would also have to be reviewed if Telecom were to face full competition. I quote from the Australian Financial Review of 17 April:
Telecom also warned that if the Government went down the path of greater competition, then Telecom would push-
I believe Telecom would have to push-
to be able to commercially set its interconnect charges-charges which would have to be paid by potential new competitors to plug into the basic telephone network.

That constitutes a warning of potential increased costs unless there is an expectation by potential commercial operators, as competitors, that they will in some way be able to build into their proposed operations an ability to feed off the basic network, which is a public resource in this country and one which certainly, in a nation such as Australia, will have to remain that way.

Australia is a vast country with large open spaces. We require a massive telecommunications infrastructure-probably as large as the transcontinental grid in the United States which, in comparison with our 17-odd million people, has a population of 250 million. It is vital that we are able to have the network and cross-subsidy operation which we have currently through the Telecom monopoly in order to be able to provide to all Australians access to basic telecommunication facilities.

The question of the development of technology is important here as one of the issues in this whole debate is and will be the decision about the continuing monopoly on the first telephone. If the community service obligations of Telecom are defined as being the provision of a single telephone on a hall table inside the home, we may very well in the future be restricting access to basic telecommunications to many Australians. Indeed, the Australian Democrats are concerned that the monopoly might be reduced to something like a connection at the boundary of individual properties, so that private connection can be made from the boundary into the home, because that would further diminish the opportunities for equity in the provision of basic communications facilities to all Australians.

As telecommunications technology has developed I believe that we have already gone far beyond an expectation that a telephone will do it all. We must leave open the opportunity for all Australians-including those on low incomes and those in isolated areas-always to have access to what is considered basic at the time because of the nature of the technology.

There may have been a time when Morse discovered his particular technology that there was an expectation that that would be the basic technology, the basic access to communications that everybody would have. If legislative decisions had been made at the time that determined that that was the case and if technological advances had not taken place quickly enough to show that there was in fact something else coming along, those who were not able to provide for themselves and plug into a very expensive network, which it would have been if it were not provided publicly, would have been vastly disadvantaged.

One of the challenges for all of us in the future is that we must not have a divided society. We have a divided society already where the rich are getting richer and the poor are getting poorer. We must not allow this to happen with information. We are in the information age and this will only increase. We must make sure that all Australians have access to basic information, as they all should have access to basic income support so that justice is served. Social justice ought to be the priority.

What we are really saying is that in this whole debate about the monopoly which Telecom has, how far that should be broken and in what areas that should be broken, social justice must always be the first thought and the first priority.

The fairly sharp responses that have come from the Austel report, given the lack of evidence and given the potential for destruction of much of the equity that is inherent in our telecommunications system, were quite justified. There is also the concern that there may be government decisions made before we have had the results of the various inquiries that are currently under way. The editorial in the Melbourne Age on 18 April was headed `Austel report points in wrong direction'. That editorial, amongst other things, many of which I have already pointed to, said:

Piecemeal inquiries such as that into the development of mobile telephone services imply an acceptance of internal competition without any examination of the broader implications or alternative strategies.
It concludes:

The Government should reject that Austel report with the contempt it deserves and appoint an inquiry into the broader implications and options of the telecommunications revolution, how Australia could best benefit from exploiting it, and whether privatisation of some of the services is in the national interest.
This reiterates the point that I have made about what is in the best interests of the wider community.

I now move beyond the mobile telephone issue because what we are really talking about is what Paul Lyneham said in the Sunday Sun on 21 January. He suggested that Telecom bashing was a new traditional Australian sport. It does happen a lot. It is one of the things that must be resisted at all costs and at all times. In that article Paul Lyneham used a great deal of evidence, more than I saw in the whole Austel report. He referred to comments made by the then shadow Minister for communications, Senator Alston, when the news came out that Telecom had made a $973m profit. I as a shareholder of Telecom was delighted, especially as Telecom is now liable to pay tax. Like any other major organisation I think we should all have been delighted. We were winning both ways, as people who own Telecom and as people whose national account would be boosted by a profitable enterprise paying its due taxes.

Paul Lyneham pointed out that it all seemed to be a bit of a problem because whenever Telecom has made a loss it has been kicked around the head by people of the ilk of Senator Alston and others and yet when it made a massive profit it was also kicked around the head. He went on to point out that with the staff nowadays numbering 84,000 it is the nation's second largest work force after the Coles-Myer group, another little duopoly almost. He pointed out that there are probably about as many-I will use his term-`bludgers' in that group as there are in the population at large. If we do occasionally see someone in that large work force perhaps not pulling his weight that is probably not something that should surprise us very much. He went on to point out that if we look back 15 years we will see that with 86,000 staff Telecom connected 335,000 new telephones but last year with 2,000 fewer on the payroll new connections had more than doubled to 682,000.

Senator Alston had apparently referred to Telecom as a sheltered workshop. Paul Lyneham felt that was pretty good productivity for a sheltered workshop. We should look at the cost of calls. In 1975 the maximum subscriber trunk dialling (STD) charge for three minutes was $2.70. Now it is $1.72. Over the same period a local call has gone up from 9c to 21c, a stamp from 9c to 41c and a litre of petrol from 14c to more than 60c. In terms of comparative productivity, the argument advanced by Paul Lyneham is a positive one, and one with which the Democrats agree. He concluded his article with a comment with which I also agree. He said:
Sure, they've got to keep boosting their efficiency and trimming their charges.

I would agree with that. I do not stand here and say that Telecom is a perfect entity and a perfect enterprise by any means. I am saying there is a distressing tendency for an increase in membership of those clubs which engage in that new Australian sport of Telecom bashing, quickly taking the place of the weather and mothers-in-law, as Paul Lyneham has said, as a key indoor sport. It is something that we would really want to work against and look at the reality.

Very recently the Public Sector Union, in defence of Telecom and in a desire to put on the record some of the facts, again jogged along by that Austel report, has produced a document which it is distributing. It is widely available and I commend it to all honourable senators before they decide to engage in this sport of Telecom bashing.

If we do take the view that deregulation, competition and privatisation are good for their own sake then we have to look at what has happened elsewhere. I will give just a few facts. In the United States the telephone system was deregulated from 1984. I will give a comment made by the director of the Consumer Federation of America. Surely that is what our telecommunications system is there for, the consumers. Five years after that deregulation he said:

You get a terribly skewed pattern, with the average consumer saving pennies on long distance and paying between forty five and sixty per cent more for local service. Most consumers have higher telephone bills overall than they did before the breakup.

People who may be impressed by the so-called independent reports that sometimes come out of Monash University and by the arguments advanced by the Australian Telecommunications Users Group that it is those long distance calls which they are trying to force down should look at the American experience. They will see that indeed the local calls did go up. The ordinary citizens, the basic community users and low income families, are the people who pay in that sort of situation. We have the evidence from the United States. As I have already shown, our long distance call charges have gone down in any case.

In April 1989-I am still referring to the United States-the national average residential rate of rental was $359 a year compared with Australia's rate of $140 a year. There are free local calls in very small localised areas in the United States. For example, in Washington local calls stop after 11 kilometres after which STD rates are paid. That contrasts remarkably with the increasing size of the local call zones here in this country and the community call which has a cheaper rate than that of the next zone. There is a good deal more I could say about the United States.

Let us look at the United Kingdom where a formerly publicly owned enterprise, such as we have here, has been privatised. Competition has occurred only within the lucrative business market. British Telecom is still a monopoly for residential consumers who are on full user pays regimes, including timed local calls. Of course, rural consumers will be very interested by that because full user pays can mean thousands of dollars simply to get a basic telephone line for people in isolated areas, and not just isolated areas but outside the major metropolitan and closely populated regional centres.

Service and quality have also deteriorated in the United Kingdom and the stories are legion. The consumer magazine Which in the United Kingdom found in a survey after July 1988 that most consumers had experienced no benefits from privatisation and competition. One of the points made to me was that the provision of the telephone directory in many areas has virtually ceased and many directories are several years out of date-which is a great help to someone with a telephone who wants to communicate-which is what telecommunications is all about-but who cannot find a telephone number because the telephone books are not up to date.

In New Zealand deregulation of the telephone network has meant higher prices for consumers. In the main capitals residential rental is $299.60 per year, compared with Australia's $140. User pays, as we have to anticipate here, also means that rural callers pay more than callers on main trunk routes. People in this country on the Sydney-Melbourne route will be salivating over the thought of carving up Telecom, but people elsewhere should not be. There have been higher total charges for residential consumers, and higher charges and poorer services for those outside the major cities. Taxpayer-funded budgetary payments for cross-subsidies, which are now funded by Telecom, would be the answer here. That is a major concern.

The proponents of removing the cross- subsidy, an inevitable result of this exercise, are suggesting that this is fine and that low income people or even people in isolated areas can be compensated by a budget line. We all know what happens to government expenditure. It is first carved up bit by bit in what is at the moment called the Expenditure Review Committee. But it is very difficult to get to the top of the priority list payments and expenditures which are there for small numbers of low income and disadvantaged people. There is ample evidence for that across the board.

In this debate about deregulation and micro-economic reform the Australian Democrats urge the Government to keep in its sights the continuing community service obligations of Telecom-not to reduce its thinking about what that entails-so that all Australians can expect the best of service. We are not saying that they already have `the best'. We are saying that they have a very good service, and there are a very high proportion of Australians who have the basic service. This has increased continuously, as some of the figures I have given show. We need to make sure that we augment this service. We do not want to carve it up, destroy it, and reduce the provision of social justice in this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Giles Sen P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In view of the latitude allowed to senators in debating the Appropriations Bills, I would like this evening to address briefly the significance of land to our Aboriginal population. This is a subject of which I am acutely aware at present, having spent some time fairly recently in the West Kimberley district of Western Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: I was delighted to hear the Government's commitment to `playing an educative and leadership role in bringing about a deeper understanding on the part of non-Aboriginal Australians of the culture, past dispossession and continuing disadvantage suffered by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people'. I am quoting and am continuing to quote:

The Government also remains committed to a genuine reconciliation with Australia's indigenous people. In particular, it will be seeking wide community support and bipartisan political endorsement of an instrument of reconciliation, variously referred to as a Treaty or Compact, between Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Australians and the wider Australian community.

The form and content of such a document will not and cannot be finalised until extensive consultation is initiated with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people and other Australians. This process of consultation will be enhanced following the recent establishment of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission.

The Government will continue to assist Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people to achieve broad equality with other Australians. To promote this goal, emphasis will continue to be placed on addressing land, health, education, housing and infrastructure needs and the further development of the Aboriginal Employment Development Policy.

I wish this evening to make a small contribution to that process. I felt that it would be extremely useful for honourable senators to hear of my experiences in a visit a few weeks ago lasting four or five days to the West Kimberley region. I took the opportunity to visit a number of new communities-communities which were previously referred to as outstations. They are new settlements. Some are very small, with just one or two extended families; other communities number up to 250 people. I believe they demonstrate clearly the value and significance of that association with the land, which is still not fully understood by many Australians who are not of Aboriginal descent. We are now seeing what has happened to the families who, within the last 30 or 40 years, were arbitrarily taken from their own lands and settled in missions or reserves close to towns. We are all well aware of the devastation that this caused, the day to day destructiveness that has manifested itself in the use of alcohol and other destructive substances. We are also aware of the destruction of the dignity of Aboriginals and of their self-determination.

Over the past few years a number of pastoral properties have been acquired for those Aboriginal families and groups who have expressed a desire to go back to their own lands. It is very gratifying to see the difference that such moves have made to the health and wellbeing of these families and groups. On the whole their living conditions are a great improvement on what they had been in the fringe camps and missions near the towns. Most of the communities are supplied with the prerequisites for dignified living in remote areas.

I imagine that one of the greatest requirements is an all-weather airstrip to make certain that communities a long way from health care will not be completely cut off in a crisis. A good water supply is absolutely crucial-most of these communities have this facility-as is a generator for electricity. Many of these communities are using solar technology in a very effective manner. One sees houses-in some places very good housing, though it varies-provided with solar water heaters. In some communities solar pumps are being used. Other communities-and I know that Senator Powell will be glad to hear this-are equipped with solar telephones. The health of these communities is attended to by frequent visits from trained nurses. The communities have contact with the Royal Flying Doctor Service. Communities that are too small to have schools of their own are beginning to use the Kimberley School of the Air. This is possible for these families because the younger parents have been educated and are literate, as I observed. In fact, I saw people in these communities filling out applications to go on the electoral roll.

One of the most gratifying aspects of this new life for these families is that they are able to restore their traditional skills. The women who have returned to the Mount Barnett Station are again creating their arts and artefacts and teaching the younger people. They have now returned to the land where the materials that are available to them are the materials with which they were familiar as children. The quality of the art and the artefacts coming from that area is quite remarkable. In fact, this work is leaving the area at such a rate and its marketability is so high that there is now a move to establish a museum in Derby so that the best examples can be kept there as a permanent exhibition.

The capacity for self-support in many of these communities is being developed through the community development employment projects scheme and I am told that there are at least six Aboriginal communities in the East Kimberley which have their own road building equipment and teams so that they are able to contract to the shires for building roads throughout the area, as well as in their own communities. One community is well advanced in planning to establish a roadhouse on the Gibb River Road, and this will be a way in which that community can engender some self-support. Many other communities have mustering teams which they contract out to pastoralists and, at the same time, the communities are building up their own pastoral properties.

One of the greatest advantages of these communities is that in most cases they are a long distance from the supply of alcohol. Living at Mount Barnett, for example, means a 350-km drive across a not very good road for anyone who wants to get alcohol. These communities on the whole have determined that they will be dry and thus able to keep their young people much more healthy. They can enjoy a happier and healthier lifestyle as a result. I cannot emphasise strongly enough the return to dignity that is possible in these circumstances-living in decent houses, away from alcohol, with proper education and health facilities and the capacity to develop economic independence, which was very difficult when they lived in close association with the towns.

We are all well aware of the continuing challenges facing Aboriginal communities, whether they are on remote outstations, like the ones I have described, or on the fringes of towns. Over the last few weeks we have seen reports of the high incidence of childhood infections, particularly ear infections leading to hearing loss. We have also heard of high infant mortality and morbidity rates compared with the non-Aboriginal population. Although the figures are much better than they were in the past, there is also the question of how good the data was in the past. One gets the impression that the babies and little children are well nourished and well cared for compared with the situation 15 or 20 years ago. Still, there are far too many infections which are not properly treated. The quality of housing and hygiene, the capacity to dispose of rubbish and the capacity of communities to have proper sewerage systems are extremely important, as they are with any community, regardless of the ethnicity of the population.

The other question that is of enormous importance to our Aboriginal communities is nutrition. This is especially so in remote communities where there is not easy access to fresh fruit and vegetables and the tendency is still for the diet not to be particularly good, especially among growing children. There is still the problem of the high incidence of babies being born prematurely and with low birth weights. This in turn points to the lack of good nutrition in their mothers and the fact that many Aboriginal mothers are quite young compared with the population generally.

There is another problem with maternal health, and that is the need to persuade Aboriginal women-the same as all women in the community-to give up smoking and avoid the use of alcohol if they want to have healthy babies. Gradually these matters are being dealt with and the communities are receiving continually improving care from the medical services generally and the Aboriginal Medical Services in particular. These services are now available in many parts of Australia. I am not saying they are available to everyone, but their availability has greatly improved.

The problem of violence is still with us in Aboriginal communities, as it is in the rest of the population. Over the past three years we have been conducting a national campaign throughout Australia to help people become aware of domestic violence as a social evil and as a crime. This is just as much a problem in Aboriginal communities as it is anywhere else. As a final phase of a three-year campaign, we have targeted particular groups with our advertising, projects and programs, and these groups include Aboriginal women, for whom a specific video has been made. An education campaign has been developed around that video.

It is a salutary thought that more women die in Aboriginal communities as a result of violence than young Aboriginal men die in custody. This tends to be as a result of living conditions, stress, and perhaps some traditional practices that have gone quite haywire, particularly with alcohol abuse. This makes the incidence of violence much higher than we might have thought. I have had the opportunity to talk to the older Aboriginal women of the Wantkajuntka community from Fitzroy Crossing about the possibility of a safe house there, and the planning for that is going ahead. The day that I was in Fitzroy Crossing a woman of 20 died as a result of head injuries.

This particular problem is one that Aboriginal communities themselves would want to approach in their own way and I believe that that should be the case. However, I also believe that as a wider community we have to do what we can to ensure that their living conditions, the circumstances in which they bring up their children and all the opportunities of their lives are such that these difficulties will be reduced to an absolute minimum.

That brings me back to what I started to say-that where Aborigines are able to resume their close association with their land, where they can live as they want to live, in dignity, with self-determination and with the assistance that we, as a wider and wealthier community are able to provide for them, we are able to restore their dignity and their capacity for generating income on which they can live. Thus we can restore their traditional values and skills while ensuring that they have the benefits of civilisation, if you like to call it that, in the form of housing, health and education of the best possible standard.
Debate interrupted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dunn Sen I.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable senators need no reminder of the public disquiet that exists concerning the state of Sydney's beaches. I have raised this matter several times in this place, largely as a result of sewage pollution. One would think that the poor example of Sydney's sewage pollution management would deter any local council elsewhere or any government department from making the same mistakes.

SPEECH.PARA: Unfortunately for the residents of Coffs Harbour, some aldermen of Coffs Harbour Council and the New South Wales Public Works Department want to impose the same fate on the northern beaches of Coffs Harbour by proceeding with an ocean sewage outfall at the Look-At-Me-Now Headland. This development is being urged by them despite strong local opposition to the outfall, the existence of viable alternative strategies to deal with the sewage effluent and the impact that the outfall is likely to have on the environment values of marine areas surrounding the Solitary Islands, which are opposite the Look-At-Me-Now Headland and which have been under consideration as a marine national park.

In June 1987, three years ago, 4,000 north coast residents marched on Woolgoolga Headland to protest against a sewage ocean outfall proposed for that site. Woolgoolga Headland at the time was the Council's preferred site. The march was led by the present Mayor of Coffs Harbour, Alderman Bernie Malouf. Following the public outcry, a commission of inquiry was established. As it turned out, the inquiry was seriously flawed. Dr Sharon Beder, a civil engineer who has completed a PhD on the subject of the Sydney Water Board's sewerage system, said of the inquiry that it had no independent technical expertise and was forced to depend on expert advice from engineers in the employ of the New South Wales Public Works Department and State Pollution Control Commission, the departments that supported the original decision favouring the ocean outfall. Commenting on the thinking of many professional engineers, Dr Beder told the North Coast Times newspaper that `ocean outfalls are traditionally preferred by sewerage engineers because of their education and limited experience with re-use options'.

While these facts suggest the reasons why the commission of inquiry reached its decision to recommend an ocean outfall at Woolgoolga, the path followed by the Coffs Harbour City Council to its final decision needs further explanation. The Council voted to follow the inquiry's recommendation but to shift the proposed outfall from Woolgoolga to the less populated Look-At-Me-Now Headland. The Council supported this site by five votes to four, a vote which could not be regarded as an overwhelming endorsement. It did so despite widespread community opposition to an ocean outfall anywhere in the Coffs Harbour area and the knowledge that viable alternatives had been put forward by local environmental groups such as the Stop the Outfall Pollution Committee, otherwise known as STOP.

This decision by Coffs Harbour Council highlights an important problem facing our society today, that is, the overwhelming reliance by decision makers on technical experts. It is a fact that such experts are often influenced in the advice they give by the need to maintain their good standing in conservative, often backward-looking professions with a clear interest in maintaining the status quo. What is especially deplorable about the decision in this case is that they are much the same experts whose advice has been accepted for many years, including advice that has led to the present state of Sydney's beaches.

Another factor may have affected the thinking of those Council members who voted in favour of moving the site of the ocean outfall to Look-At-Me-Now Headland. They may have thought that, because there are fewer residents at Look-At-Me-Now Headland than at Woolgoolga, there would be less resistance to the proposal. If so, they were proven to be mistaken.

At the previous local government election at Coffs Harbour `no outfalls' was a major plank in the platforms of many of the record number of candidates. Among the successful candidates who campaigned on a `no outfall' promise were the Mayor, Mr Bernie Malouf, and Alderman Rob Telford. It pains me to have to say that candidates for political office, even at the relatively humble level of local government, are capable of going back on their promises once they are elected. That is what happened in the case of both Mr Malouf and Mr Telford, who not long after their election made statements in favour of the sewage outfall development which they had formerly opposed.

So decided was the change in approach by Mayor Malouf that on 25 February last year, the Mayor threatened to resign because the New South Wales Minister for Environment, Mr Tim Moore, was pressing the Council not to proceed with the ocean outfall. At that stage Mr Moore was concerned at the effect the outfall might have on the environment of a proposed marine national park for the Solitary Islands.

More recently the balance within Council on this controversial issue has changed, with Alderman Norma Woods now supporting the anti-outfall residents. Mayor Malouf, who was so annoyed by Environment Minister Moore's interference, was not averse to arranging a bit of his own. The Mayor sought the support of the New South Wales Deputy Premier and Minister for Public Works, Mr Wal Murray, and encouraged his intervention in the matter. A report in a Coffs Harbour newspaper, the Advocate, dated 26 August last year, stated that Mr Murray supported Mayor Malouf's position on the outfall development at a National Party conference in Coffs Harbour which was also addressed by Malouf. Subsequently, concern has been expressed by residents and councillors at the possibility that Mr Murray's Public Works Department might not honour its commitment to provide the usual 50 per cent subsidy that applies to council sewerage developments for the northern beaches sewerage scheme because Council rejected an ocean outfall.

It seems to me that, if the Coffs Harbour City Council and the residents both support the alternative proposal of microfiltration technology and a dual pipe system to allow treated effluent to be reused for firefighting, irrigation and other industrial domestic uses, other than for drinking water, of course, Mr Wal Murray and his Public Works Department have no business interfering. It would be a great pity to see any repetition of the situation at Fingal Head, which was investigated by the Independent Commission Against Corruption. I refer to the intervention by Mr Murray in November 1988 when he stopped work on four Aboriginal Housing Commission homes. One of these homes was on land that Ocean Blue Club Resorts Pty Ltd was anxious to purchase from the Tweed-Byron local Aboriginal land council for part of its $200m resort project. The comparison is not out of place as resort development is an argument raised by the pro-outfall lobby at Coffs Harbour. Their argument is that Coffs Harbour needs more tourist development and that only a sewage ocean outfall would meet the demand. I would have thought that, if promoting tourist development was the aim, everything possible would be done to keep the area's ocean and beaches in a clean and unpolluted state. It hardly seems likely that tourists will flock to Coffs Harbour to swim in sewage effluent when there are such opportunities to do so in Sydney at Manly and Bondi.
Mayor Malouf was quoted in the Coffs Harbour Advocate newspaper on 26 August last year as saying:
We should go ahead with the outfall and if studies later show it's not needed we can block it off.
But, as his Deputy Mayor, Mr Brian Zouch, said in the same newspaper item:
The facts are that the (alternative) technology is already proven and the proposed outfall is already obsolete. So why spend the $1.6 million?

Why indeed? The only party that I can think of which would benefit from Mayor Malouf's proposal to build now and block later would be the Public Works Department, whose engineers would be given both jobs.

The Look-at-Me-Now Headland ocean outfall controversy provides an interesting backdrop to the New South Wales Premier's rhetoric about the need for better management of the public sector and economic rationalism. It also brings into question his Government's commitment to the Premier's call for better management of the `commons', in this case the ocean, set out at such length in Mr Greiner's Earth Day statement which he made last month.

There are two ocean outfalls already in operation in the Coffs Harbour area; one is at Sawtell and the other at Coffs Harbour. I believe the New South Wales State Pollution Control Commission sent a memorandum to the Coffs Harbour City Council not long ago asking the Council to monitor the water around these outfalls for organochlorins. These are the substances that have contaminated fish around the Sydney sewage outlets and caused the fishing industry considerable losses.

I remind honourable senators that government reports on pesticide levels in fish of up to 250 times the allowable limits in the Sydney area were kept from the public for over a year. It is to be hoped that the Coffs Harbour City Council and the State Pollution Control Commission will not repeat that disgraceful example. If the Look-At-Me-Now Headland sewage outfall were to be constructed, all incentive for Council to pursue alternative treatment and reuse systems would be gone. Experience has shown that the temptation to overload and abuse ocean outfall systems is almost too great for any administration to resist. No guarantee can be given by Council against future overload of the ocean outfall system. The proposed ocean outfall at Look-At-Me-Now Headland is not the only environmental problem that this area faces. The headland's continued resistance as a public reserve is under threat.

At present, Look-At-Me-Now Headland is crown land administered by the New South Wales Lands Department. It was resumed by the New South Wales Government 10 years ago for public use and to protect the area from development. The headland is the site of at least one rare and endangered plant species. It provides habitat for over 100 bird species, including the threatened osprey which builds its nest there. The confluence of southerly and northerly ocean currents off the headland has created a very rich marine environment in which both tropical and cold water fish occur together.

The headland also overlooks the most popular surfing beach for many kilometres around, as well as three safe swimming beaches which afford sheltered conditions in all weather. Recreational activities such as snorkelling, diving, fishing and bushwalking are available. Behind the headland is the Moonee Nature Reserve. This area joins the coastal crown reserve and provides a buffer for the estuarine system and the wildlife of the seashore and the dunal and heath areas.

On 5 December last year a public meeting was organised by John Allen and Associates of Coffs Harbour on behalf of the New South Wales Lands Department. The purpose of the meeting was to discuss the future management of the headland. The demands of the local residents were very modest. They wanted a fenced car park to prevent further damage to the headland by vehicles, and some walking tracks. Mr Peter Evans from the regional office of the National Parks and Wildlife Services told the meeting that the service could carry out this work for $35,000-a very modest amount. An official from the Lands Department told them that his Department could do it for $300,000 and would have to subdivide part of the headland and sell it off in order to raise the funds. Not surprisingly, those at the meeting found the offer from the Lands Department less than irresistible. They voted for Look-At-Me-Now Headland to be taken out of the control of the Lands Department and handed over to the National Parks and Wildlife Service to manage.

The Lands Department's vastly inflated costing of $300,000 may merely be a measure of its inefficiency. However, given the predisposition of the New South Wales Government to sell any piece of public land that it can get away with, I am inclined to the view that it was an attempt to justify subdivision and sale.

The proposed Solitary Islands Marine National Park off the coast has been the subject of controversy for some time. The idea of the marine park is more than 20 years old and dates back to 1969. The conservation proposal for the area was downgraded from the original aim of a national park to an aquatic reserve as a result of ministerial and interdepartmental wrangling within the New South Wales Government.

The marine national park concept appears to have been derailed by the efforts of Public Works Minister, Mr Wal Murray, the Minister for Natural Resources, Mr Ian Causley and the Minister for Minerals and Energy, Mr Neil Pickard. Should I even bother to mention that the mostly ineffective and politically inept Mr Moore, the New South Wales Minister for Environment, has lost yet another round with the National Party Ministers who really run New South Wales?

An aquatic reserve would be controlled by the New South Wales Department of Agriculture and Rural Affairs under the Fisheries Act. I hesitate to say that this authority would immediately clear the way for an effluent outfall from Look-At-Me-Now Headland. But I must observe that the Minister responsible for administering fisheries, the New South Wales Minister for Agriculture and Rural Affairs, Mr Ian Armstrong-from the National Party-apparently cares so little about the Department's responsibilities that he is forcing the whole organisation to move from Sydney to a site at Orange, some 300 kilometres inland, which is not even on a river.

Offshore mining interests are another factor in deciding whether or not the area will be declared a marine national park or an aquatic reserve. While there has been no final decision on mining, a number of exploration licences have been granted. Mining would be unlikely in a marine park because of the restrictions that apply to the approval of mining leases under the National Parks and Wildlife Act, whereas an aquatic reserve established under the Fisheries Act would, on the other hand, offer little resistance to mining.

The controversy over Coffs Harbour's ocean outfall continues to simmer. My most recent information is that the council has been persuaded to adopt the time-honoured political strategy of giving the matter to a committee to examine and to make recommendations. In this case, the issue is in the capable hands of the effluent committee, as it is called. One can only hope that the name of this committee, which is dominated by the State bureaucracy, is not indicative of the quality of the recommendations likely to flow out of it.

Honourable senators may be wondering about the relevance of this account of provincial affairs to the nation's Parliament. It is this: the matters which I have raised concern, in most cases directly, management of the environment in a part of Australia's territory which is properly the responsibility of the Commonwealth. The ocean off Coffs Harbour is part of the coastal sea, for which the Commonwealth has responsibility under international law and the Australian Constitution. It is significant that none of the many actors mentioned in this account include a representative of the Commonwealth. Issues such as the Coffs Harbour ocean outfall arise in many other parts of the country, yet the government with direct responsibility for the territory and resources most affected is hardly ever involved.

It is time for the Commonwealth to take seriously its responsibilities for managing the environment of this country. There is an obvious need for national standards to be established and enforced to protect coastal waters and their resources. It is no longer good enough for the Commonwealth to look on disinterestedly while the various State governments and numerous local authorities, all with different ideas and interests, struggle to find solutions.

This country is managing its environment with about as much unity and cohesion as was shown by the German principalities and Italian republics in the conduct of their collective interests in the nineteeth century. Regrettably, I do not see in the Government a Bismarck or a Garibaldi of the environment who can bring us together.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
